caption: Dear friends and supporters of YRSG,It has come to our attention that a group of individuals have been trying to sell keychains under the guise of a fundraiser initiated by the Yellow Ribbon Project. Yellow Ribbon Project and Yellow Ribbon Fund conduct fundraising activities in this manner and we have not authorised any individuals or groups to do so in public on our behalf.Charity organisations who are licensed to solicit funds in public will be granted a Collector's Certificate of Authority from the National Council of Social Services and a police permit.The authenticity of these documents can be verified by either sending an SMS to MCCY Charities Unit with the following "FR<space><NCSS Approval No>" to 79777, or checking the Charity Portal at may also report to the police immediately if you encounter any suspicious donation collectors.

The Yellow Ribbon Community Arts Festival 2025 is here! Launched at One Holland Village and graced by our Guest-of-Honour, President Tharman Shanmugaratnam .sg, and his wife, Jane Ittogi, the festival celebrates second chances through art, fashion and music.This years theme, We Are Each Others Second Chances, features 60 powerful artworks by 31 inmates who poured their stories and hopes into every piece. Their works are on display and for public adoption, with proceeds going towards rehabilitation and reintegration efforts.Whether youre interested in experiencing live music by ex-offender bands or participating in fringe activities like art workshops, be sure to look out for our Roving Arts Truck as it travels around Singapore this August. Find out more at: SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YellowRibbonCommunityArtsFestival SG60

It's official FoYRSG is LIVE on WhatsApp! Your all-access pass to second chance stories, upcoming events, and volunteering opportunities is now just a chat away.Tap the link in bio to join now and be part of the very first wave shaping a community beyond second chances. YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChancesBeyondSecondChances Communitychannel FoYRSG FriendsofYRSG

6 MORE DAYS TO GO! Friends of Yellow Ribbon Singapore (FoYRSG) is officially making the move to WhatsApp! From 1 August 2025, stay connected with us on WhatsApp for the latest updates, volunteering opportunities, events, and inspiring stories of second chances. More than just a channel, FoYRSG is a community. Lets continue building a nation beyond second chances together. Stay tuned, the WhatsApp link will be dropping very soon! YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChancesBeyondSecondChances Communitychannel FoYRSG FriendsofYRSG

In July 2025, YRSG partnered with ISCA and ISCOS to conduct a financial literacy workshop for supervisees, ex-offenders, and their families at .brewin.The initiative is part of a two-year Memorandum of Understanding between the organisations, aimed at creating career pathways and supporting the successful reintegration of ex-offenders through training and employment-related support. YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ISCOS ISCA

[LIMITED RELEASE] Celebrate Mid-Autumn with a mooncake set that tells a story of second chances.Introducing Heritage & Hope a sweet remix of Peranakan-inspired treats, whipped up by our talented inmate-bakers. These aren't your usual flavours. They're bold, unexpected, and dreamed up entirely from scratch. Flavours you'll fall for: Purple Potato and Yam with Macadamia Red Date with Salted Egg Putri Salat Green Tea Rose with Blueberries (crowd fav is BACK!)Each set comes in a reusable tingkat featuring artwork by an inmate-artist, a beautiful blend of batik and Vanda Miss Joaquim vibes. Orders open soon don't miss your chance to taste hope, heritage, and heart this Mid-Autumn!YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances YellowRibbonBakery YRBMooncakes Mooncakes Mooncakefestival2025 Handmadebakes

Age doesn't define impact and these young artists have proven just that.The Yellow Ribbon Art Competition 2025 invited students across Singapore to explore the theme "We Are Each Others Second Chances." Through stirring short films and powerful illustrations, these youths showed us how empathy, support, and hope can transform lives. Were deeply inspired by their heartfelt contributions to this years Yellow Ribbon Community Arts Festival. Swipe through to view the winning artworks, and catch the short films on Yellow Ribbon Singapores YouTube channel. Experience the winning entries in person at the Exhibition @ One Holland Village, happening 26 August.Together, lets nurture a society that believes in redemption, renewal and second chances for all. An official email will be sent to award winners and their respective schools from YRP_ARTs.gov.sg. Please note: Yellow Ribbon Singapore will never request personal details or payments from the public. Stay vigilant against impersonation scams..officialYellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances YRCommunityArtsFestival

Drop the Label, See the PeopleThat was the theme of this years Unlabelled Run, where over 6,200 participants united at the OCBC Square to build a more inclusive, cohesive, and compassionate society! This also marked the first time that the Yellow Ribbon Project collaborated with The New Charis Missions flagship run as an impact partner. Together with Guest-of-Honour Minister for Manpower Dr , staff members from both the and Yellow Ribbon Singapore, reformative trainees, ex-offenders, volunteers and community partners took part in the run which championed the removal of negative labels.Having marked this historical milestone, the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run will also be taking a pause to support this cause and will return better than ever in 2026. A warm thank you to all participants who ran with heart and for second chances. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore YellowRibbonProject UnlabelledRun Runningoutfit running runningsg DroptheLabelSeethePeople

"It doesn't mean someone is bad just because they made a mistake."Mdm Balbir Kaur may have retired from her accounting career over a decade ago, but she has never been busier. For the past 16 years, she has been a prison volunteer, supporting inmates and ex-offenders after their release.From teaching laughter yoga and positive thinking to helping them find jobs, Mdm Balbir brings heart, hope, and a whole lot of languages (yes, even Hokkien!) to every inmate she meets, walking with them every step of the way."Everyone deserves a second chance. I just want to help them believe in themselves again." YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances FriendsofYRP

In the lead-up to the Yellow Ribbon Community Arts Festival (YRCAF) 2025, inmate artists were given a meaningful opportunity to show their artwork, which will be featured at the Festival, to their families. Organised by the YRCAF Committee and the , the Family Joint Session was more than just a visitit was a moment to reflect, create, and heal. Along with their families, they viewed artworks together, designed keepsakes, and reflected on how far their loved ones have come. Come experience these powerful stories for yourself this August at YRCAF: Static Exhibition @ One Holland Village (26 Aug) Roving Art Truck, islandwide (231 Aug)Let's celebrate creativity that inspires change. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YellowRibbonCommunityArtsFestival

In 2011, Susanty Binte Yaakop was arrested and admitted to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre (DRC), after 20 years of drug abuse.In 2016, her life took another turn when her husband was incarcerated. Alone but determined, she chose recovery not just for herself, but for others like her.She founded Hijrah. Uzair. Fikir. Ikrar (HUFI) .bersatu, a ground-up initiative that supports women in recovery through holistic approaches: wellness, sports, mentoring and peer support.Susanty was referred by FITRAH, who opened up the opportunity for her to apply for a bursary from the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) and Singapore After-Care Association (SACA) . With their support, she completed her studies and earned a Diploma in counselling.Today, she walks alongside others who are also trying to heal themselves turning every second chance into a spark for change.YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ASecondChanceToMyself

Employers, did you know? You can receive wage support when you hire local ex-offenders? Through Uplifting Employment Credit, your business can benefit from wage offsets while championing inclusive hiring through providing employment opportunities. This scheme will be applicable to ex-offenders hired from April 2023 to December 2028. Find out more here: SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore

What a performance by the !On 6 April 2025, the took the stage and captured our hearts at the SiGlap 60 Carnival, a two-day intergenerational community event, which was honoured by the presence of Dr , Minister in the Prime Minister's Office, Second Minister for Education, and Second Minister for Foreign Affairs. A heartfelt thank you to Dr Maliki for his steadfast support as one of the five East Coast advisors!A memorable moment was when the band performed "You & I", an original song written by two members of the band in 2024 to commemorate the Yellow Ribbon Project's 20th anniversary. The piece carries a powerful message of resilience, hope, and finding the strength to look beyond mistakes and move forward together. Thank you to everyone who turned up, cheered them on, and stood in support of second chances. Rehabilitation happens one step (and one note) at a time. "It's never too late to rebuild your life from ground zero."Against all odds, Derrick Tan proved that a fresh start is possible. Armed with only a PSLE certificate, finding work was tough. But, he never gave up. Today, Derrick is employed, happily married and with a five-year-old daughter. He earned his driving license at age 36 and is set to collect the keys to his own BTO flat at 40.His advice, "There are no shortcuts in life. If you think you need help, please seek professional help. Most importantly, don't be afraid to change and acknowledge your mistakes. Your loved ones are there for you."Despite his multiple relapses and incarcerations, his family was always there for him. They never missed a chance to visit Derrick and continued to extend their love and support to him, pushing him to turn his life around. "I wish society could see the effort that we put into changing and listen to our stories. We just need a second chance, and sometimes all we need is just a person who will believe in us!" YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ASecondChanceToMyself

Step beyond 20 years of championing second chances with an exciting transformation! The Yellow Ribbon Project is happy to be supporting the Unlabelled Run on 28 June 2025 at the , in lieu of the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run.The Unlabelled Run and the Yellow Ribbon Project share the same belief that ex-offenders if given a second chance in life can contribute and pay it forward to society. The Unlabelled Run also has strong alignment with the Yellow Ribbon Projects mission of building an inclusive, cohesive, and compassionate society. From 2026, the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run will return with a brand new look, so keep a lookout for more exciting details that will be announced in time. What are you waiting for? Sign up now at and show your support! BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore YellowRibbonProject UnlabelledRun

"Inmates would typically start preparing for employment nearing their release or Community-Based Programme placement, leaving little to no time to explore their potential career paths and aspirations. The Career Circles Programme was introduced to bring career-related conversations much earlier in the incarceration phase." Bryan has been with YRSG for seven years, working on managing ex-offenders' reintegration back into society through gainful employment, supporting and guiding staff and leading initiatives with . Career Circles co-developed with inmates from the Empatherapy Hub in Institution B1 in 2023, aims to spark inmates interest in planning for their careers and help them understand common workplace challenges they may encounter upon release.SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSG YellowRibbonSingapore BeyondSecondChances

"I have come to see that everyone's story is different, but one truth remains with support, belief and compassion, they can rewrite their narratives."Ms Clara Yap, a volunteer with (SACA), has been passionately supporting the second chances movement since 1999. Her journey began with a community outreach initiative focused on helping ex-offenders reintegrate into society and 26 years later, she continues to be deeply moved by the resilience and stories of those that she has supported through her work."It is not always about fixing everything, but simply being there consistently, with empathy and without judgment."A moment that reminded her why this line of work matters was when one of her clients shared how Ms Clara had helped them by giving them a space to speak openly, without feeling labelled, and knowing that someone genuinely cared."My hope is that we can build a more compassionate and inclusive societyone that prioritizes rehabilitation over rejection and offers support instead of stigma." YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances FriendsofYRP

The Singapore Academy of Law's (SAL) annual charity futsal tournament, Chief Justice's Cup (CJ), was back for another edition in 2025. More than 160 members of the legal community joined to raise funds for the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) and the Singapore After-Care Association (SACA) . The event was graced by Matthew Wee Yik Keong, YRF STAR Bursary Chairman and Deputy Commissioner of Prisons (Operations & Rehabilitation) of the . The event raised a record of $205,000 this year and this amount will provide financial support to needy ex-offenders seeking vocational and skills training offered under the SAL-YRF Skills Training Assistance to Restart (STAR) Bursary and befriending services to the incarcerated and their families under SACA's Volunteer After-Care Programme. We would like to express our sincere gratitude to the SAL and all the participants at the CJ's Cup for their dedication in supporting the education and rehabilitation of ex-offenders and assisting their families, to offer second chances and hope.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore

17 individuals from seven companies across various industries participated in a Project Beyond Hiring workshop at .The session allowed participants to identify motivations, challenges, and performance issues faced by ex-offenders, while learning strategies for inclusion, effective communications, and coaching methods to enhance ex-offender employees' performance.We are grateful for the ongoing commitment of our partner employers in offering second chances to ex-offenders. The SPS-YRSG Corporate Advance at saw over 800 attendees, comprising staff and community partners. Themed Forward Corrections: Innovate and Collaborate, the event highlighted ongoing efforts to build community partnerships that uplift inmates employability.At the event, YRSG highlighted two initiatives: Career Circles programme, launched to equip inmates with the skills to set career goals and prepare for job searches. About 300 inmates have undergone the programme since its inception. Project Beyond Hiring initiative, introduced to enhance support for both employers and ex-offenders in the workplace.These initiatives aim to support the gainful employment of ex-offenders, enabling successful reintegration and longer-term desistance.Together, lets stride toward a more inclusive societyone where ex-offenders are given a second chance in every aspect of their lives and career development. YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances CorporateAdvance2025

Themed Forward Corrections: Innovate and Collaborate, the event highlighted ongoing efforts to build community partnerships that uplift inmates employability.At the event, YRSG highlighted two initiatives: Career Circles programme, launched to equip inmates with the skills to set career goals and prepare for job searches. About 300 inmates have undergone the programme since its inception. Project Beyond Hiring initiative, introduced to enhance support for both employers and ex-offenders in the workplace.These initiatives aim to support the gainful employment of ex-offenders, enabling successful reintegration and longer-term desistance.Together, lets stride toward a more inclusive societyone where ex-offenders are given a second chance in every aspect of their lives and career development. YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances CorporateAdvance2025

"I wish society would ask more questions rather than use label. If someone were to ask, 'Why did you do it in the first place?' they might gain a deeper understanding." For Hamzah bin Mohd Ariff, his reintegration process was not easy. However, through his actions, he managed to regain the trust and support of his loved ones.During his rehabilitation, Hamzah learnt the concept of 'Super-Substitution', which kept him busy by spending time with his family and new hobbies, instead of relapsing. Through it all, he found his relationships drastically improving, with his family being an anchor throughout his recovery journey. His advice, "Do not be afraid to seek help. There are people out there willing to support you, but you need to take the first step. Be confident, keep upgrading yourself, and stay positive." YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ASecondChanceToMyself

"In life, no one gets a redo, but we can give and receive second chances. As a society, we can benefit and heal from within if we are inclusive in our words and actions." Mr Avinash Mishra, Senior Sales Excellence Manager at Microsoft Singapore, has been a volunteer for YRSG and since 2021, teaching over 500 inmates Microsoft Excel and Powerpoint skills, to enhance their employability after their release."If we give ex-offenders a second chance for them to find a way to reintegrate with the society and be productive once again."One moment that stuck for Mr Avinash was when he received an email from an inmate attendee thanking him as the skills he had learnt from the workshop had helped him for his university classes."I am so proud that I had a small part to play in his journey. If we are able to impact the life of even one person positively for them to come closer to realising their potential, that is all that matters."YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances FriendsofYRP

"Rebuilding life after incarceration is more than just re-entering societyit's about finding purpose again." For Andrew Joseph Ng, co-developing Empatherapy has given him the chance to turn his past into a force for good, mentoring inmate peer supporters and creating a community of hope for inmates and ex-offenders alike. His journey hasn't been easy. Returning to a world that moved on without him, Andrew faced the weight of lost timestrained relationships, outdated skills, and the stigma that follows an incarceration record. Rebuilding trust with loved ones took patience. Adapting to rapid technological advancements meant relearning even the simplest daily tasks. Through it all, Andrew found strength in the very thing he advocates forcommunity. By surrounding himself with mentors, like-minded peers, and people who believed in his growth, he was able to navigate these challenges step by step. As he shares, "What will turn an ex-offender away from prison is when he or she has communities of support that they can count on. When people feel seen, valued, and supported, they are more likely to thrive." YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ASecondChanceToMyself

Mr Muhammad Ridhuan Bin Abdul Gaffor shares his journey of reintegration after multiple incarcerations, a path marked by struggles and self-reflection. A heartfelt letter from his daughter was the pivotal moment that made him confront the deep impact of his past actions, awakening a desire to change for the sake of his family. His advice: "Don't care about what others say. Move forward with your lifeyour future is in your hands. Set your goals and work towards them." Today, the bond with his family and children has never been better - a reminder that reintegration is about overcoming challenges, as well as personal growth and the pursuit of a better future. YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ASecondChanceToMyself

lovewins youareenoughThis March 8th, International Womens Day, I was invited to speak at Changi Female Prison. I brought my mum, making her dream come trueto return not as a prisoner, but as a beacon of hope. Mum was incarcerated in Changi from the mid-70s to 1983 for drug offenses. She turned her life around, living drug-free for decades. Her presence that day was a powerful message: *Its never too late to change. You are enough.* The inmates asked raw, valid questions about change and forgiveness. Mums life was the answerproof that no matter how far you fall, you can rise again. This day also reminded me of my familys 30-year journey to reconciliation. My parents divorced, and Dad remarried, but by Gods grace and effort, weve built a close-knit family. I adore my step-siblings, Adam and Andrea, and cherish the love we share. Ive been blessed with an incredible support systemmy overprotective brother, Spencer, who stepped up as a parent, my amazing aunties, uncles, and my Granny, who taught me, *Nothing is impossible, and family is worth fighting for.* To the ladies at Changi: Keep the faith. Believe in yourselves. Your past doesnt define your future. Never give up. And to anyone reading: Family and love are worth fighting for. Healing is possible. Grateful to AGAPE and Changi Prison for this meaningful opportunity. Forgiveness Reconciliation SecondChances Hope Family NeverGiveUp LoveWins

Our Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) STAR Bursary Networking Session on 1 March 2025 was a meaningful gathering of students, families, funders, and case workerscoming together to celebrate achievements, forge connections, and support one another. Through gratitude activities, a mental wellness workshop, and heartfelt conversations, we remain committed to walking alongside our students on their educational journey.A special thank you to our funders, case workers, and the YRF Secretariat for being part of this journey, and to Mr Matthew Wee Yik Keong, YRF STAR Bursary Chairman and Deputy Commissioner of Prisons (Operations & Rehabilitation) of the , for inspiring our students as they embark on their next chapter. We look forward to empowering more students on their path to rehabilitation and reintegration. YellowRibbonSingapore YellowRibbonFund SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Adeline Lee has been collaborating with YRSG since 2023, designing and implementing training programmes for inmates in the food services and retail sectors. Her strong passion for education and workforce development has empowered many individuals with incarceration experience to pursue meaningful career pathways."I want to be with them in their rehabilitation and reintegration journey by creating opportunities and equipping them with essential skills to enhance their employability upon release." YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

We all make mistakes; we are all human. Former offenders have already served their time; they and their families paid a significant price during incarceration and subjecting them to further stigma after release is unnecessary. Mr Lee Oi Wei, Integrated Ministry Care Lead at and a Befriender with the , has been involved in community work for over a decade, assisting individuals and families through challenging circumstances."It's incredibly rewarding to witness the successful reintegration of former offenders back into their families and society." Despite the many years he spent supporting their rehabilitation and reintegration, Mr Lee continued to be inspired by their faith, resilience, and belief in a better future for themselves and their families. YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances FriendsofYRP

For over 20 years, Chia & Thai Food Supplies has embraced hiring ex-offendersoffering more than just jobs; they provide stability, support, and an opportunity to rebuild. "It's about looking beyond the past and focusing on what they bring to the table today," says Samuel Koh, Director. By fostering an inclusive environment and offering support and mentorship, they've created a workplace where employees can thrive. Their advice to other employers? "Keep an open mind. You might just find some of your best employees where you least expect." YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

"Reintegration is a journey filled with challengesstigma, self-doubt, and the struggle to find purpose. But Ive learned that setbacks are opportunities for growth."Mr. Mohammed Sufian Bin Mohd Noor shares how discovering his inner strength and seeking support from loved ones helped him navigate through various challenges after his incarceration. With perseverance, he rebuilt his sense of identity and found purpose through volunteering and creative pursuits."I wish society understood that people like me are more than our past mistakes. With compassion and second chances, we can contribute, grow, and thrive." YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances ASecondChanceToMyself

YRSG held its first YR Connects of the year, celebrating The Power of Second Chances with employers who make a difference in the lives of ex-offenders. Their commitment to inclusive hiring and supportive workplace practices help create a society where providing second chances leads to lasting changes. Our special guest Associate Professor , Minister of State for Home Affairs & Minister of State for National Development thanked the employers and reaffirmed the importance of the community coming together to support ex-offenders reintegration. A heartfelt thank you to all who believe in the power of second chances. Lets keep building a more inclusive and brighter future together. YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Yellow Ribbon Singapore remains committed to empowering ex-offenders by equipping them with skills and providing employment assistance for their successful reintegration into society.In 2024: More than 3,900 inmates were trained in nationally accredited skills aligned with Singapore's Skills Framework. The average training hours per inmate trained was 102 hours. 94% of inmates referred to YRSG secured a job prior to release. More than 6,700 employers support hiring ex-offenders.We would like to thank our partners and employers for their invaluable support in the reintegration journey. Let's continue working together to create meaningful opportunities and build a more inclusive society. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore

"Social stigma frequently impedes successful reintegration into society, reinforcing cycles of crime, poverty, and marginalisation."I believe that fostering a culture that gives second chances can assist ex-offenders in rebuilding their lives, positively contributing to their communities, and lowering recidivism rates."Ms B Thanabavany Naidu, a volunteer with Muneeswaran Community Service and Volunteer Case Worker with the , works closely with supervisees and ex-offenders as they embark on their reintegration journey.She continues to upskill herself in the field of counselling and psychology, in hopes to share her knowledge to the individuals she crosses paths with. "I hope the society will develop greater empathy, understanding, and support for ex-offenders, recognising that people are more than the mistakes they've made."YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances FriendsofYRP

Throwback to the last run of Camp Cacti for 2024 that was held at =DREAMS in September. As part of the holiday camps, children got to participate in an art activity with their caregivers as well as in sports activities that allowed them to explore various parts of =DREAMS. A special shoutout to =DREAMS for partnering with Yellow Ribbon Singapore and making the event a success. =DREAMS is a first-of-its-kind initiative that offers a weekday boarding programme for Secondary school children from disadvantaged families, mostly living in rental flats or under financial assistance schemes. They empower the children to excel in their studies, improve social mobility, and uplift families toward a brighter future. Have a child in mind? Applications are now open, find out more at BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore

"To anyone struggling, remember that it's okay to seek help and lean on your community. Take one step at a time, and be gentle with yourself. Every small progress counts, and you are not alone in your journey. Believe in your strength and the possibility of brighter days ahead." Hear from Susanty, a Senior Patient Service Associate at a hospital as she shares what she hopes for HUFI, an addiction recovery support group she founded for Muslim women, and the support she received from her son during her own rehabilitation journey. Meet Chef Royce, whose journey from being an ex-offender to a celebrated chef is a powerful example of the importance of family support and how culinary arts have the power to transform lives.Since his release, Royce has actively participated as a Chef Mentor for the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competitions in 2020, 2021, and 2022, and as Chef Judge in the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition 2023. Royce is currently preparing to launch his social enterprise that focuses on Ready-to-Eat meals in 2025. He hopes to provide culinary training and career opportunities for ex-offenders and others who may be interested in entering the F&B industry.YellowRibbonProject SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

After overcoming years of addiction and incarceration, Aziz Bin Hashim has spent the last two decades helping others on their paths to recovery. His story is a powerful reminder that everyone who works hard in their recovery deserves a second chance, and with the right support, change is possible. Through volunteering, both locally and abroad, Aziz has seen how initiatives like the Yellow Ribbon Project can make a difference for inmates and ex-offenders, as well as the entire community around them. Together, we can break down barriers and create a more inclusive future. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

For the past 16 years, Mohammed Nazim Bin Rahuma Dulla has been a source of emotional and spiritual guidance for inmates and ex-offenders. Through Islamic education and counselling, he supports their journey towards rehabilitation and reintegration, extending that care to their families as well. Nazim believes that the Yellow Ribbon Project plays a crucial role in inspiring hope, not just for those behind bars, but also for their loved ones. His message is clear: treat ex-offenders as equals, without judgment. Everyone who is willing to work hard to rehabilitate deserves a second chance to move forward. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Capping the Yellow Ribbon Project's 20th anniversary celebrations with the performance of a lifetime! 2024 saw many community initiatives that spread the message of second chances and celebrated 20 years of fostering hope, developing resilience, and supporting inmates and ex-offenders in their rehabilitation and reintegration journeys. The Concert also celebrated those who have made our own journey possible, from community partners to volunteers.Whether you checked out our Moving HeARTs in the City exhibition or attended this year's Yellow Ribbon Prison Run, thank you for doing your part and supporting our cause! Here's to 20 more years and beyond of being each other's second chances.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

The Yellow Ribbon Project partners with various organisations to support the reintegration of ex-offenders into society. One of such organisations which has demonstrated strong support for the Yellow Ribbon cause is . This festive season, Geneco has partnered with a non-profit organisation which partners to conduct family programmes for inmates to help to break the cycle of intergenerational incarceration and co-created the book, Love Beyond the Walls: Till the End of Time.Written by inmates participating in the family programmes facilitated by NLS and illustrated by former inmate artists from CANVAS, this heartfelt book features 10 stories that convey love and hope from the incarcerated parents to their children. You can pre-order at: If you would like to receive the book in time for gifting this Christmas, the book will be available for purchase at Genecos Till the End of Time pop-up event, happening outside Ngee Ann City, from 12 to 18 December, and 100% of proceeds will go directly to NLS.Limited edition Yellow Ribbon Project 20th Anniversary Hope Bears will also be available for purchase at the event, and 100% of proceeds will go towards supporting the Yellow Ribbon Fund. Image credits: Geneco YellowRibbonProject YRP20 YRPHopeBears YellowRibbonFund Geneco GenecoSG TillTheEndofTime SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Meet Muhammad Ridhuan Bin Jailer, a visual artist and member of CANVAS Art Interest Group, whose story of transformation is a testament to the power of resilience. Shirin Nadia, People and Culture Partner at , shares how their commitment to second chances has paved the way for over 400 ex-offenders to rebuild their lives through training, career development, and a supportive community. Their success stories are a testament to the power of acceptance and opportunityshowing how, when given a chance, lives can be transformed. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Camp Cacti initiative was awarded the prestigious 'City of Good' at the President's Volunteerism & Philanthropy Awards 2024.Funded by Hope Foundation, Camp Cacti is a year-long programme that invites children from agencies supported by Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG), to participate in programmes during their school holidays. YRSG congratulates CapitaLand Hope Foundation and its charity partners, , Fund and for the collaborative initiative to empower children in their personal growth by fostering social and emotional resilience and promoting character development.Are you part of an organisation who wants to do more? Find out how you can contribute by visiting our website at SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

In November 2024, 16 participants from eight different companies across diverse industries participated in a Project Beyond Hiring workshop at the . This initiative focuses on enhancing supervisory skills for managing ex-offenders in the workplace. This session was conducted through a mix of interactive methods, including group discussions, role plays, theoretical lessons, and assessments. It ended with a dialogue session featuring a YRSG career coach. The career coach shared insights into his role and engaged in a Q&A with employers, providing valuable perspectives on supporting ex-offenders in the workplace. We are grateful for the ongoing commitment of our partner employers in offering second chances to ex-offenders. Let's continue to stride towards a more inclusive society. If you are interested in inclusive hiring, do find out more at our website SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSG YellowRibbonSingapore BeyondSecondChances

Organising a Culinary Competition during a Pandemic. In 2021, the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition was organised in collaboration with the Singapore Chefs' Association. Themed "Recipe for Change," the culinary competition showcased the determination of participating inmates, as well as, resilience of our community partners during the COVID-19 Pandemic. Having to maintain safe distancing meant that all training for inmate participants had to be conducted virtually. Judging, too, had to be conducted virtually and feedback was provided via video. In the end, it was all worth it, especially for the inmates who participated. They were able to share their dishes with their loved ones, who received a special delivery as part of the competition. Stay tuned for the return of the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition in the future!BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

While there has been progress in raising awareness for second chances, Gurdip Singh from Drumkin Impex believes that there is still a lot that the community can do to reduce the stigma for those with past convictions. Drumkin Impex has been an early adopter of second chances, employing individuals with incarceration records since the 1980s! Gurdip shares that where possible, one should always make an effort to make ex-offenders feel belonged, both in society and at work. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

When ex-offenders feel true acceptance and belonging, everyone wins. Malika Kaur, Assistant Manager at Dashmesh Singapore Pte Ltd, shares the company's endeavours in ensuring that ex-offenders feel a sense of belonging to the company and making sure they feel valued and appreciated. As a result, they see ex-offenders who meaningfully engage with their work and become invaluable additions to the unit. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Christopher Chia faced many challenges including relapses and a constant battle with his inner demons. While he had the opportunity to pursue a degree while in prison and eventually graduating with double majors in Sociology and Psychology after his release, he found it challenging to secure stable employment due to his past. Since then, he has witnessed a change in the way employers and organisations view individuals with past convictions, thanks to efforts by the Yellow Ribbon Project. Christopher now plays an active role in supporting and guiding ex-offenders as they reintegrate into the community. He does this in his capacity as a social worker, as well as a volunteer with numerous organisations to raise awareness and advocate for second chances. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Were excited to share about Yellow Ribbon Industries Pte Ltd-Yellow Ribbon Fund booth at the Makers Market! This is a fantastic opportunity to see the pottery products created by our talented inmate artists from the Visual Arts Hub, showcasing their creativity and craftsmanship. Proceeds from the sale go to the Yellow Ribbon Fund to support the rehabilitation and reintegration programmes for our inmates, ex-offenders and their families.Event Details:Location: Singapore Chinese Cultural Centre, Table D10Dates: Friday, 8 Nov, 11 am 7 pm Saturday, 9 Nov, 11 am 7 pm Sunday, 10 Nov, 11 am 6 pmCome support our booth at Table D10 and see firsthand the amazing work that reflects the journey of our inmate artists. Your encouragement means a lot to us, and wed love to see you there.YellowRibbonSingapore YellowRibbonFund SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

The Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) had a meaningful Get-Together session with 30 STAR Bursary students and their family members at Our Tampines Hub on 12 October 2024. The event was graced by Matthew Wee Yik Keong, YRF STAR Bursary Chairman and Deputy Commissioner of Prisons (Operations & Rehabilitation) of the , who presented certificates to graduating and new students. The students also received laptops donated by SGBono. The event culminated in a fireside chat with two of the graduating students, Susanty Binte Yaakop and Naresh Kumar, recounting their educational paths, obstacles faced, and personal insights. We look forward to empowering more students on their journey in rehabilitation and reintegration.YellowRibbonSingapore YellowRibbonFund SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Picking yourself up after a series of relapses is not an easy feat - take it from Azmi Bin Abdul Rahman.Having been incarcerated nine times, his last incarceration in 1996 was a turning point that started him on his path of recovery. Having benefited from an anonymous support group as part of his rehabilitation, he co-founded his own support group called Agents of Change, which helps others to navigate life after prison. His advice for other ex-offenders? "Just give yourself a chance. Go to a support group and listen. Give yourself a chance, surrender everything and gain acceptance."BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Impacting Lives, One Tune at a Time. Meet Mohammad Ridzwan Bin Abdol Latiff from the Yellow Ribbon Performing Arts Centre (PAC) Alumni Band, and his mentor, Aaron Lim, Master Vocal Coach and Director at Since his release in 2015, Ridzwan has used music as a source of personal growth and meaning.This year, Ridzwan and his bandmates from the YR PAC Alumni Band performed across Singapore as part of the Moving HeARTs In The City Roving Arts Truck Exhibition. They recently took the stage at the Yellow Ribbon Project 20th Anniversary Concert, performing alongside other local singers at The Star Performing Arts Centre. Discover more about the band's journey and others who are championing the cause of second chances in the Yellow Ribbon Project 20th Anniversary E-Publication: SecondChances YellowRibbonProject BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YRP20 YRP20Concert2024

Meet SUPT Luke Leong, the Superintendent of Institution Tanah Merah 1 & 2, which houses inmates studying at the Prison School as well as young offenders at the Reformative Training Centre. He is also the Chairperson of the Yellow Ribbon Project 20th Anniversary E-Publication Committee. He reflects on his experience collaborating with SPS officers and colleagues from Yellow Ribbon Singapore to conceptualise, develop, and launch the e-publication to commemorate 20 years of second chances. If you'd like to read the three-part e-publications, visit:Unlocking The Second Prison: Second Chances: Are Each Other's Second Chances: Together, let's stride towards a more inclusive society for inmates and ex-offenders! Were excited to recap our recent YR Connects, themed Second Chances & Sustainable Futures: Championing Inclusive Workplaces, held in September! We brought together employers from diverse industries, all eager to explore innovative workforce solutions. A heartfelt thank you to TAFEP and NVPC for their invaluable insights on flexible work arrangements and the Company of Good initiative.Participants left feeling inspired and ready to embrace new possibilities in their workplaces. One attendee remarked, The discussions today opened my eyes to the future of work. Its encouraging to see so many companies prioritizing flexibility and employee well-being!Thank you to everyone who joined us! Together, were creating a more adaptable and inclusive work environment.YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Our community partners, donors and employers have been instrumental in the success of the Yellow Ribbon Project.2019 marked a historical amount of money raised for the Yellow Ribbon Fund and the launch of the "Moving Forward Together" exhibition. A sequel to 2018s exhibition, this showcased 100 artworks and 23 poems created by inmates. Each piece of work expressed creative interpretations of their rehabilitation journey and aspirations! Thank you all for supporting this year's Moving HeARTs in the City roving art truck exhibition. See you at our next art exhibition!BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

A Song for Second Chances Since 2017, Sara has been part of the Yellow Ribbon Project, starting with a songwriting competition during her incarceration. Music became her outlet, connecting her with others facing similar challenges. "After my release, I navigated a whirlwind of emotions, music has been my anchor, guiding me through my darkest moments." Now, Sara is set to perform with .wav at the Yellow Ribbon Project 20th Anniversary Concert! This special performance is about embracing change, spreading kindness, and showcasing the power of second chances. Keep an eye on our social media for exclusive concert highlights! YRP20Concert2024 SecondChances YellowRibbonProject BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Gopal Mahey's difficult childhood and poor choices led to his incarceration for substance abuse. Reflecting on his journey, he credits his turnaround to the invaluable support and forgiveness from his wife, family, and in-laws, and the sense of discipline that he gained in prison. He also credits his transformation to the Yellow Ribbon Project, which provides support to ex-offenders like him as they strive towards reintegrating into the community.Having successfully conquered his demons, Gopal now spends his time working as a psychotherapist, helping others who are either struggling with addiction, are in recovery or have their own reintegration challenges. He is also an active volunteer, sharing his personal experiences with others and offering guidance and support in their time of need.RecoveryJourney SecondChances YellowRibbonProject VolunteerImpactBeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Making art out of second chances. In 2018, the Yellow Ribbon Project and the celebrated nine years of fruitful partnerships with an exhibition themed "Transitions:Crossroads & Choices". The exhibition, which was launched by then President of Singapore, Mdm , showcased 78 artworks that were the result of a year-long collaboration between inmates and artist mentors. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Meet SUPT Lim Hui Juian, the Officer-in-Charge of a Correctional Unit in Institution A4 at the (SPS), who is also the Programme and Partnerships In-Charge for the upcoming Yellow Ribbon Project 20th Anniversary Concert 2024! She shares her experience working alongside SPS officers and colleagues from Yellow Ribbon Singapore, conceptualising and planning the concert's programme. You can join us to catch performances by local artistes, as well as talented ex-offenders, as they share their stories on conquering adversity. Life hadn't been rosy for Thomas Koh, but he managed to defy the odds and build a successful business. However, at age 39, everything crumbled around him due to prolonged substance abuse, and he attempted to take his own life.Now, almost 10 years sober, Thomas volunteers at various organisations to help others overcome their vices and start anew. He credits his recovery to his support group, role models, and the three-week inpatient recovery program. The journey was made easier by the Yellow Ribbon Project's efforts in building an inclusive society, making his reintegration less challenging. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Over 22 days and 16 locations, the Moving HeARTs In The City art truck journeyed across Singapore, celebrating creativity , transformation , and the power of second chances . With over 10,000 visitors to the truck and 34 artworks adopted, weve shown how art can inspire change and new beginnings.A heartfelt thank you to everyone who visited, adopted artwork, and joined in the activities! Together, weve championed second chances and created something truly meaningful. P.S. You can still browse the catalog and adopt a piece until 31 Dec 2024. Explore here: SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20 MovingYRHeARTs

One of the challenges many ex-offenders face is finding employment after their release. The willingness of organisations and companies to hire ex-offenders is a crucial aspect that increases their chances to successfully desist. Rachel Lee, HR Director from Guzman y Gomez, shares how the company collaborates with Yellow Ribbon Singapore to integrate inclusive initiatives into their hiring practices, establishing a comprehensive support system to support the successful reintegration of incoming and existing crew members. We truly appreciate all the efforts of our partners who seek to bring down barriers and embrace ex-offenders for their skills, experience and characters, rather than their past. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

The Yellow Ribbon Project is honoured to have received the Presidents Award at the International Corrections & Prisons Association (ICPA) Correctional Excellence Awards Ceremony during the ICPA Annual Conference 2024!Over the past twenty years, we have made remarkable progress in championing second chances for inmates and ex-offenders. Heres to many more years of garnering support for second chances, towards a more inclusive Singapore. Celebrating 20 years of Second Chances together at the International Corrections & Prisons Association (ICPA) Annual Conference 2024! On 4 September 2024, Yellow Ribbon Community Day was launched as part of Regional Day at ICPA Annual Conference 2024. After an opening address by Chief Justice of Singapore, Sundaresh Menon, ICPA delegates and community partners shared their experiences during various plenary sessions and workshops.The comprehensive sharing underscores how efforts by SPS and other CARE Network partners provide crucial support to offenders towards successful desistance. As part of the celebrations, the Yellow Ribbon Project also launched part two of the web publication, "Celebrating Second Chances", which showcases stories from the community, highlighting their journeys and showcasing the resilience and hope that comes with second chances! A huge thank you to everyone for your continued support in supporting the rehabilitation and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders. Check out both parts of the 20th-anniversary web publication here:Part 1: Part 2: SingaporePrisonService BeyondPrisonWalls ICPA2024 EnablingDesistance BeyondRecidivism CaptainsOfLives SecondChances YellowRibbonProject BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

A HUGE thank you to all runners who put their best foot forward and ran in support of a Nation Beyond Second Chances! On 1 September 2024, Guest-Of-Honour, Senior Minister , flagged off this years Yellow Ribbon Prison Run. He was joined by Minister for Digital Development and Information & Second Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs .ylm. This event welcomed about 11,000 local and overseas participants, taking part in 10km or 5km run categories. This year also saw the introduction of the inaugural Kids Dash category, as we seek to inspire the younger generation about the importance of giving second chances!The 15th edition of the Yellow Ribbon Projects (YRP) flagship event also coincided with YRPs 20th anniversary celebration. As we move beyond two decades of championing second chances, the YRP hopes to expand collaborations and encourage more community partners, while also empowering desistors to play a more active role in leading projects and initiatives.In addition to the record number of participants for the YRP run event, the run had also raised a total of $557,370.00, which was the highest ever since the event was introduced! These funds will go towards various programmes that support the rehabilitation and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders, as well as support their families and children to prevent inter-generational offending.For participants who completed the 10KM Competitive Run , you can check out your race timings here: in the next few days. Thank you for being part of the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run, and see you next time!yellowribbonprisonrun 2ndchances SG4SecondChancesYellowRibbonProject YellowRibbonSingapore aNationBeyondSecondChances YRPR24 YRP20

For Dr Riduan, the initial years after his release were a relentless struggle against the fear of relapse. His dedication to helping others stems from a deep desire to prevent them from facing the same challenges he did.Heartened by the shift in public perception and the growing support for ex-offenders, Dr Riduan expresses his gratitude to the Yellow Ribbon Project for its role in transforming stigma into compassion. Join us to celebrate 20 years of championing second chances, towards progress and dedication, together.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Tackling personal challenges and inspiring change are key features of Alexiss reintegration journey.Overcoming the shame and self-criticism she developed after her incarceration, the unwavering support of her family, friends, and faith helped rebuild her life.Today, through her dedicated work with Prison Support Services, the New Hope Community Services and Homeless Hearts of Singapore, Alexis is giving back and creating opportunities for others. Her involvement with the Yellow Ribbon Project is helping shift societal attitudes and open doors for second chances. Lets celebrate the power of recovery and the incredible impact of second chances. RecoveryJourney SecondChances YellowRibbonProject VolunteerImpactBeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20 MovingYRHeARTs

What does 'Hope' look like to you? For 42 inmate artists in 2016, it was expressed through various paintings and art forms. Each was showcased for the first time at the 'From Night To Light' exhibition at the (SAM)! Launched during the Singapore Night Festival 2016, the exhibition was led by SAM curators and 2 YRP volunteers, Kim Whye Kee and Barry Yeow, who were both ex-offenders and former inmate artists from the Visual Arts Hub. Together, they provided invaluable technical guidance and creative consultations to inmate artists, helping them go beyond their limits to express their personal hopes. Want to see more inspiring work from inmate artists? Check out our 'Moving HeARTs in the City' roving art exhibition! Stay tuned for more details. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Having been an SPS volunteer since 1998, Jimmy Yuen has helped and supported many inmates and ex-offenders to navigate this challenging phase of their lives. SPS's volunteers, like Jimmy, are crucial to the successful rehabilitation and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders. Not only do volunteers help them through this journey of change and redemption, they also help offenders embrace their second chance at life wholeheartedly.And the proof is in the pudding. Over the years, Jimmy has seen changes and improvements in the perception and attitudes towards inmates and ex-offenders, particularly since the launch of the Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP). To this date, he continues to support YRP towards an inclusive society for all. If you'd like to find out more about volunteering with SPS, visit: BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Every journey begins with a single step (or a single serving of food).In June 2014, The Hope Caf Training Kitchen and Restaurant was launched at Changi Prison Complex to equip eligible inmates with Workforce Skills Qualifications (WSQ) Certificates in Culinary Arts and Food & Beverage Operation.These qualifications, combined with the hands-on training provided, enhance the employability of the inmates, which allows them to contribute to society upon their release and desist from a life of crime.This would not have been possible without a collaborative effort by Yellow Ribbon Singapore, Workforce Singapore and .BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore YRP20 YellowRibbonProject

ICYMI Were thrilled to launch the Yellow Ribbon Projects Moving HeARTs In The City, a roving art exhibition showcasing artworks from inmates and ex-offenders, on 31 July 2024! Our Guest-of-Honour, Mr , Minister for Transport and Second Minister for Finance, kickstarted this meaningful journey at the LASALLE College of the Arts.This roving art exhibition, themed Our Journey, Our Hope, showcases the remarkable talents of inmates and ex-offenders through 41 stunning artworks. From canvas paintings to pottery and mixed media, these pieces reflect their rehabilitation journey, embodying hope and the quest for second chances. Stay tuned as we travel across Singapore, bringing these powerful stories to life at:1 Aug, 11am - 7pm Ang Mo Kio Public Library 3 and 4 Aug, 11am - 7pm by the Bay (Beside the Canyon) 8 Aug, 11am - 7pm Regional Library 10 Aug, 4pm - 9pm at National Day Heartland Celebrations 2024 Singapore (Bishan) 11 Aug, 11am - 7pm Holland Village (Main entrance) 17 and 18 Aug, 11am - 7pm + 24 and 25 Aug, 11am - 7pm City Convention Centre 1 Sep, 8am - 2pm at the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run End Point Carnival in Changi Prison ComplexSee you there! BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20 MovingYRHeARTs

Attention friends and supporters! Fake accounts under the guise of YRSG and YRP have been requesting for the personal details of our participants, which may follow a request of fee payment.We have not authorised any individuals or groups to reach out to our followers on our behalf for any purpose, nor do we ask our followers to click on any links. Winners for our giveaways will be notified via DM on our official accounts. If you receive such messages or comments, do not click on any links or share your details.You may reach out to us at: Feedback.gov.sg, if you have any questions or concerns.

Alif was inspired to support other ex-offenders as he was at the receiving end of stigma from his prison sentence. He spent the last seven years volunteering with various organisations to help other ex-offenders in their rehabilitation and reintegration journey. Hes witnessed and experienced the impact of the Yellow Ribbon Project through the years in helping ex-offenders, who now feel more comfortable in asking for help and sharing their experiences and challenges with others. In doing so, they found that help and support is available for them, when they need it, along with other opportunities too. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

Edna's passion for volunteering with the Yellow Ribbon Project was driven after witnessing the difficult emotions that families go through when an ex-offender returns home after being in prison. Having been a Yellow Ribbon Community Project volunteer since 2012, she continues to do so despite her tight schedule because she understands how meaningful her contribution is to this cause.Through working closely with volunteers, like Edna, we continue forging the path ahead for ex-offenders by helping them navigate this journey and work towards reducing the society's stigma towards ex-offenders, one step at a time.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

The journey towards successful desistance didn't come easy for Hannah. She was incarcerated twice in 10 years due to her drug addiction and delivered her child while serving her second sentence. She fought hard to overcome her addiction and to turn her life around. Now, Hannah dedicates her time to helping other women who are recovering from drug addiction."I hope to see more successful stories among women (with addiction disorder) and help to improve recidivism rates in Singapore."To her, a strong network of support, like the Yellow Ribbon Project, as well as the encouragement from family, is essential to help inmates and ex-offenders embrace their second chance at life. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonProject YRP20

This June school holidays, over 30 volunteers and Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP) volunteers came together to organise the latest run of Camp Cacti, which focused on inspiring the children to be community changemakers. The volunteers had a great time interacting with children from the following agencies: , , , and . Together, they went on an amazing race to find "Singa, The Courtesy Lion" and engaged the seniors from Thye Hua Kwan (THK) Active Ageing Centre through dance workouts and games.A special shoutout to CapitaLand Hope Foundation, the philanthropic arm of CapitaLand Group, for supporting Camp Cacti since 2022, which aims to build the socio-emotional resilience of vulnerable children from incarcerated families.YellowRibbonProject YRP20 YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

On 3 July 2024, the Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP) and .happiness celebrated a milestone - earning a place in the (SBOR)! This was achieved together with support from the community by stitching together the largest patchwork blanket, measuring 20 x 24.6 meters. Comprising 15,255 hand-stitched patches, volunteers from the community contributed to the patchwork blanket as a symbol of the evolution of YRP - from raising awareness of the importance of giving second chances to ex-offenders and their families, to inspiring community actions through advocacy efforts. Thank you to our key partners from , Logwin Air + Ocean Singapore Pte Ltd, and the Zone 8 Sewing Interest Group, who also played an instrumental part in this significant achievement. Thank you to one and all for making this possible! YRP20 YellowRibbonProject SGBOR SGBookOfRecords BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

"I'm coming home, I've done my time.Now I've got to know what is and isn't mine." Do you know the lyrics to 'Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round the Ole Oak Tree'? The 1970s hit song inspired the name of the Yellow Ribbon Project! Project Beyond Hiring is an initiative where YRSG engages, trains and builds a network of workplace supervisors, with the aim of uplifting employers and enhancing workplace support for ex-offenders. In May this year, a group of partner employers from the logistics industry came together to attend a 1.5-day workshop on 'Master Workplace Coaching and Mentoring' conducted by NTUC Learning Hub. YRSG's career coaches and trainers from The Logistics Academy facilitated group discussions on overcoming challenges at work. We appreciate the continuous efforts that our partner employers put into providing second chances for ex-offenders and look forward to bringing more on board to join us on this journey. The year 2013 saw the Yellow Ribbon Project celebrate its milestone 10th anniversary! There's no better way to recognise the community's support than to get them involved in a historical feat! The formation of the giant Yellow Ribbon in Singapore, organised after the year's Yellow Ribbon Prison Run, symbolises the concerted effort to support the rehabilitation and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders. A decade on, our community remains stronger than ever. Look out for more history-in-the-making with our YRP20 celebrations this year!BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore YRP20 YellowRibbonProject

Happy Father's Day! Meet Hamzah, a desistor and proud father of three, who has dedicated himself to rebuilding and strengthening his family bond. Hamzah's journey as a father is a testament to love, resilience and growth. Despite facing significant challenges in maintaining familial ties due to his detention, Hamzah persevered, eventually gaining his family's trust and deepening their connections. With support from and , Hamzah continues to learn and grow as a father, while also giving back to the community by helping others like him. His journey reminds us of the incredible power of family and the importance of never giving up. YellowRibbonSingapore BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances FathersDay

A purr-fect second chance for all ex-offenders. In 2012, the fourth ever Yellow Ribbon Prison Run was flagged off with over 10,000 participants, including one extraordinary runner - Mdm Jenap Said! She ran twelve hours in her own Dusk till Dawn Challenge to raise funds for the Yellow Ribbon Fund. Just like running a marathon, the reintegration journeys of ex-offenders and our efforts to develop a community beyond second chances require commitment from all of us. What do YOU remember from 2012? BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore YRP20 YellowRibbonProject

From incarceration to community reintegration, Josiah's journey exemplifies the power of resilience and support. Despite being initially uncertain about his future, Josiah found a lifeline through the Midway Home programme with . Through small group gatherings and a newfound sense of discipline, Josiah rebuilt his life one step at a time. Riding on society's growing acceptance of ex-offenders and support towards second chances, he now dedicates himself to helping others, and is always ready to lend a listening ear and support where needed. Discover how Josiah turned his life around and continues to make a positive impact to others who were once like him. SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore BeyondSecondChances

Give someone a dish and feed them for a day. Teach them how to cook and feed them for a lifetime. With this philosophy in mind, YRSG partnered Workforce Singapore 10 years ago to set up The Hope Caf to provide skills training to inmates, so that these skills would aid them in their reintegration journey after their release. In partnership with Nanyang Polytechnic's Asian Culinary Institute (), inmates are given the opportunity to take the Workforce Skills Qualifications (WSQ) Higher Certificate in Food Services (Culinary Arts). This is part of YRSG's Skills and Career Masterplan 2.0, where inmates go through upskilling and skills deepening during their incarceration. Take a look inside The Hope Caf at Institution B4 to find out how the TAP (Train and Place) & Grow programme continues to pave the foundation for the next wave of culinary talent in the F&B industry. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSG thehopecafe tapandgrow

In partnership with Nanyang Polytechnic's Asian Culinary Institute (), inmates are given the opportunity to take the Workforce Skills Qualifications (WSQ) Higher Certificate in Food Services (Culinary Arts). This is part of YRSG's Skills and Career Masterplan 2.0, where inmates go through upskilling and skills deepening during their incarceration. Take a look inside The Hope Caf at Institution B4 to find out how the TAP (Train and Place) & Grow programme continues to pave the foundation for the next wave of culinary talent in the F&B industry. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSG thehopecafe tapandgrow

The Singapore Academy of Law's (SAL) annual charity futsal tournament, Chief Justice's (CJ) Cup, was back for another edition in 2024. More than 100 members of the legal community were joined by local football legends Fandi Ahmad and K Kannan to raise funds for the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) and the Singapore After-Care Association (SACA) They raised a record of $180,000 this year and have raised more than $710,000 since the first CJ's cup 11 years ago. This amount will support financially needy ex-offenders seeking vocational and skills training offered under the SAL-YRF Skills Training Assistance to Restart (STAR) Bursary and befriending services to the incarcerated and their families under SACA's Volunteer After-Care Programme.We would like to express our gratitude to the SAL and all the participants at the CJ's Cup for their dedication in supporting the education and rehabilitation of ex-offenders and their families, to offer second chances and hope to them. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore

A huge thank you to for joining us in creating the biggest patchwork blanket for entry into the SG Book Of Records! 185 UNIQLO employees worked together in groups to contribute to this meaningful cause. This activity showcased the value of strong partnerships, where we enriched peoples lives, especially when we work together with like-minded collaborators, said a Uniqlo representative.Each patchwork is created by various communities, as well as inmates and ex-offenders, as a pledge of their support for second chances.The final blanket will be a physical representation of the growing symbol of hope, resilience, and second chances for inmates and ex-offenders as they seek new beginnings.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore YRP20

Every May, we celebrate the achievements of our dedicated workforce, including ex-offenders who have rediscovered a path to reintegration through employment. Meet Sam Lim, Manager at 's Caf, where he has been working for more than a decade. Beyond the simple act of putting food on the table, his job has taught him how to embrace his role as a husband and father. With a greater sense of direction and fulfilment in his life, he has achieved greater peace and is looking to share that experience with fellow ex-offenders. Are you ready to offer them a second chance? SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore BeyondSecondChances

Celebrating 20 Years of Second ChancesOn 30 April 2024, we celebrated the Yellow Ribbon Projects journey of transformation and empowerment for inmates and ex-offenders. The 20th anniversary festivities were launched during the SPS-YRSG Corporate Advance 2024. Guest-of-Honour Mr K Shanmugam, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, highlighted YRPs milestones in our commitment to Unlocking the Second Prison.Themed Forward Corrections: Beyond Second Chances, details of upcoming YRP-theme events were unveiled to the attendees, comprising over 600 SPS and YRSG staff and their strategic partners.As part of YRP20, the first of three commemorative e-publications, themed Yellow Ribbon: Our Journey of Second Chances, was also launched. You can download your free copy of this e-publication here: go.gov.sg/yrpwebpub learn more about the Yellow Ribbon Project!Dont just wear a Yellow Ribbon, be one. Join us in celebrating YRP20, and let us continue to be each others second chances BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore YRP20 yellowribbonproject

In this episode of our YRP20 Through The Years series, we to another highlight that happened in 2009!On Singapore's 44th birthday, 88 inmates were presented with an opportunity to be part of the National Day celebrations. They volunteered to help pack the iconic National Day Funpacks and Yellow Ribbon Packs, allowing them to give back to the community, while still serving their sentences.Do you have one of the National Day Funpacks from 2009? Comment a below!BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore YRP20 YellowRibbonProject

Mistakes are an inevitable part of life.But how do we overcome our past mistakes and rebuild our lives? With unwavering support from her family, friends, and employer, Halijah found the strength to believe in herself again.By embracing self-forgiveness and experiencing unconditional support from her community, she now focuses on creating a brighter future and making positive changes in her life. Discover the steps that helped Halijah during her journey towards reintegration and self-forgiveness.YellowRibbonSingapore BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances SPS SingaporePrisonService OneHomeTeam

In this episode of our YRP20 Through The Years series, we return to 2009! The Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP) continued to raise awareness towards giving second chances and generate acceptance of ex-offenders and their families and inspire community action to support the rehabilitation and reintegration of ex-offenders back into society. On 6 September 2009, the YRP launched the first-ever Yellow Ribbon Prison Run which attracted more than 6,000 runners! Do you have any fond YRP memories of your own from 2009? Share it with us in the comments below.You can also pre-register for the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run 2024 happening on 1 September 2024 too! BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore YRP20

On 24 March 2024, the Department of Corrections of the Thailand Ministry of Justice organised their inaugural Yellow Ribbon Run Run For Relife! Graced by Police Colonel Thawee Sodsong, Minister of Justice, the event held at Nonthaburi Province was attended by more than 2,000 participants. Our SPS and YRSG staff participated in the event to show our support too! Run for Relife aims to raise public awareness of the need to give second chances to ex-offenders, generate acceptance for ex-offenders, and inspire community action to help ex-offenders reintegrate into society successfully. Funds raised from this event went toward a prisoner welfare fund that will support the prisoners rehabilitation and reintegration and their families. Join us in showing our encouragement and support for Yellow Ribbon Thailand! YellowRibbonProject WeAreEachOthersSecondChances SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Together with our community partner, .happiness , the Yellow Ribbon Project set up a booth at Our Tampines Hubs Hari Raya Celebrations for YOU to join us in weaving the largest patchwork blanket in Singapore. Aiming to be included in the SG Book of Records, were grateful to one and all who came over to contribute their stitches and weaves! Guest of Honour, Minister for Social and Family Development and Second Minister for Health, Mr Masagos Zulkifli also contributed to weaving the patchwork blanket! Together with our community partner, .happiness , the Yellow Ribbon Project set up a booth at Our Tampines Hubs Hari Raya Celebrations for YOU to join us in weaving the largest patchwork blanket in Singapore. Aiming to be included in the SG Book of Records, were grateful to one and all who came over to contribute their stitches and weaves! Guest of Honour, Minister for Social and Family Development and Second Minister for Health, Mr Masagos Zulkifli also contributed to weaving the patchwork blanket! A big thank you to everyone who came down and contributed your time and effort. Let us continue to support second chances and beyond as a community! BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore YRP20

Did You Know? This year's Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) Charity Golf and Dinner is into its 9th edition. Throughout the years, YRF has provided financial assistance for low-income ex-offenders who wish to pursue further education or acquire vocational skills after their release through various programmes, helping over 70,000 beneficiaries, including Mohammad Ridzwan Bin Abdol Latiff. As a recipient of the YRF STAR Bursary, he shares with us why events like these inspire him in his journey to restart his life. This event would not be possible without Dr Jimmy Koh and his group of avid golfers who volunteered to organise this event for YRF. He shared his inspiration for supporting YRF in its efforts to uplift the families of ex-offenders. We also met Wu Chenghui from Yellow Ribbon Fund. He shared that the proceeds from the event don't just fund YRF's programmes, but community-led ones too. YellowRibbonFund YellowRibbonSingapore SG4SecondChances

Our colleagues from the Yellow Ribbon Project and officers from the had the privilege of sharing about the Yellow Ribbon Project on 4 and 6 March 2024 at the , School of Accountancy. Desistors Mr Jabez Koh, Mr Zulkhairee Udik and Mr Safari Ahmad, who are Industrial & Services Co-operative Society Ltd (ISCOS) Titans, also inspired many through their sharing on their journeys of desistance. It was an enriching experience for all of us, and we are truly touched to feel the warmth and compassion of SMU's students and faculty. Thank you, SMU for inviting us to share our experiences! We warmly welcome more schools and students to join us in making a difference We Are Each Other's Second Chances! Reach us at Let's spread love and positivity! Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) raised $568,096 at this years Charity Golf and Dinner!Held at the Tanah Merah Country Club, the 9th edition of this event was also a celebration of YRFs 20th anniversary.Over the years, proceeds from charity functions have enabled YRF to help over 70,000 beneficiaries through the funding of various programmes, such as the YRF STAR Bursary. Guest of Honour, Minister of State for the Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development, Assoc Prof Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim, was present to speak with some of the beneficiaries and show his support for their rehabilitation efforts. As YRF continues to support inmates, ex-offenders and their families, let us all continue to do our part in contributing towards the various reintegration programmes that make this possible. YellowRibbonSingapore YellowRibbonFund sg4secondchances

Behind every challenge lies an opportunity for change. Matthew Poh, an ex-offender turned entrepreneur and owner of The Caffeine Experience , sheds light on the misconceptions surrounding addiction and incarceration. Find out how his personal experiences moulded his approach to mentorship and community building, along with the challenges he's overcome since. He also shares the one thing that makes him happiest - seeing his employees succeed in life. Show him some appreciation in the comments below! HappyMomentsMovement Resilience

The Catholic Welfare Services (CWS) and Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) signed a Memorandum of Understanding to provide more opportunities for low-income ex-offenders to enhance their employment and career prospects. With applications opening from April 2024, the CWS is committing $100,000 to The CWS Emmanuel Second Chance Education YRF Skills Training Assistance to Restart (CWS ESCE YRF STAR) Bursary. This partnership aims to provide eligible ex-offenders with financial support for vocational training and academic courses, including private GCE N-, O- and A-Levels, Nitec, Higher Nitec, Diploma, Degree, and Graduate Diploma courses.Providing more than a financial boost, the CWS ESCE YRF STAR Bursary goes beyond second chances, empowering ex-offenders to upgrade their vocational skills and enhance their long-term employment prospects. As the CWS and YRF strive toward a more inclusive and dynamic workforce, let us all continue to do our part in supporting ex-offenders in their reintegration journey. YellowRibbonSingapore YellowRibbonSG sg4secondchances

Throughout the years, with the support of our partners and the community, the Yellow Ribbon Project has launched various events and competitions to help inmates develop useful skills and gain new experiences. Reintegrating back into the community after spending time in prison is not easy. From career prospects to reconnecting with family, there are a lot of different challenges that ex-offenders may face. We talk to Faith Yu, a Senior Manager at the Yellow Ribbon Fund where she shares her one tip on what everyone can do to help ex-offenders in their journey to make the most of their second chance.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances YellowRibbonSingapore

Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) galvanises industry partners and employers to help inmates and ex-offenders find employment. We provide them with relevant skills training and assist with career placements and retention. In 2023:1. More than 4,000 inmates were trained, with an average of 80 training hours, providing them with skills aligned with Singapore's Skills Framework.2. 94% of inmates referred to YRSG secured a job prior to release.3. Over 6,500 employers support the hiring of ex-offenders.As we persevere with building a system of support for inmates and ex-offenders, we thank all partners and employers for being part of the journey in giving ex-offenders a second chance.
