What's in store at the Yellow Ribbon Race 2022 physical run/walk this Sunday, 25 September For those who have signed up for the physical run/walk, you are definitely in for a treat!We have fun activities lined up just for YOU - from immersive exhibitions and carnival games to attractive prizes to be won! Meet Alvin Tan, Assistant Director for Assurance at Yellow Ribbon Singapore! His day-to-day work entails enterprise risk management and further improving occupational health and safety standards. This helps achieve YRSG's objective of uplifting inmates and ex-offenders through skills and career development.Alvin recalls his most memorable experience from the past eight years and counting at YRSG, "In my previous role in Skills, I managed the set-up of the TAP & Grow Precision Engineering Programme facility and enabled the training for inmates, in collaboration with Nanyang Polytechnic. I worked closely with my Partnership colleagues and Singapore Prison Service officers to implement this initiative.It is heartening to play a part in creating more training opportunities and career pathways for inmates."Like Alvin, if you want to contribute to an inclusive society, a nation beyond second chances, join us for a fulfilling career at YRSG.Apply to our positions via the link in our bio today!SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Meet Shariff, a loyal participant who has never missed a chance to support the Yellow Ribbon Cause. Shariff was born without a left foot and at 40-years-old, he had to undergo amputation to remove his stump due to a skin infection. Shariff never lose hope, and picked himself up by starting to train as a runner. His motto: Set intention. Work for it. Learn from it. Never quit. Accept failures and challenges, and come back stronger. To date, he has completed 30 marathons, six ultra-marathons and other races, such as the annual Yellow Ribbon Prison Run (now rebranded to Yellow Ribbon Race) to show his support for inmates and ex-offenders who yearn for second chances. Apart from participating in the Virtual Race and Physical Run at the Changi Prison Complex on 25 September this year, Shariff will also participate in the first Gold Coast Marathon! Regardless of age, mobility or background, wed love to see everyone join the Yellow Ribbon Race 2022 this September and work towards creating a more inclusive society for not just ex-offenders, but everyone! Show your support for second chances and register for both the virtual and/or physical race! Click on link in bio. YRrace2022 SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Meet Nuristianah Amran, who has been working at YRSG for a decade and counting! Nuristianah supports ex-offenders by working with industry partners to develop engagement and employment assistance strategies that provide better career opportunities for those who want to work in the media industry.Nuristianah recalls her most memorable work experience fondly, saying this was what made her job fulfilling.At the 2021 Media Graduation Ceremony , 28 inmates graduated with Specialist Diplomas from a media training academy set up in collaboration with Singapore Media Academy. "The graduates' families witnessed the joyous occasion and it was heart-warming to see how proud their family members were and to witness YRSG's positive impact on these ex-offenders and their families." If you, like Nuristianah, believe in creating an inclusive society and want to help ex-offenders and their families lead a better life, you can embark on a fulfilling career with us. We are looking for someone to support the development and management of industry partnerships. Closing date is on 15 August 2022, click on link in bio to apply now! SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Thank you, TTJ Design and Engineering Pte Ltd (TTJDE) for the generous donation of $41,000 to help transform the lives of our beneficiaries and congratulations on your 41st anniversary!The donation will go towards developing and implementing rehabilitation and reintegration programmes for ex-offenders and their families. We have been supporting the Yellow Ribbon cause for many years, hiring ex-offenders since more than 20 years ago. It was natural for Yellow Ribbon Fund to be chosen as the recipient for the donation, shared Mr Teo Hock Chwee, Founder and Executive Chairman of TTJDE.Organisations can also contribute beyond monetary donations, such as volunteering for events and activities to raise awareness towards creating an inclusive society. Click the 'Volunteer' link in bio to find out more!SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

The Yellow Ribbon Fund's (YRF) signature Charity Gala Dinner is back! Happening on 3 February 2023 at the Ritz Carlton, the YRF Charity Gala Dinner raises funds to uplift the lives of over 3,000 ex-offenders and their families.YRF is devoted entirely to the development and implementation of rehabilitation and reintegration programmes for ex-offenders and their families. Show your support by purchasing tables to the Charity Gala Dinner or giving sponsorship in cash or in-kind. We look forward to creating a successful and meaningful event with you. For more info, kindly e-mail YRF staff secretariat at angela_swee.gov.sg.SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

On 18 July 2022, Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network held its annual Summit 2022, themed Igniting Connections, Empowering Lives, to raise awareness and appreciation of CARE Network and its efforts in strengthening throughcare support for inmates and ex-offenders. CARE Network is co-chaired by Commissioner of Prisons and Chairman of YRSG.CARE Network's stakeholders, corporate partners, social workers and ex-offenders were invited to hear the key developments of the CARE Network and participate in panel discussions to share more about their experiences. A networking session was also held for community partners and social enterprises to share about their work and create collaborative opportunities.Special thanks to Guest of Honour Josephine Teo .ylm Minister for Communications and Information and Second Minister for Home Affairs, for highlighting the need to look beyond the immediate post-release rehabilitation of former inmates through new approaches and capabilities.Mrs Teo also expressed her appreciation for the work done by members of the CARE Network, which comprises over 100 community partners and supporters across various social service agencies, halfway houses and religious groups. With an effective aftercare support network, we can work together to help rebuild the lives of inmates, ex-offenders and their families and lower the recidivism rate. CARENetworkSummit2022 IgnitingConnections EmpoweringLives CARENetwork SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

OH YES! The Yellow Ribbon Prison Run is back with a whole new twist! This year, its called the Yellow Ribbon Race and were hosting not two but THREE race categories Foot , Water , and Wheels ! Yep, this time round, you can walk, swim or even rollerblade to show your support for second chances! Participants of almost all profiles, including children can participate in this annual event. The Yellow Ribbon Race aims to bring together children, adults and families from all walks of life to share a fun day out and show collective community support for second chances for our ex-offenders and their families. Stay tuned for more info! YRRACE2022 SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

At Yellow Ribbon Singapore, we believe that the collective support of individuals, organisations and employers helps in the reintegration of ex-offenders into society. If you are a business owner or hiring manager who is keen to support the Yellow Ribbon cause, look no further! Equipping ex-offenders with practical work skills or offering them a job gives them a better chance to rebuild their lives. Beyond skills and careers, there are other ways in which you can support them. Read on to find out how you can make a difference! Thank you Studio Ardent () from Hwa Chong Institution (College Section) for designing this post!SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Zach (not his real name) is a participant in this years Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition (YRCC). We noticed that he had given a unique name to the dish he cooked: Charlies Angels! Charlies Angels was my first encounter with western food, first cooked by my brother who has since passed on. It was a pivotal moment for me as I believed it ignited my passion for cooking. In a way, my late brother has planted this passion for cooking in me, right until now. Thus, this dish is my tribute to him. When asked if he was confident of winning the competition, he shared that he would try his best, but emphasised that his main reason for joining the competition was to try something new and enjoy the process. Over the last few days, weve shared a peek into the minds of the inmates participating in this years YRCC 2022. Are you curious to know who will win? Stay tuned for the Final Cook-Off! YRCC2022 SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances YellowRibbonCulinaryCompetition ATasteofHome

On this International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking, meet Kelvin Quak, who spent almost a decade behind bars for drug abuse. He was released in 1986 and has remained drug-free for the past 36 years. In 2019, Kelvin received the Outstanding Achievement Award during the Yellow Ribbon Celebrating Second Chances Awards Ceremony. The award is the highest honour presented to outstanding ex-offenders who have remained crime and drug-free, and have contributed significantly to the community.Today, Kelvin is a loving husband and a doting father of two who whips up sumptuous meals for his family. According to his wife, Lay Hwa, Kelvin is the better cook and cooks great Cantonese dishes! For the past two decades, Kelvin has been actively volunteering, dedicating most of his time to guiding ex-offenders in Asia on their rehabilitation and reintegration journey. He also volunteers at the Prison Fellowship Singapore (PFS) and , where he counsels former drug addicts and helps them stay on the right path. Click on the images to learn more about Kelvins advice! DrugFreeSG SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Meet Gaya (not her real name), who is a participant in the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition (YRCC) this year! Heres the inside scoop behind her modern rendition of her familys traditional recipe, founded by her late mother, whom Gaya used to run a stall with. My mother always said that Masala Chicken is a dish that is ordinary. One day, she decided to incorporate yoghurt to enhance the flavour. From that day onwards, we started receiving compliments from our customers. My mother was not expecting such a positive response as she only wanted to experiment with the dish. From then on, the Chicken Masala Yoghurt became a family recipe. Gaya decided to cook the Chicken Masala Yoghurt, in memory of her late mother. I miss my late mother a lot she is the main reason why I decided to cook this dish for the competition. YRCC2022 SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances YellowRibbonCulinaryCompetition ATasteofHome

David (not his real name), who sharpened his culinary skills while working in a prison kitchen, is one of the participants in the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition (YRCC)! Hear what he has to say about Singapores food culture and the dish that he has selected to cook in the competition. When I was young, I used to assist my mother in running a hawker stall. We would sell all sorts of Malay cuisines, such as Mee Soto and Mee Rebus. I interpreted the theme of this years competition, A Taste of Home as food that is uniquely Singapore. Singapore is a multi-racial country with an array of food options to choose from. Hence, I have chosen to cook Nasi Briyani as it can be enjoyed by all races and is a great dish for sharing on any occasion. David is the first of three inmate features for this years YRCC. Keep a look out on this space for our next feature! YRCC2022 SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances YellowRibbonCulinaryCompetition ATasteofHome

The Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) and (SPS) SPS-YRSG Corporate Advance 2022 was held today.During his opening speech, Guest-of-Honour Associate Prof Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim (), Minister of State, Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of National Development praised the collaborative efforts of SPS, YRSG and community partners for supporting ex-offenders in their rehabilitation and reintegration after their release. "Our next target is to bring down the five-year recidivism rate. We need the communitys even stronger support, to join us to co-create and transform rehabilitation and reintegration... Alone, the work may be daunting, but together, we can do so much more," shared MOS Faishal.MOS Faishal also launched theFriends of YRSG Telegram Channel(click link in bio)! Join the channel for the latest news, updates, and learn how you can play a part and contribute to the YR cause.SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances FriendsOfYRSG

For Lisa, YRSG is like her family. They celebrate happiness together and support one another when help is needed during challenging times. This is why she has chosen to stay in YRSG for over eight years!As a Human Resource professional at People, Lisa strives to develop staff to meet their best potential, so that they can achieve YRSGs mission, as well as their personal work goals. Lisa also ensures that staff welfare and mental well-being are well taken care of.YRSG is the lead agency in championing forgiveness, hope, acceptance and second chances for ex-offenders, and we strive towards building a safer and more inclusive Singapore. I am proud to work here as our staff work hard, believe in our mission and most importantly, walk the talk.Looking for a fulfilling career? Visit for careers opportunities at YRSG. Together, we can spark a positive chain reaction to inspire An Inclusive Society, a Nation Beyond Second Chances. SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Support and understanding from the community are crucial to the successful rehabilitation and reintegration of ex-offenders. Even after their release from prison, the stigma that follows our ex-offenders subject them to invisible walls of prejudice and discrimination.By breaking these stigmas, we can help and support ex-offenders to be reintegrated into society and become responsible citizens.StopStereotyping BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances ShortStoriesofSecondChances

The inaugural YR Connects 2022 was a gathering of industry leaders, trade associations and employers, who met and shared their insights into supporting second chances. During our conversation with 's Human Capital & Development Manager, Mr Kelvin Ho, we learnt about its ongoing initiatives to support inmates and ex-offenders in their career development and employment prospects. The Pan Pacific Hotels Group has been a strong advocate of inclusive employment from across diverse backgrounds and communities, and these efforts have created a more compassionate working environment for our workforce. Im glad that at our hotel, this compassion has extended to supporting ex-offenders in their reintegration into society. With an avid commitment to providing employment and skills training to ex-offenders, Mr Ho shares with us, For ex-offenders, we should continue to be their advocates by sharing success stories of rehabilitation, career progression and their assimilation back to society. As a business, we must also continue to extend support to them and listen to them, just as we would for any other associate on our team. This helps us to understand their situation, needs and in managing expectations. We will then be able to support the ex-offenders in their reintegration journey and help them to achieve their goals.YRConnects SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances
We wish everyone a Happy Labour Day! CaptainsOfLives BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

The Yellow Ribbon Fund is grateful to the 156 golfers and many other generous sponsors who pledged their support towards the Charity Golf event, which was held at the Tanah Merah Country Club, Garden Course on 23 March 2022. The proceeds from this event will be channelled to fund rehabilitation and reintegration programmes and services for inmates, ex-offenders and their families. One example is the Yellow Ribbon Emergency Fund, which provides financial assistance to newly released inmates who could be struggling to afford basic needs, or families and children who are impacted by the incarceration of their loved ones. Special thanks to Asia Pacific Breweries (Singapore) Pte Ltd, Ben and Jerrys, and Khong Guan for sponsoring refreshments for this event. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Zul (pseudonym) is the epitome of persevering and working hard for second chances. Having been incarcerated for two decades, Zul aspired to be a better father to his son, and a productive member of society. He started producing curry puffs from his home kitchen, and recently his handmade curry puffs have made the news! ? In 2008, I was interested in curry puffs after trying some really tasty ones at the hawker centre. I thought that there was room for improvement, so I experimented with the fillings and the pastry. It took me many attempts before I was confident enough to share them with my friends and family. I also distributed them to patrons at the hawker centre to gather feedback on my curry puffs. Many of them were very shocked when they bit into the huge fillings of my curry puffs! This gave me the confidence to start selling them. . ? I hope that he will grow up to be bright and successful. I am very supportive of his future goals, and I have always encouraged him to achieve his dreams. ? The team has been very supportive since my son enrolled in their befriending programme. (It is) not just the volunteers, but the case workers and therapists have always supported and guided me for the past three years. I have never felt alone ever since being part of their programme.YRStories BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

, . - Mary Anne Radmacher In March 2022, students of Class 4N1A at Serangoon Secondary School took the initiative to kickstart their Values in Action (VIA) project with the Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP), to raise awareness of and give support to ex-offenders and their families. The students and their form teachers personally delivered care packages to 10 families under the Yellow Brick Road (YBR) programme. Luther Tan from 4N1A shared, "This VIA Project taught me to empathise with others and to show care for people I do not know.", while his classmate Nur Elyza shared, "I learnt the importance of caring for the community and helping people in need." We appreciate the unsung heroes of Class 4N1A, the students and form teachers Ms Caelyn Lim and Ms Moritza Lim for their spirit of volunteerism and support for second chances!BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

As the world steadies itself from COVID-19, it is essential that we work together to support vulnerable groups in our society. With the support of trade associations, employers, and government agencies, we can work together for the rehabilitation and reintegration of ex-offenders. At the recent YR Connects event, Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) had the opportunity to connect with industry players, trade associations and employers. Singapore Logistics Associations (SLA) CEO, Mr Oh Bee Lock shares on the ongoing initiatives that support inmates and ex-offenders in their career development and employment opportunities. Such events are important as it helps us connect and learn about facilitating the reintegration of ex-offenders to better support and give them second chances. We hope inmates and ex-offenders who are actively looking for employment will be equipped with industry-relevant knowledge and skills, and at the same time enable employers to engage and better understand the needs of these job seekers, said Mr Oh, who believes that education and skills training are essential for the rehabilitation and reintegration of ex-offenders.The Logistics Academy, a wholly owned subsidiary of SLA that was set up in 2010, is committed to providing quality training and lifelong learning for the logistics workforce. Our trainers are drawn from well-qualified industry practitioners with hands-on experience in various logistics roles. YRConnects SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

As a crochet and knitting enthusiast, Yen Ee attributes her inspiration to volunteer to her faith. Her volunteering journey began in 2021, when she was inspired to do more for second chances after a surreal vision of a divine guide showed her a sign of unravelling yarn. This sparked her desire to help inmates and ex-offenders. At 22, Yen Ee and her team from are dedicated to her volunteer work with Yellow Ribbon Project that spans from teaching other volunteers how to crochet, as well as guiding over 50 inmates and ex-offenders to learn the craft. She also pioneered the Yellow Ribbon crochet pattern, which can be viewed here: "It is good to know that I taught someone a skill, so that they might feel proud of themselves for creating something out of nothing,", Yen Ee shared, hoping to provide support to help inmates cope. There are a lot of people out there who need help and this project helps to open that door to giving them an outlet to cope and perhaps even use this craft to start their own ventures in the future, and I would appeal to the youth to use their unique talents and crafts to volunteer as well, as having volunteers ready to help is a huge step in rehabilitation and reintegration for many. SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

[Spotlight & Support PART 1/3] Welcome to the Spotlight & Support, where we feature businesses that either support or are operated by ex-offenders! If you are craving some good food and coffee, look no further! The Caffeine Experience () is a social enterprise cafe run 100% by ex-offenders that serves specialty coffees roasted in-house. Being an ex-offender, it wasn't easy for Matthew Poh to start this business. However, with resilience, hard work, and the help of his team, his caf has flourished! If you would like to support The Caffeine Experience, head down to their caf to enjoy their scrumptious food! Stay tuned for future Spotlight & Support posts, and be sure to support these businesses for a good cause! Thank you to Studio Ardent () for supporting second chances!

Plato once said, Music gives a soul to the universe, and this is evident when were talking to Ridwan Bin Juhari, a talented musician from XC Band. Incarcerated for drug-related offences, Ridwans enthusiasm for music never waned. I started playing the guitar in primary school. However, I picked up playing the keyboard five years ago, while in the prison. It was during my incarceration that I managed to attain the Basic Music Class Grade 5 as well. The Ritchie Blackmore and Yngwie Malmsteen fan shares that his passion for music has motivated him to stay clean, and with his loved ones support for his musical inclinations, he has been able to free his mind from stress. At the end of the day, second chances are important for recovery and reintegration, and an opportunity to showcase our talents can go a long way in motivating former offenders like us to stay on the right path! YRtalents SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

. , . Being employed and having a strong support system at work is crucial for an ex-offenders reintegration journey. This was the reintegration experience for Grace, a Customer Service Team Leader at XDel Singapore Pte Ltd. I was imprisoned for drug offences for almost six years and because of that, I could not take care of my family. While serving my sentence, I reflected and decided to turn over a new leaf, so I resumed my education while in prison. I was eventually selected for the Community-based Programme and placed in a halfway house. Worried about her past affecting her career options, Grace was ecstatic to find XDel Singapore assessing her purely based on her own merits. They made me feel very comfortable and offered me the opportunity to work for them. Today, Grace credits XDel for turning her life around. For Grace, employment support went a long way in stabilising and anchoring her reintegration journey. Thank you XDel for believing in second chances, and giving Grace self-confidence, a sense of purpose and the opportunity to successfully reintegrate into society. SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

The smell of delectable fudgy brownies and rich vanilla custard puffs lingers in Sabrina Chong Abdullahs home, where she started her home-based business in 2017, after spending more than a decade in prison.As a mother of six and an ex-offender, it was not easy for Sabrina to rebuild her life after her incarceration. With support from other strong women in her family her own mother and sister, Sabrina found the strength to press on, and was encouraged to start a home bakery. In 2017, I took some baking courses while battling a very low point in my life. I shared my bakes with my counsellors, as well as my daughters teachers at school, who encouraged me to start my own venture. With the support of Industrial & Services Co-operative Society Ltd (ISCOS) and Family Care Services, Ive been able to manage my business and be independent in life. When asked of what a strong and resilient woman means to Sabrina, she smiles and shares, all women are born strong, and have the ability to overcome any adversity., , !BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances InternationalWomensDay

- With Valentines Day approaching, giving flowers to your loved ones is often seen as an expression of love. , a florist offering exceptionally crafted floral creations, is an active advocate for second chances, believing that gainful employment is an important aspect of being successful in society as an ex-offender. Jeremi, who recently joined Beato Fiore, shared that during his incarceration for drug offences, he chose to focus on his rehabilitation by studying. After his release, Jeremi, having managed to secure gainful employment, continues to stay on the right side of the law(n), with support from his beloved mother. Having partnered with Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) since 2019, Beato Fiore offers employment to ex-offenders regularly. We personally conduct interviews at Changi Prison Complex and once we have a profile, the YRSG team assists on the necessary paperwork which really eases the process of hiring, shared Pauline Lee, Director of Beato Fiore. SG4SecondChances HappyValentinesDay

Teaching us a valuable lesson of giving back in the , and personally embodying the qualities of bravery and strength is Terence Tan.Terence spent years behind bars but came out with a strong resolve to help others who are having a hard time in their reintegration journey. Recalling his first reunion dinner many years ago, Terence shares that it was a grand affair, with everyone joining in and welcoming him back home.These days, many ex-offenders dont have that family love and support. So, I get them to join me for reunion dinner with their spouses, and we have a mini reunion of sorts...A strong support system, in terms of family, peers or even counsellors goes a long way for ex-offenders. There were some roadblocks in my reintegration journey. However, I was fortunate to have good counsellors and support from Industrial & Services Co-operative Society Ltd (ISCOS) to keep me motivated to stay on the right path. This encouraged me to give back to society and do my part for others too. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Committed to supporting second chances, SeaCabbie, part of the Maritime & Port Authority of Singapore , started to employ ex-offenders since 2021. Ms Mary Rose, Business Development Manager at SeaCabbie, shares on their partnership with Yellow Ribbon Singapore.We started in early 2021. Although we were initially hesitant to hire ex-offenders, we realised that it gives opportunities for them to grow. We started with hiring two people who had their own career coaches to guide them. Now they are well-adjusted, and are very good at what they do.One of their recent recruits is Muhd Yusof - an aspiring Captain who is on his way to a Steersman license. It has helped a lot. Due to the pandemic, employment can be difficult to find, and even more so with a criminal record. But I'm grateful for the support and confidence that SeaCabbie has given me.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

. . The inaugural Yellow Ribbon Awards 2021, jointly organised by the (SPS) and Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG), is themed We Are Each Others Second Chances. The event celebrates the communitys success in shaping a more inclusive society, recognising 577 award recipients for their achievements and commitment to second chances. The man himself - Bruce Mathieu shared his struggles in fighting his drug addictions for three decades, and coming out of it as a new man.I had a lonely and confusing childhood. I began with marijuana at the age of 13, and this led me to heroin addiction at the age of 15. Being dependent on these drugs, I also ended up in the company of gangs and I was arrested for the first time at the age of 22.For the well-known Triad Trails, Bruce, a charismatic tour leader, shared the historical secrets that Singapores Central Business District conceals. It gives ex-offenders like me, an opportunity to have conversations that otherwise would not be possible, as it gives our tourists the liberty to ask us about our past without hesitation.As an advocate for youths-at-risk, Bruce dedicates his time to give talks at schools, and train to be a street journalist. He also spends quality time with his family. He highlighted that people are sometimes judgmental and slow to trust those with criminal pasts. Thus, he wants to help ex-offenders have a good support system when they are released to reduce their chances of re-offending.A believer in faith, he shared that change often comes from within. Many ex-offenders and their families approach me for help and support after their release from prisons, and I truly feel that unless there is an innate desire for change within a person, its difficult to bring about a large-scale change to society. But I would like to tell our society and community to take a chance on us, as those of us who are serious about changing our lives are some of the most hardworking and sincere people you will meet.SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

As a teenager, Bruce Mathieu struggled with drug addictions and eventually spent almost over 30 years behind bars. So how did a former troubled teen with multiple run-ins with the law become an advocate for anti-drug movements, especially for youths-at-risk, and also a passionate volunteer who dedicates his time to support other ex-offenders in their reintegration journey? Tune in to find out more. SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

, In the beginning, I created art because it helped me to relax and also challenged me to think about the different ways I can express my feelings. As time passed, I realised that art has totally changed my perspective in life. The process of creating art has helped me to recognise my character flaws and has allowed me to focus on my strengths over my weaknesses. There is no shortcut in life. Now I practise art to make full use of my clear mind.Titled Breaking Dawn, Hameed envisions dawn as the moment he first saw hope; and that it is such hope that shapes his future.Follow us for more details on the Yellow Ribbon Community Art and Poetry Exhibition 2021, a virtual exhibition featuring artworks by existing and former inmate artists, launching on 30 November at SG4SecondChances YRCAPE2021 SaveTheDate

The inspiration behind my artwork and poetry is the love and longing for my family. I have always wanted a complete family, but I have lost touch for a few years due to my incarceration. I hope to be able to spend enough time with my father who isn't keeping well. I will always be grateful for his love and support. To my Mom, she is always an inspiration to me and Im thankful for her.Syaherahs All About You is an artwork dedicated to the artists father, who is ill. Despite the physical separation, the artist expresses the bond that continues to connect them sending her father strength through the lines she expressively painted, wishing for new hope despite her circumstances.Follow us for more details on the Yellow Ribbon Community Art and Poetry Exhibition 2021, a virtual exhibition featuring artworks by existing and former inmate artists, launching on 30 November at SG4SecondChances YRCAPE2021 SaveTheDate

Before I started doing art, I seldom managed to control my emotions. I would always get frustrated easily and at times get caught up in feeling useless. After learning that there are Art Programmes in prisons, I decided to get myself involved as I have been interested in the subject since young. Ever since I started, I have learned how to be more patient and not give up easily. I am more confident in controlling my emotions too.This beautiful piece by Ian, Edge of Time - perfectly encapsulates the possibilities of lifes journey. The artist muses that for us to accomplish great things, we must not only dream and believe, but also plan and act. This painting of an old man sitting beneath a tree and reminiscing his past is representative of the artists determination to change and better his own life, to put himself into action and end his own journey on better terms.Follow us for more details on the Yellow Ribbon Community Art and Poetry Exhibition 2021, a virtual exhibition featuring artworks by existing and former inmate artists, launching on 30 November at SG4SecondChances YRCAPE2021 SaveTheDate

Ever thought of what you could be doing at 74? A conversation with Mr Christopher Yeow, the oldest participant for this years Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run (YRVR), is a refreshing reminder that age is truly just a number. I have been a Toastmasters Prison Volunteer for over 15 years and often take the opportunity to support the Yellow Ribbon activities whenever I can." Keeping healthy became a priority for Mr Yeow, an adjunct lecturer at Nanyang Polytechnic, after he discovered that physiotherapy and regular exercise help him with knee pain five years ago. In his mission to stay active, he persevered and has been an ardent supporter of the Yellow Ribbon cause. During this COVID-19 period, the YRVR allowed me to enjoy the outdoors, walking around the neighbourhood and beyond to discover new sights and surprising things that I was not aware of before. He also shared that some of his favourite walking spots are around Bedok Park Connector, where he takes in the sights of nature, as well as creative murals and art pieces along the way. Mr Yeow hopes to encourage others to be involved in rehabilitation efforts. In doing so, we will develop empathy for inmates and ex-offenders, and at the same time, help them unlock their second prisons. YRVR2021 YRInspire2021 ChallengeYRself SG4SecondChances

Sometimes, a little kindness can go a long way in changing someones life! Thank you Richard for your dedicated service over the course of two decades and still counting. Read on about Richard's journey on the Yellow Ribbon Singapore Facebook page now! WorldKindnessDay

A family which runs together, stays together. Meet Eric and Mark Huber, a father-son duo who continue to support second chances across the years, and most recently, in this years Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run (YRVR) 2021. Erics passion for supporting ex-offenders in their rehabilitation and reintegration goes back to 1968, when he, then 17-year-old, played guitar at Changi Prison for Prison Chapel Services. Over the years, he opted to become a prison counsellor and has continued his legacy of helping inmates for the past 54 years. .The first time my dad invited me to join him in the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run was 5 years ago, for a 10km run. The finishing point was at the prison compound itself. It was astonishing and admirable. I felt a deep connection because of my Dad. I understood the meaning of the years of his dedication to the cause and that somehow sparked my interest in the Yellow Ribbon cause too. .Running with dad is like running with a man with a legacy in volunteer work who does not quit. That, I feel, is my fondest memory for this years run. During our runs, he would share wonderful stories with me of many inmates who have mended their ways and done well for themselves after their incarceration. YRVR2021 YRInspire2021 ChallengeYRself SG4SecondChances

Helping others to help themselves is a philosophy that Andrew Ong embodies into his daily life. As an ex-offender himself, Andrew is determined to help others like him turn their lives around and contribute positively to society. Andrew co-founded Break The Cycle SG, an initiative that uses cycling as a means to help ex-offenders break their pattern of reoffending. Join him on 23 October 2021 at 10.30am for a webinar to learn more about this initiative! Register at With over 15 years of experience in marketing, communications, and business development, Andrew seamlessly combines his corporate experience with his mission to advocate for the needs of ex-offenders as the Assistant Director of Partnerships with HCSA Community Services. In recognition of his contributions to society and his own personal transformation in life, Andrew was awarded at the 2020 Singapore Silent Hero Award under the Outstanding Adult category. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Usually, all it takes is a friend to push you in the right direction, and this includes support for second chances! Bryan Ho, 35, tells us how he discovered the joy of contributing to a positive cause by running for the Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run 2021 under the YRChallenge category. For YRChallenge, he clocked 60km in five runs! ?My friend introduced me to it and I thought Id give it a shot, especially since its for an excellent cause. Ive always supported the Yellow Ribbon cause, and I thought Id give this fundraiser a shot, since I think this needs more exposure, especially in the local community. .No matter where we are in life, there may always be situations where we need a second or even a third chance. We are always given that opportunity to do better. For ex-offenders who are willing to make a change in their lives, lets be gracious and extend our hands to help them and welcome them back into society. After his first run, Bryan desires to continue participating in future Yellow Ribbon Prison Runs to show his support for ex-offenders. Thank you for your support in unlocking doors of opportunity for ex-offenders in our community! YRVR2021 YRInspire2021 ChallengeYRself SG4SecondChances
As we head into the weekend, a reminder that acceptance can be life-changing and sometimes, second chances can mean the world to the lives of others.SG4SecondChances JustaReminder

Second chances can come in many forms, especially when children are the reason behind wanting to make a positive change in life. For Mdm Safia (pseudonym), her son Rahim (pseudonym) has been her greatest motivation for her to do better. For her, Rahim is her second chance at life.Rahim has been a beneficiary under the (NLS) befriending programme since 2018. He befriended five .official students, who became his Learning Friends. They inspired and encouraged Rahim to study very hard, and he even received a bursary for his outstanding performance in school recently. Rahims zest for life and his positive attitude towards his education inspires Mdm Safia greatly, pushing her to do better for herself. Putting her past behind her, she is now a devoted wife and mother, and enjoys spending her weekends bringing her family on excursions around Singapore.This Childrens Day, I'm grateful that many in the community want to help my children and I. Im also grateful to the HCI boys, who came and helped a family like ours. Even though they knew of our situation, that I am an ex-offender, they still accept my children without any prejudice. They accepted him as one of their own. HappyChildrensDay BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Education is a lifelong endeavour, and the 28 inmates who graduated yesterday after completing a series of media courses for Specialist Diplomas know this very well. In the cohort, 15 inmates graduated with a Specialist Diploma in Social Media Marketing and Online Content Creation (SMMOCC) programme, while 13 inmates graduated with a Diploma in Media (Content Production and Management) Assistant Director (DMAD). Their graduation ceremony, which was held virtually, was attended by several media representatives and potential employers.Id like to take this opportunity to thank YRSG for their support and effort in helping inmates and ex-offenders achieve their goals. Their motto has always been second chances and I am one of the many examples of second chances that YRSG has helped so that everyone like myself can have a brighter future, shares Adam (pseudonym), an inmate who graduated from the programme.A collaboration between YRSG and made this programme a success. The partnership resulted in the establishment of a media training academy inside prison to enhance the skills and career prospects of inmates and ex-offenders in the media industry. The four-month SMMOCC diploma programme and 10-month DMAD programme started in November 2020, with lessons taking place twice a week. Through three cohorts per year, YRSG expects to train about 60 inmates.Employment is the cornerstone to successful reintegration. When ex-offenders are gainfully employed, it gives them a sense of personal fulfilment to be able to contribute to their families well-being. I am grateful that employers continue to hire ex-offenders and extend second chances to them during this difficult period. said Mr Matthew Wee Yik Keong, Chief Executive Officer, YRSG.Congratulations to all the graduates, and a special thanks to the staff for facilitating the conduct of the programme, which allows for more doors on second chances to be opened for the inmates.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances
What matters is not the weight in our pockets, but the value of our hearts and our support for second chances. HelenIvan SG4SecondChances

On a YR MissionPastor Simon Neo - Founder of Breakthrough Missions Halfway House and Mr Freddy Wee, its Deputy Director, have made it their mission to seek out those who are still in the shackles of drug addiction and help in their rehabilitation. With their own experiences and history as former drug-users, they hope to reach out and inspire others to brave the journey of transformation. They will always carry the stigma of being ex-offenders. We need to help them drop the label by accepting them in our midst and help them along the way. You may be their employer, a family member or a friend, our role is to support them, communicate with them on their needs and most importantly, be a listening ear. Ultimately, it is your love and support that will guide them through the process of healing. - Pastor Simon highlights how society can destigmatise ex-offenders and give them the support they need to reintegrate into society and contribute positively. Speaking from years of experience, Mr Freddy also shared on how society can empower ex-offenders and aid them in rebuilding their lives. "Every person is important regardless of their past. A second chance is all they need. Lets spare a thought for the ex-offenders and their families, include them as part of our community, and build a society with equal opportunity. Do your part, lets support second chances by registering for the Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run today: YRInspire2021 ChallengeYRself SG4SecondChances

Blessings come in many forms, and this is the theme that embodies the grace of the Origami Crane Trees at the Gardens by the Bay Mid-Autumn Festival 2021. Featuring paper cranes folded by inmates through the Yellow Ribbon Project, the entire installation presents 2,000 colourfully folded paper cranes, with words of blessings from the community.To me, blessings mean a clear state of mind and feeling peaceful. I will be more positive and count on my blessings every day and be more grateful with whatever is given to me. I feel really honoured to be participating in this initiative because it gives me a chance to be part of something beyond these four walls. To contribute to something, so beautiful, to me, is a blessing, shared an inmate involved in this project.Check out the installation at the Gardens by the Bay Mid-Autumn Festival 2021, open now until 3 October!BehindPrisonWalls BeyondPrisonWalls BeyondSecondChances

A desire to help the underprivileged or those who are in difficult situations is exactly what motivated Ms Rachael to join Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG).Ms Rachaels scope of work includes conducting career assessments to guide inmates to discover their career interests and guide them towards preparing themselves to apply for jobs. Within this process, she engages with inmates on a one-to-one basis regularly, and coordinates job interviews with potential employers to help inmates secure suitable employment before their release. ?The successful implementation of virtual job interviews in prisons. When COVID-19 hit Singapore and we entered the Circuit Breaker, ex-offenders released during that time were unable to receive employment assistance before their release. The team worked hard to introduce technology into our work processes and enabled employers to resume interviews with ex-offenders virtually. This allowed our work to continue, while keeping everyone safe. ?Building rapport with the inmates and ex-offenders and listening to them. Some of them can be quite inspiring and cause us to reflect on our life choices. At the end of the day, its a fulfilling job. Everyday might bring new challenges to my job, but when I hear that they are successful in staying out of prison, its a joy for sure. --------- If you are looking for a fulfilling career and have the heart to help others change for the better, do visit to join us. Together, we can support the Yellow Ribbon cause and inspire collective action for An Inclusive Society, a Nation Beyond Second Chances. SG4SecondChances

! Registration for the Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run has been ! What are you waiting for? Join us and show your support for second chances today!Challenge YRself, Inspire Second Chances: Link in bio!YRVR2021 ChallengeYRself YRInspire2021 SG4SecondChances

Grab a paper and take notes! Steven Loo has completed the YRChallenge race category in this years Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run (YRVR) 2021! Outside of YRVR, the 50-year-old is an avid runner and clocks in approximately 60km to 80km weekly!As a first time Yellow Ribbon runner, Steven expressed that the challenge is daunting, yet its an interesting way to explore his neighbourhood. Route planning has to be done in advance due to the number of traffic lights, road junctions and exhaust fumes in the neighbourhood, Steven recommended. He shared that his decision to participate in this year's YRVR was to support the marginalised community in Singapore, while also encouraging the community to do their part for second chances.Joining Steven is Syahrin Mohd Salleh, who has also completed the YRChallenge! Syahrin is an Ustaz and Manager at FITRAH (Family and Inmates Throughcare Assistance Haven).Syahrin has participated in the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run since 2018 and is no stranger to the cause. I was very touched by the humanity to help those who had strayed into the wrong side of the law, Dr Jimmy Koh tells us how he got involved with the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) in 2005. As the Managing Director of Antara Koh Pte Ltd, Dr Koh has been involved in some instrumental moments in Singapores history, including the relocation of the Merlion to the promontory in front of The Fullerton Hotel. As a YRF partner, Dr Koh has contributed in many YRF initiatives that have been rolled out to provide rehabilitation and reintegration services to ex-offenders and their families, such as the YRF STAR Bursary, which assists low-income ex-offenders in pursuing further education after release. What I realise is that every jail sentence meted out to punish the wrongdoing of a person must serve a social purpose. The society must be compassionate and help to rehabilitate those who were jailed to return to the society and to be good citizens. The society must help to mitigate the suffering of innocent members of the family, especially the children. We must help to support their daily needs, provide them the education and training to help them to reintegrate into society. Dr Koh hopes that with his efforts, as well as every individuals support, society can facilitate the rehabilitation of ex-offenders and support their families through difficult times. Do your part, and support second chances by registering for the Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run now - link in bio! YRVR2021 YRInspire2021 ChallengeYRself SG4SecondChances

Terence expresses his enthusiasm for participating in this year's Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run, as the team developed a 5km to 7km Strava App art route in the shape of a yellow ribbon.It's a great initiative that allows us to show our support and to allow ex-offenders to be given a chance to reintegrate into society. We hope to help raise awareness of the cause, and through our support, raise funds to aid the Yellow Ribbon Project in their rehabilitation efforts and care-giving programmes, said Terence. Join us to support second chances - link in bio!YRVR2021 YRInspire2021 ChallengeYRself SG4SecondChances

I can only imagine that in solitude and separation from family, they had plenty to think about. In that time, their resolve to become a better version of themselves increases with every passing day. All they ask is for a second chance. Ex-offenders are no different from you and me, all striving to build a better tomorrow. Look beyond the past, treasure the present, create a bright future. Lucas Lam, Singapore Media AcademyAs a first-time participant for this years inaugural Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run, Singapore Media Academys (SMA) Lucas Lam hopes that this event will raise awareness to the cause of the Yellow Ribbon Project, and encourage employers to hire ex-offenders. Mr Lam describes how SMAs diploma enriches the lives of inmates and provides them with the right tools that aid their reintegration process after release. He shared, We partnered YRSG to kick off the inaugural batches for two diploma programmes to selected inmates in November 2020. The main objectives of both programmes is to arm the inmates with industry relevant skills with hands-on training to be able to join the workforce.Join us and support second chances - link in bio!YRVR2021 YRInspire2021 ChallengeYRself SG4SecondChances

Para-athlete Shariff Abdullah ( ), more popularly known as Blade Runner, has been running for second chances for over a decade. He took part in his first ever Yellow Ribbon Prison Run in 2010, after reading about the cause. Perseverance despite challenging circumstances are qualities Shariff embodies in his personal life. He shares that whenever he is down, he watches YouTube videos of runners and encourages himself. He draws the same philosophy when it comes to encouraging inmates and ex-offenders to do better. They need someone to push them and support them to stay on the right track. We as a community can do just that!Since 2010, the running enthusiast has never looked back. Shariff runs every year to rally societal support for ex-offenders. In 2014, I ran with a 8kg weighted bag to represent the burdens some ex-offenders face when they are released, shared the ardent runner.This year, Shariff is back for the Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run 2021, running 60km to raise support for the cause. Join him during his live run on 5 September at 8am as he runs for second chances!This year I dedicate my run to inmates and ex-offenders, as well as the staff who do their best to support inmates and ex-offenders!YRVR2021 YRInspire2021 ChallengeYRself SG4SecondChances

For more than a decade, every September, weve gathered as a community at the starting line to begin our run for second chances. These second chances are for ex-offenders who have completed their sentences and left prison, only to find themselves stepping into a second prison; one with invisible bars of suspicion, mistrust and discrimination. This year, for the very first time, and due to unprecedented challenges of battling COVID-19, we have opted for a virtual run! We may not congregate at the starting line together, but we can run for the same cause, with the same passion, in the hope for a more accepting and inclusive society.The inaugural Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run 2021 offers an opportunity for the public to run, walk or hike at their preferred locations, at their own time, throughout the month of September.Kick start your run, walk or hike on 1 September in the shape of a yellow ribbon and send in your photos by tagging YRInspire2021 on social media! Register today - link in bio!

This morning, Yellow Ribbon Singapore and Singapore Logistics Association (SLA) signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) that enhances the career prospects of inmates' and ex-offenders' in the logistics industry. Under the MOU, training would be conducted in Changi Prison Complex for inmates who are keen to embark in a career in the logistics industry. The Logistics Academy, a wholly-owned subsidiary of SLA, has curated a curriculum Certificate in Logistics Operations for the inmates. The course covers fundamentals of job functions in the logistics industry, such as warehouse management and operations, and transport management and operations, to meet real market needs. The course is expected to commence in November 2021 and more than 500 inmates will benefit from this training programme annually.This collaboration improves inmates career prospects in the logistics industry upon their release and supports their reintegration into society.SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Committed to helping inmates and ex-offenders, Nelson decided to joined Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) to enrich our programmes with his own insights as an ex-offender. Now eight years on, he shares the highlights of his role as a Senior Skills Associate. .As a Senior Skills Associate, I assist ex-offenders with skills training in the community after their release. We conduct briefings, and also coach them to deepen their skills, which improves their chances of employment. The type of training we run is accredited by Singapore to ensure that they are equipped with industry relevant skills, such as Culinary Arts, Generic Manufacturing and Design Thinking. ?The pleasant moment when I bump into ex-offenders outside, and they would thank me for supporting them. Im happy to see many of them still doing well and going strong after their release, knowing that the training they went through had a life-changing impact on their reintegration journey. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------If you are looking for a fulfilling career and have the heart to help others change for the better, do visit to join us. Together we can support the Yellow Ribbon cause and inspire collective action for An Inclusive Society, a Nation Beyond Second Chances.SG4SecondChances

The YRSG Board of Directors play a key role in ex-offenders rehabilitation and reintegration, by enhancing and strengthening the employability of ex-offenders. This is done by providing them with opportunities from strong partnerships with chambers of commerce, trade associations, employers and other key partners. We are pleased to introduce YRSGs Board of Directors new members with effect from September 2021. Their contributions to the board will help in continuing our work and vision of an inclusive society, a nation beyond second chances. We would also like to thank our outgoing members who have led and pioneered YRSGs key reintegration efforts in the past 6 to 12 years. From career development for ex-offenders and establishing YRSGs strategic directions to achieving key milestones, like our rebranding from SCORE to YRSG. We extend our heartfelt thanks to all members and chairpersons for their contributions!BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

As we commemorate our National Day this year with the theme Together, Our Singapore Spirit, we share Rojes story and his embodiment of the Singapore spirit by making a difference to the lives of others.The father of five recalls that he was always a yes-man and had no hesitation to join his friends in taking drugs in the past. But when he later found out that his son had hesitations in acknowledging him as a father, it spurred him to take charge of his life to be a better role model to his son.And he did.After a three-month stint as a Housekeeping Operations Executive, he was promoted to a Manager and simultaneously pursued a Specialist Diploma in Service Leadership. Roje then took a leap of faith and started his own cleaning company actualising the dreams and goals he had set for himself since his release in 2018. Today, he leads a growing team of 15 and has hired three ex-offenders thus far. He is also a Peer Leader with the Association (SANA) and spends his time counselling and mentoring others in need.Roje shared, As a leader, I have the responsibility of encouraging and motivating my team members. Having my own company allows me to provide more opportunities to others. I joined SANA as a Peer Leader because I wanted to give back to the community and help those who are in recovery.To me, the Singaporean "Kampung Spirit" is about living and working together in harmony. As we progress, I hope we can extend a hand to those who may need a lift in their journey, despite their past.As long as you have the heart, there are many ways in which we can give back.On this day, let us we remember and celebrate all who have contributed to Singapore in their own ways and give our support to those who are still on their journey of change. Happy National Day! SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances NDP2021

Red Dot August is a series of free performances that celebrate all things uniquely Singapore in the month of August. Titled Music for the Soul We Are Each Others Second Chances, the performance will feature original songs written by inmates from previous years Yellow Ribbon Songwriting Competition and an original song written by one of the alumni, Mr Upu Badarrudin. Catch the Yellow Ribbon Performing Arts Centre (PAC) Alumni band live on Esplanade Offstage and Esplanades Facebook page at 7.15pm today!Swipe to hear from the performers on how music has empowered them to pay it forward!We are thankful for the support from community partners, Esplanade Theatres on the Bay and Intune Music in providing the opportunity for ex-offenders to showcase their talent and give back to society. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Our mooncakes are back in time for the Mid-Autumn Festival! Introducing our new flavours Yuzu, Yam and BlackSesame. Our mooncakes are baked using a YellowRibbon mould specially designed by Redbean Pte Ltd, and packaged in a box designed by inmates from the Multimedia Hub within Changi Prison Complex. Each mooncake represents our inmates hopes for a better future together with family and friends. You can make a difference in their lives, while indulging in these delicious handcrafted mooncakes. Proceeds go towards the Yellow Ribbon Fund and other initiatives that support reintegration programmes for offenders.PS: Our mooncakes are also halal certified.To make a personal order, please visit or contact angela_swee.com.sg for corporate bulk purchases. Hurry, as stocks are limited! Orders close on 3 September!BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Earlier this month, the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) Charity Golf 2021 raised a record amount of $465,700 in donations to support inmates, ex-offenders and their families!Proceeds from the event will be channelled towards the rehabilitation and reintegration programmes and services, such as the YRF Skills Training Assistance to Restart (STAR) Bursary, which provides financial assistance to low-income ex-offenders who wish to pursue further education after their release.This would not have been possible without the support from our donors, as well as, event sponsors such as and . As Senior Secretariat for the Yellow Ribbon Project, Denise helps to organise and implement events that share Yellow Ribbons message of giving second chances and promote awareness towards supporting ex-offenders. Denises colleagues in Aftercare go beyond just helping ex-offenders, and often extends aid to the families of ex-offenders, who are consequently impacted by their incarceration.Aftercare is important as we help ex-offenders to unlock the second prison of social stigmatisation, which they may potentially face after their release. Being able to help others, drives a sense of purpose in my work and motivates me to do more to positively impact the lives of our beneficiaries. To individuals who have the passion and interest for a job that is more than just social work and prioritises helping others this is the job for you.If you are looking for a fulfilling career and have the heart to help others change for the better, do visit to join us. Together we can support the Yellow Ribbon cause and inspire collective action for An Inclusive Society, a Nation Beyond Second Chances. SG4SecondChances

!In a pre-recorded speech, Guest-of-Honor, Mrs Josephine Teo, Minister for Communications and Information and Second Minister for Home Affairs thanked CARE Network and its partners for rallying together to find new ways to support ex-offenders and their families during the pandemic.She announced the two strategic thrusts to take CARE Network to the next horizon to reduce the 5-year recidivism rate, and called for CARE Network and its partners to continue to forge new partnerships, learn new skills and work in new ways to continue to make a difference!Our keynote speaker, Ms Melissa Kwee (CEO of National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre) shared her experience in social service, and how every one of us has the power to address wicked problems, together. She encouraged the participants to act and start thinking about the possibilities.Follow us at our event page for more information BeyondSecondChances

"As a home-grown Singapore company, we believe that a Singaporean core is important. The provision of employment opportunities to Singaporeans is also aligned to our principle of sustainable development. The Yellow Ribbon Reintegration Programme is a commendable initiative, and we identify with it. We have worked with Yellow Ribbon Singapore for two years now, and we have more than 10 successful placements thus far.Sembcorp Marine is pleased to have the opportunity to provide gainful employment to such individuals and help them take that bold step to re-integrate into society. We encourage other employers not to dismiss this avenue to find suitable employees."Thank you Sembcorp Marine for your support in second chances. If you are keen on employing ex-offenders, please visit to find out more!BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

As we celebrate National Forgiveness Day, let us remember and value the second chances that others have offered, and for us to offer the same hand in times of need.On this occasion, I would like to seek forgiveness from my mom and those Ive hurt directly prior to my incarceration. My family has been there with me from the beginning, and our relationship has been better since my incarceration.To others like me who are seeking forgiveness, you will find it. And to those who act on your recovery, you will earn it. Its been almost two years since James (not his real name) release. He remains determined in his journey of desistance and has taken active steps to improve his relationship with his family. Today, James continues to volunteer with the Industrial & Services Co-operative Society Ltd (ISCOS) and actively participates in events to help others.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances NationalForgivenessDay
We are just TWO MONTHS away from our first Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run! Follow us to find out how you can register! YRVR2021 ChallengeYRself SG4SecondChances

In June, the Yellow Ribbon Fund collaborated with Acronis and Cyberlite Books to conduct a virtual Cyber Safety Workshop for 25 children of ex-offenders.The interactive session equipped the children with basic IT skills, such as internet safety tips, and guidance on growing platforms like YouTube and TikTok. The session was well-received and we look forward to organising more workshops in the future. A big thank you to our partners for their support! BeyondSecondChances

Dear friends and supporters of YRSG,We have received feedback that some individuals identifying themselves as reformed ex-offenders have been trying to sell keychains under the guise of a fundraiser initiated by the Yellow Ribbon Project. We would like to reiterate that the Yellow Ribbon Project and Yellow Ribbon Fund conduct fundraising activities in this manner and we have not authorised any individuals or groups to do so in public on our behalf.Charity organisations who are licensed to solicit funds in public will be granted a Collectors Certificate of Authority from the National Council of Social Services and a police permit. The authenticity of these documents can be verified by either sending an SMS to MCCY Charities Unit with the following FR<space><NCSS Approval No> to 79777, or checking the Charity Portal at You may also report to the police immediately if you encounter any suspicious donation collectors.

Incarceration is family matter that can affect the offenders spouse, as well as those who depend on them for financial support or for caregiving duties.Like a stack of falling dominoes, imprisonment may also layer on economic, social and emotional consequences on their lives.Ex-offenders often fight unseen battles, sometimes without their loved ones by their side. Thats where support from the community and those closest to ex-offenders can help tide them through tough times.We continue to work with community partners to provide support to inmates, ex-offenders and families who are impacted by their incarceration.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances
We are happy to announce our very first Yellow Ribbon Virtual Run happening this September! Mark your calendars and stay tuned for further details.

I had an ex-offender assigned to me who had accumulated some debts after his release, among other issues. He called me one night and told me he was contemplating suicide as he felt lost and did not know how to deal with the situation. I worked with him through his troubles and gave him the SOS hotline number to call. For the next few weeks, we would talk constantly, and he slowly regained his confidence and determination to overcome his challenges. Eventually, when he was ready, I managed to arrange for him a job which met his salary request at a logistics factory. A year later, he called me on Chinese New Year to express his gratitude and informed me that he had been promoted at work.Employment is the foundation of every individuals livelihood, helping sustain individuals and their families. As a career coach, Bryan rebuilds the lives of ex-offenders by creating employment opportunities for them to take charge of their rehabilitation and create stability in their own lives. He also assists them in overcoming challenges at work and manages other barriers they might face during their reintegration journey. On-site job visits, check-ins with employers and engaging clients the day of a career coach is hectic but rewarding. The effort from a career coach can create a ripple effect that can ultimately change an ex-offenders and their familys lives for the better.If you are looking for a fulfilling career and have the heart to help others change for the better, do visit to join us. (linked on our bio!) Together we can support the Yellow Ribbon cause and inspire collective action for An Inclusive Society, a Nation Beyond Second Chances. SG4SecondChances

"My family visited me regularly and sent me letters and cards. Whenever they came to visit, they would express their love by giving me flying kisses through the glass panel. It felt like they were so near, yet so far. I asked myself why I was being so selfish, leaving them behind and giving them trouble... I had to change.Its been three years since Ramachandrans release. He remains determined to stay on the right path and provide for his family. He is also an active volunteer with Industrial and Services Co-operative Society Limited (ISCOS), where he speaks to inmates through outreach programmes in prisons.Looking back, Ramachandran recalled that his arrest had changed things for his family. In his absence, his wife juggled between her job and taking care of their three children. While in prison, Ramachandran felt a sense of loss to be away from his family and guilty that he had missed out on their milestones and birthdays. Family support, Ramachandran says, was the driving force that kept him going. It motivated him to stay positive and eventually pushed him to turn his life around for good.I hope to be a living testament for those who feel like they have no guidance, those who feel hopeless or even someone who needs a listening ear. I also want to assure my family that Im here now, and I will be here with them all the way no matter what. HappyFathersDay BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Congrats to the teams from the Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP) and Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) for their achievements in this years MHA Innovation Awards! Despite the disruptions and challenges posed by COVID-19, both teams were quick to adapt and champion new initiatives towards the message of second chances and fundraising.YRP championed new approaches and initiatives to encourage second chances, despite the challenges posed by COVID-19. In 2020, the team enabled over 50 inmates and ex-offenders to improve the lives of over 500 beneficiaries. For their effort, the team received a Commendation under the Project category.Nominated under the Dare-To-Try category, the YRF Secretariat team adapted their traditional fundraising efforts and raised $122,000 in their first Online Musical Fundraiser in 2020. Well done to both teams! BeyondSecondchances

In May 2021, we joined our community partners and agencies across ministries for a webinar on Partnering Families in the Journey of Rehabilitation. The webinar helped kickstart conversations about empowering families to support ex-offenders, and we also discussed on how the support provided can help to prevent re-offending and intergenerational crimes for a safer Singapore. The session concluded with a panel discussion featuring speakers from , Associate Timothy Sim from .sg, Mdm Saleemah from and Mr Samuel Mo from . Ex-offender Kent and his wife Jean also shared about Kents 10-year desistance journey and how Jeans unwavering support solidified his determination to change for the better. Thank you all for joining us in this session! BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Behind every ex-offenders successful rehabilitation is a journey of perseverance riddled with obstacles. Support from family, friends and the community provide motivation for ex-offenders to persevere, while employment provides them with financial stability and a structured lifestyle. Yellow Ribbon Singapore and the Yellow Ribbon Fund also provides financial, rehabilitative and aftercare support, so that they may have a smoother transition into society. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

As a Partnership Associate at Yellow Ribbon Singapore, Shirley works with like-minded employers to co-create employment opportunities for ex-offenders. It includes meeting with potential employers to share about hiring processes and providing the support that employers need after theyve successfully hired a candidate. Being gainfully employed gives every ex-offender a sense of purpose and the motivation to work harder. I believe a good working environment allows candidates to have a sense of belonging and this keeps them away from bad company. Seeing the same employers return to us to offer more job opportunities is our greatest motivation for the team. If youre looking for a meaningful career in rehabilitation and aftercare, visit Together we can support the Yellow Ribbon cause and inspire collective action for An Inclusive Society, a Nation Beyond Second Chances. SG4SecondChances

It has been 10 years since Aidil last celebrated Hari Raya with his family. Having been in-and-out of prisons six times, the 42-year-old shared that he was first incarcerated in 1998 for drug related offences. Distracted by the lure of drugs, he re-offended even after his first release. 23-years later, with unwavering support from his family, he is set on quitting his old ways.Aidil shares that he is grateful to be emplaced at the Jamiyah Halfway House and hopes it would signal a new beginning for him.The staff here are very understanding. We can approach them for help with our issues, like renewing our SingPass. Even the head (Mr Mohamad Faizal Bin Abas), hes like a father figure to me.Im really looking forward to my overnight home leave on Hari Raya, so I can be at home spending time with my family again. My parents have always been supportive of me, but I would still like to seek their forgiveness for the things Ive done. I also hope to spend more time with my son soon.For those in recovery, the support from family is critical. May Hari Raya be a time of reflection, togetherness and second chances for all.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

To many ex-offenders like Azahari, Hari Raya is a time for new beginnings and forgiveness.For me, Raya is an occasion to be with family and to treasure the moments spent with them. Its a time for us to appreciate and be thankful for the blessings bestowed on us. When I was incarcerated, I missed being with my loved ones Ive wasted my youth in prison and the time lost can never be retrieved back hence I decided to take charge of my life and make the best out of it."After serving a 20-year sentence for drug trafficking, Azahari is now a site service technician and a Peer Leader with the Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association. He also volunteers actively at anti-drug events to help others.Im thankful for the support from my family. My mother never missed a single visit during my incarceration, and my wife encouraged me to take up my Diploma, even though she had to be the main breadwinner. Everyone makes mistakes and should be given a second chance. We cant reverse the bad decisions weve made in life, but we can all hope to forge new beginnings for a better future.Selamat Hari Raya!BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances SelamatHariRaya HariRaya

Growing up, Hannah struggled with self-acceptance and loneliness. She was always looking to filling up a void she had. So she chased for validation and attention in the hope to attain fulfilment.This led her down a rabbit hole of constant partying and drugs. Even after her imprisonment in 2002 for drug related offences, Hannah continued taking drugs after her release.All that changed when Hannah had her son. He reminded her of the struggles she had while growing up, and motivated her to change for the better to provide a better life for him. I didnt want him to grow up like how I did, and I didnt want to affect him with the state I was in, said Hannah. Today, Hannah is a proud mother of four and spends her time volunteering at The Turning Point, a womens halfway house which provides structured aftercare support for offenders. She also leads a team of volunteers to counsel individuals who need guidance.It has been 16 years since Hannahs last release from prisons, and she hopes to carry the lessons from her past to inspire others to lead better life. My past gave me an opportunity to share how dust can turn into diamonds. Ex-offenders are walking through a journey which has many steps behind an average human being. So let's all be kind and have patience. The more love they receive, the more they are strengthened and motivated from within. When you show kindness to them, you may not know that you are contributing to their healing.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

"Mama is sick, I want you to change." These last few but impactful words from ShaEffas mom that have stayed with her since her previous incarceration. It all started 10 years ago when ShaEffa had her first encounter with drugs. Curious about the experience, ShaEffa decided to try it for the first time and she became addicted. Now 35 and a mother of five, ShaEffa turned her life around and works as a full-time baker to support her family."My parents sacrificed a lot for me when I was in prison. And as a mom myself, being in prison affected me deeply because I realised Im getting older, and my kids are growing up as well. I didnt want to disappoint them. Im grateful to my family for their support and encouragement. They gave me the wings I needed to carry on.To all mothers in recovery, you must stay strong even when it gets difficult. Never give up. You still can make-up for the time youve lost.Motherhood is a journey of discovery and growth for many. For our ex-offenders, the support from family and those close to them will aid in this journey and encourage them to go the distance. Thank you to all moms who have also worked tirelessly to provide for their children and families. HappyMothersDay BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Anna (not her real name) used to cook for me. She would cook my favourites, especially Asam Pedas. In my eyes, she has surpassed me by becoming a better cook. This is the first time she baked for me.Earlier last month, inmates from Institution A4 baked cookies for their families under a Mothers Day project sponsored by SSA Culinary Institute.For Annas mom, Mdm Munirah, it was a much-welcomed gesture as it reminded her of beloved moments spent with her daughter. I cherish all the memories we have together. It could just be talking to her, or when she takes me out for walks. They are all my favourite. When shes released, the first thing I would like to do is to give her a big hug. I miss her very much. I will wait for her till the end of time. I really hope that when she is released, she will change. I plan to cook her favorite dish, Asam Pedas Ikan Sembilang.A mothers love is stronger than distance, and more powerful than time. This Mothers Day, we thank all mothers for the sacrifices theyve made for us, and their unwavering support and acceptance.HappyMothersDay BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances
