In celebration of Mothers Day, 12 inmates participated in a project sponsored by SSA Culinary Institute to bake cookies for their families. It has been a difficult period for the inmates as open visits with their families could not be organized due to COVID-19 safety management measures. The day started with a demonstration by Chef Aishah from SSA Culinary Institute, followed by a hands-on session for the inmates. Their labour of love was also freshly delivered with the help of Bravehearts SRM Services Pte Ltd to convey their love for their families.It was great to see them so involved and curious. They wanted to learn more and asked many questions about the baking process. Seeing their interest makes me heartened to offer more of my knowledge. said Chef Aishah.Thank you to .institute and for partnering with Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP) and making this possible for our inmates and their families. Support from them as our community partners contributes towards the inmates rehabilitation and reintegration journey.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

It was a gainful morning of conceptualising and charting new frontiers for the next bound.We look forward to new possibilities in the areas of Capabilities and Capacity Development, Service Transformation and Community Mobilisation! .sg CARENetwork CARENetworkRetreat2021

Family support can make all the difference in an offenders journey of change. For Hanz, her grandfathers brush with death changed her perspective on life and encouraged her to quit her life of crime. Back then, I was living a life without goals and discipline. I was around addicts, those selling illegal cigarettes and many others. My day only started when others ended theirs. I would sleep in the morning, and once the sun goes down thats when my day would start.During a family visit while she was still incarcerated, Hanzs parents shared that her grandfather had suffered from a heart attack, and in his moments of consciousness, called out for Hanz to come to him. That was a blow. I panicked and asked if he was ok. They said yes but said that he was still calling for me. That really motivated me to stay clean and finish my sentence. The fear of losing a loved one while being inside... its something you will regret, said Hanz.With the support of her family, Hanz has stayed crime free for the past 10 years. Now 32, Hanz is a manager at a popular retail store and is looking forward to owning her first home.After all the support and hard work, Ive finally managed to get my own house. Im waiting to collect my keys now. Im thankful to my bosses and general manager who have always believed in me and trusted me, Hanz shared with gratitude.We are all the same, though the path we choose might be different. Everyone makes mistakes, and they just need that opportunity to change. The support we receive will help in our journey of finding our way home.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Launched in 2019, CANVAS was founded to help inmate artists from prisons Visual Arts Hub (VAH) continue their journey with art after their release. In addition to cultivating patience and discipline, art allows one to explore and develop a voice in their journey of change.Co-founder, Barry Yeow shared that CANVAS was started as he wanted other aspiring artists to do well, and he had hoped to provide an avenue of support for them after their release.I struggled to cope with art and life after leaving prisons. Its not easy without the support of others. Hence, CANVAS helps to provide support to the ex-VAH artists who wish to continue to pursue their art. But more than just art, the group was also started to support them to do well in life.In commemoration of World Arts Day 2021, let us celebrate the creative expressions and contributions brought about by artists, and the positive impact it has made in the lives of ex-offenders and the community. BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

The process of abstaining from crime, also known as desistance, is often a challenging journey for many individuals as they attempt to live a pro-social life. Every individuals journey is different, but the ones who eventually succeed are those who do not give up, and persevere through multiple successes and failures.During the journey of desistance, it is important to understand that successes and failures are not defined by incidents of relapse or abstinence. Rather, we should look out for small steps of successes during their journeys, and encourage them to choose actions which bring them closer to their end goal of a fulfilling life.Desistance is an ongoing process that requires full commitment from individuals, those close to them, and society. Your support can be the push that helps them through their journeys of change.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

We were all shocked when we received the call. Yusuf (pseudonym) had always been stable so we didnt suspect anything." Despite Yusufs mischievous and cheeky demeanor as a kid, nothing in his behavior would have prepared his family for his string of arrests later on. He had never shown signs of drug addiction. But it was after his first divorce when things started going downhill. The subsequent relationships he had were unhealthy, and they even did drugs together. I tried not to be too involved because he was an adult, but I remained hopeful and continued supporting him, said his sister, Farah (pseudonym).During his first two sentences, I supported him financially when he was released. I also wanted him to be more financially stable, so I got him a job as a Grab driver. But I told him that he needs to help himself too. I even asked him Do you want to change your habits or change your address to Changi Prison?Things took a turn when their father suffered a stroke during Yusufs third incarceration. This was a wake-up call for him, as he came to the realization that he could lose his father while being incarcerated. With Farahs help and coordination, Yusuf was able to speak to his father again.During the pandemic, we made phone calls instead of tele-visits. Otherwise my dad would not have been well enough to leave the house. In the call, Yusuf told our dad that he would pray for him and hopefully be able to see him again soon. My dad was very happy to hear this as he had been asking about Yusuf, said Farah.Yusuf is thankful for the support he has received and plans to join his family in the construction industry after his release in 2021.The support from Yusufs sister will be one of the critical factors for his successful reintegration. On this International Siblings Day, we commemorate the love and support from our brothers and sisters, and their commitment to love us even when we are at our lowest.InternationalSiblingsDay BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Every year, about 9,000 inmates are released from prisons to start a new life. Many do so without the support of their families. Left on their own, some face struggles when trying to reintegrate into society. The inmates release pack was piloted by the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) in late 2019 to help ex-offenders find their footing as they take their first steps beyond the prison gates. Specially curated with vouchers and pre-loaded cards to address their basic needs from clothing, grocery to transport, the pack also includes handy information on social support organizations which ex-offenders can seek for help. Thanks to the support of like-minded partners like CIMB, more than 1,170 ex-offenders have been provided with this release pack since the projects inception in 2019. It has helped to lighten the financial and practical concerns of the ex-offenders especially during the COVID-19 pandemic. The initiative has been very well received and we look forward to more community partnership with other agencies.

I called my sister to tell her that I was going to bail myself out and run away. It was then she told me that moms cancer had relapsed. It was stage four again.These were the last words Gary (pseudonym) heard before his court sentencing for his third imprisonment.I was prepared to be on the run. But I knew I would never see my mom again. I told my friends, Dont bail me out. I will just go. said Gary.Gary was first imprisoned in 2000 for drug possession. He shared that it was through friends that he came to know about drugs. He relapsed in 2004, and served an additional three years behind bars. During his second imprisonment, he shared that the opportunities that he received then that kick-started his culinary journey.Prisons gave me a lot of chances to excel. I had the chance to head Dining Behind Bars (DBB), and they allowed me to select and lead the whole team. I was the very first executive chef for DBB and was glad to pull through many events with exciting menus. Through all the events, I managed to upgrade myself.But it wasnt until his third imprisonment that Gary decided to quit his old lifestyle for good. I was married before my last imprisonment and was doing well in life. But my biggest mistake was when I started to get close to drugs again. This was when my moms cancer relapsed.Today, Gary is the successful owner of several culinary and consultancy businesses. He is grateful for the help he received during his imprisonment and seeks to give back by hiring ex-offenders for his own company. When inmates are released from prisons, they really try their best. But they get hindered by so many setbacks, it brings their patience and confidence down. The unlocking of the second prison plays a big part and I hope that families do their best to support them. Else it would be difficult (for their rehabilitation). said Gary.And to other inmates, when you are released, you need to have a goal. Whether its long or short term, big or small goals it doesnt matter. If you dont have a goal, you will find that your life is pointless. You may do things that could eventually hurt your family. SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Among us, we encourage each other to do better. If someone lacks something or needs help, we will try to help each other out."In January this year, the Selarang Halfway House (SHWH) started offering residential and recovery programmes to inmates on Community Based Programmes (CBP). Under the CBP, suitable inmates can serve the tail end of their sentences in the community under supervision.For Adam, Farhan and Daniel (pseudonyms), this was an opportunity they welcomed as they sought to restart their lives and return as contributing members of society again.There were many changes we were inmates and now we are civilians. Its a big change and its a stepping-stone for us, said Adam.At the halfway house, we attend programmes and courses like Digital and Design Thinking that helps us to plan for our future. We also have group counselling where we share our thoughts and how we want to overcome our (drug) triggers. Having consumed drugs from the age of 13, Farhan adds that triggers can come in different forms for each person. When we see certain things, it can trigger us. For me, Ive struggled with memories and places.For me, I have a lot of friends good and bad. When I bump into the bad ones, thats when I can get triggered. Now that I am aware of this, I know I need to leave these people in my past, behind. Its unnecessary to keep them, added Daniel.When asked about their motivations, the trio shared that it was their families that kept them going.My children grew up without me, and my wife survived without me. I want to be a good husband and father as theyve sacrificed a lot for me. Its time for me to give back to them, said Daniel.Ive disappointed my parents seven times, but they are still supportive and believe in my change. Their belief motivates me to change, shared Farhan.As Adam, Farhan and Daniel look forward to their future, they hope for a permanent and stable return to make amends for their past mistakes.We also want to be part of society and the community, and be as happy as everyone (else). Nobody sets out in their life to make a mistake and go to prison. said Adam.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Congrats to our students from the Yellow Brick Road (YBR) programme who have studied hard and achieved their goals in the academic year of 2020!To acknowledge their efforts and to encourage the children in their academic journey, Eastspring Investments has kindly sponsored bursaries to those who have shown improvement in their studies. Each child will receive $250 comprising vouchers from NTUC, Popular and Toys R US.Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) is thankful for the support of like-minded partners such as Eastspring Investments. These efforts will go a long way in supporting our inmates and ex-offenders and their families along their journey of reintegration and rehabilitation.

Halfway houses like the Selarang Halfway House (SHWH) are designed to provide a conducive rehabilitative environment for ex-offenders to steadily reintegrate back into society. During their stay, SHWH works with their residents to address reintegration issues through counselling and vocational training that encourages them to make positive and lasting changes in their lives. Residents are also given time-off to return home to be with their families, or to participate in community activities where suitable. For those who need help to get employment, there will also be assistance rendered. Emplacement at the SHWH is part of the Mandatory Aftercare Scheme (MAS) for selected ex-offenders, upon their release from prisons to help them in their transitional process in the community as part of their rehabilitation and reintegration journey. Thank you Mdm and Assoc Prof for joining us earlier this week for a tour at SHWH.SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

At the tender age of 14, he started using drugs with friends on a recreational basis. But this addiction grew into a habit that was beyond his control. He was eventually arrested and placed behind bars.Now 29, Jordan (pseudonym) hopes to make amends and put his past behind him.Since 2020, hes been making the most of his days after being emplaced at The Helping Hand (THH) one of eight halfway houses that work with Singapore Prison Service (SPS) in providing transitional support for ex-offenders.Back then, my life felt aimless. I didnt have any goals. Even if I had a goal, I would stop halfway when it got difficult. I always thought I could stop (taking drugs) when I wanted to, but its not that easy. In fact, it just got worse and I was desperately hooked.All that changed when Jordan learnt of his grandmothers passing. It was a wake-up call that spurred him to take charge of his life.We were very close from the beginning. The sudden loss made me miserable as I always confided in her. We got even closer when she was battling cancer, and her passing made me feel like I lost a part of myself.After losing her, I told myself that I wanted to stay clean and be there for all my loved ones. Time is short, I dont want to waste it anymore. I dont want to attend another funeral in prison clothing.Today, Jordan is serving the tail end of his sentence as an Assistant at THHs urban farm, where he helps to cultivate fishes and a vegetation site. With the support from THH, Jordan has also received his admission to study for a diploma at a polytechnic.As he looks forward to his future ahead, Jordan also hopes to inspire other ex-offenders to lead their best life.I hope I can use my story to change someone elses life. Patience is important when we are first released from prison. Just like farming, rehabilitation is a process. A good life doesnt mean every day will be smooth sailing. Dont give up.To the community out there, I hope you can be more patient with us. For people like us, when we are first released, we are quite lost and for many, they dont really have any family support.DrugFreeSg BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Being gainfully employed is one of the most crucial aspects of an ex-offenders journey back into society. A stable job is more than just a source of income for them it gives them a renewed sense of purpose and allows them to be responsible for their families. As an employer, you can make a positive impact by providing them a job and help build their career.Under the Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI)* scheme, employers who hire ex-offenders will receive 50% salary support for 18 months.To find out more, please visit may also visit to find out more about JGI. SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances*JGI is applicable to hires between September 2020 to September 2021.

When ex-offenders are given a second chance to restart their lives, many set off to make up for lost time meaningfully. However, some may experience a disconnect with the world that has seemingly moved on without them. Apart from catching up with the society, many are also fighting to remove the label that society has placed on them.For this years Happiness Film Festival, the Happiness Initiative will be screening six international films, each paired with a local film followed by a dialogue that explores issues faced by vulnerable and marginalized groups. In partnership with The Happiness Initiative, we will also be discussing second chances and rediscovery for ex-offenders, and how we can better support their journey.Join us on 27 March 2021 (Saturday) at Filmgarde Bugis+ to catch the movie Skid Row Marathon a movie about a judge who inspires the homeless, addicts and ex-offenders through a running club. Grab your tickets here - SG4SecondChances

Shocked, joy and hope. These were some of the many feelings Amin (pseudonym) and his family experienced when they heard the announcement. He had emerged as the champion in this years Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition (YRCC), with his winning entry of Nasi Briyani and Fish Masala.Amin earnestly shared that he had no experience in cooking, and only had four months of practice prior to the competition. It was a push he received from SGT Saharudeen Sawad that kickstarted his culinary journey.I started by learning how to chop vegetables at the The Changi Tearoom for six months. During that time, I was curious and would always peek at my fellow inmates who were cooking. SGT Saharudeen saw this and asked me if I wanted to take up cooking as well. It was difficult to pick it up at first. I always forgot to add ingredients to the dishes in the beginning, Amin laughed when recalling his first foray into cooking.But the most difficult situation he has dealt with during his incarceration was his mothers recent passing. Amin was first sentenced in 1995 for drug related offences, and continued this drug lifestyle up to 2016. By 2016, he was into his fifth sentence. The frequency of his arrests also meant that he had little time with his family, a consequence he regrets.Ive been in prison since I was 19. Im halfway through my life now, but I still hope to be able to spend time with my family and take care of my father. If my mother was still here, I would like to tell her that Im doing all of this for her. Ive never really cooked for the family; it was always her (doing the cooking). I hope she will be proud of my achievements today.When asked about what he looks forward to after his release, Amin mentioned that he hopes to cook curry chicken for his family the first dish he learnt in prison that started it all. To other inmates and ex-offenders - if you think you want to change, there is always someone who will support you. Just do it, dont look back, said Amin.Amin is currently serving an eight-year sentence and will be released in 2023.

Shocked, joy and hope. These were some of the many feelings Amin (pseudonym) and his family experienced when they heard the announcement. He had emerged as the champion in this years Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition (YRCC), with his winning entry of Nasi Briyani and Fish Masala.Amin earnestly shared that he had no experience in cooking, and only had four months of practice prior to the competition. It was a push he received from SGT Saharudeen Sawad that kickstarted his culinary journey.I started by learning how to chop vegetables at the The Changi Tearoom for six months. During that time, I was curious and would always peek at my fellow inmates who were cooking. SGT Saharudeen saw this and asked me if I wanted to take up cooking as well. It was difficult to pick it up at first. I always forgot to add ingredients to the dishes in the beginning, Amin laughed when recalling his first foray into cooking.But the most difficult situation he has dealt with during his incarceration was his mothers recent passing. Amin was first sentenced in 1995 for drug related offences, and continued this drug lifestyle up to 2016. By 2016, he was into his fifth sentence. The frequency of his arrests also meant that he had little time with his family, a consequence he regrets.Ive been in prison since I was 19. Im halfway through my life now, but I still hope to be able to spend time with my family and take care of my father. If my mother was still here, I would like to tell her that Im doing all of this for her. Ive never really cooked for the family; it was always her (doing the cooking). I hope she will be proud of my achievements today.When asked about what he looks forward to after his release, Amin mentioned that he hopes to cook curry chicken for his family the first dish he learnt in prison that started it all. To other inmates and ex-offenders - if you think you want to change, there is always someone who will support you. Just do it, dont look back, said Amin.Amin is currently serving an eight-year sentence and will be released in 2023.

And the winning entry from this years Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition goes to Amin and his Bee Hoon Briyani with Fish Masala & Acar!Inspired by his love for briyani, Amin (pseudonym) wanted to pay homage to his favourite dish with his own creative take while incorporating the competitions main ingredient seabass. Despite not having any culinary experience prior to the competition, Amin joined the competition as he wanted to make his family proud. With only four months of practice prior to the competition, he blew the judges away with his creativity and flavoursome dish. Congratulations Amin! YellowRibbonCulinaryCompetition SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Earlier this month, residents from HEB Ashram Halfway House and Green Haven came together to participate in NParks OneMillionTrees movement. The movement aims to restore nature back into our garden city through the planting of more than a million trees with more than 163,000 trees planted to date!Residents from both halfway houses started the day with a collective beach clean-up at Sembawang Park, followed by prep work for the tree planting. We are happy to share that residents planted a total of 30 trees during the initiative! Thank you for giving the residents from the halfway houses the opportunities to give back to help build a greener nation for future generations to enjoy. This project was also made possible through the coordination with Ms Nutan Shah, a participant from the Emerging Stronger Conversation Beyond Second Chances event held in 2020. She had approached the organisers with the intention to bring ex-offenders and the community closer through nature. SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Featuring our top 5 winners for this years YellowRibbonCulinaryCompetition! For this years competition, the Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP) and the Association (SCA), ran its first-ever virtual cooking competition with the theme Recipe for Change. This was inspired by Singapores resilience to overcome the disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic and the motivation within the inmates to develop their own recipes for change during their rehabilitation journey. Prior to the formal runs of the competition, inmate participants also underwent culinary training with professional chef mentors from SCA: Dexter Lim, an Executive Sous Chef at TWG Tea Singapore; and Royce Lee, Head Chef in Research & Development of Food Products at H&Z Mart Pte Ltd. Royce is also an ex-offender and he wanted to contribute to the competition as a mentor, not only to impart his culinary knowledge but also to inspire the inmates to successfully turn their lives around and give back to the community like he did.In a YRCC first, each participant also had their dishes prepared with love delivered to their families.Do share with us your favourite dish in the comments below! BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances RecipeForChange

The work of a career coach is often hectic and demanding. From engaging ex-offenders to understanding their needs, as well as on-site job visits and check-ins with their employers, being a career coach is challenging but a rewarding and meaningful job!In celebration of the International Womens Day this year, we speak to Julie Watt, who is one of the 13 career coaches at the Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG), to find out more about her passions and role as a career coach.While studying Criminology, Julie learnt that people are driven by certain factors (social, environmental or personal choice) to commit crimes. On a more personal level, she also felt compelled to help the needy like inmates and ex-offenders, and wanted a hands-on career that allows her to pursue her passion to help. With these ambitions in mind, she accepted a job as a career coach at YRSG.My favorite part of the job is when I am able to go on-site and engage the supervisees to understand their situations in a more in-depth manner. Understanding their stories allows me to build rapport with them. They also become more comfortable and I gain their confidence and trust that YRSG is able to make a difference in their lives. Being in this field also poses its own set of challenges, such as management and prioritization of supervisees needs. However, Julie is grateful to her reporting officer, Siti Aishah, for her guidance through the different cases, and has also learnt to organize and plan her work week to better manage her time.But on her most hectic days, it is the outcome of making a positive difference in the lives of others that keeps her going.I had an ex-offender whom I managed previously. She shared that she was grateful to have me as her career coach. The ex-offender said she appreciated the way I encouraged and motivated her. That made her want to work towards being a better version of herself. To Julie Watt and other women who are passionate about making a positive difference in the lives of others, we celebrate your achievements in helping to create an inclusive world!BeyondSecondChances CelebratingSGWomen ChooseToChallenge

[Handmade cookies by inmates from YRI Bakery]Don't we all love the aroma of freshly baked cookies? From a humble workshop within prisons in 1976, YRI Bakery has expanded to become to a full-fledged industrial bakery under YR industries today. The Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition is one of the many initiatives that aims to equip inmate participants with skills training relevant to the Food & Beverage (F&B) Industries to enhance their employability. This years competition also marks Singapores first virtual cooking competition, where as part of the programme, inmate participants are also given the opportunity to cook and have the food delivered to their families.For one inmate participant, his passion for cooking began even before he was incarcerated.Mark has been interested in cooking since young and helped out at our restaurants when he was around 10 years old, recalls his mother, Mdm Tan, as she bites into his fried fish. Hes very particular when it comes to food presentation you can see it in his cooking. Hes cooked and sliced his fish beautifully. The colour and cut on his vegetables are good too.The pineapple rice, she pauses and reminisces. Its our familys specialty.Thus, when Mark was jailed in 2018 for drug offences, it broke her heart. Im not young anymore, and hes going in for quite some time. Ive felt lonelier these past two years, but I keep myself busy by working at the restaurants. I cant wait to invite him back home.Although Mark had committed drug offences, Mdm Tan maintains that he is a filial son. He would check up on her during her visits, asking her if she had enough money to spend and reminded her to eat and sleep well. But above all, he always would always ask her to wait for him to come out.As mothers, we just want the best for you, so please spend your time in prison well. Thats all we ask for. said Mdm Tan.While his days in the kitchen differ slightly now, it is evident that Mark still possesses the same burning passion and skill behind bars. He has also done well enough to top his cluster in this years Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition and will move on to compete for the winning spot against five finalists from the other clusters.BeyondSecondChances SG4SecondChances

Employment gives ex-offenders a structured lifestyle, and with that they can build onto other extensions such as being responsible towards their families. It also gives them a sense of purpose and achievement. Being gainfully employed in a regular job is crucial for their reintegration. - Marc Chong, Senior Assistant Director of Careers, Yellow Ribbon Singapore.For ex-offenders, employment provide more than just income. It gives them a routine and structured lifestyle that they can follow through as they make the transition from prison life. It is also an opportunity for them to contribute back to society.Thanks to the continued support from employers, we saw an increase of almost 300 employers who have registered with Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) in 2020 to provide job support programmes for inmates prior to their release. SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

At the tender age of 14, Johnson was introduced to drugs while with a group of friends. What started out as curiosity soon turned to habitual use over many years. It all came to a halt after he was reported to the authorities by his so-called friends.From his fast-paced life as a fitness trainer and commercial diver who frequently travelled the world, it was a stark contrast to his life in prison. This also severely impacted his relationship with his family.Fortunately for Johnson, things took a turn for the better after he met his career coach, Bryan who handed him the second chance he needed to get back on his feet again.Hear all about it via or tap the link in our bio!

Years of incarceration can take a toll on not only an ex-offender, but their loved ones too. Many find themselves released from a physical prison only to walk into a second prison, a prison with invisible bars of suspicion, mistrust and discrimination.Follow the journey of one such ex-offender, K, and peek into his struggles and unseen challenges post-release. Stay with us for part 2 of his story.

Earlier this month, the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) sponsored Bag-to-School packs to aid more than 200 children with incarcerated parents to prepare them for the upcoming school year. Each pack contained school essentials such as stationaries, a water bottle and a bag pack. The Bag-to-School packs were also packed by a group of YRP volunteers and delivered by , a logistic company run by an ex-offender!Through this initiative, YRF hopes to give them a boost of confidence and encouragement in their studies as they begin their new school year.

Meet Ms Natasha Liok, a Board Member of the Yellow Ribbon Fund who has served more than four years.She helps support the development and implementation of rehabilitation and reintegration programmes for ex-offenders and their families.Beyond her duties, Ms Liok is a volunteer on the Advancement Committee and the Family & Childrens Welfare Committee where she prepares programmes such as fundraising opportunities for the families of the incarcerated.Through these activities and events, I was deeply moved by seeing how family members, both young and old come together to embrace the inmates. However, I have also seen the unspoken impact it has on some of them through their expressions and that for me hits home on the work we need to continue doing to bridge the gap.Additionally, through the support of my fellow committee members who each are experts in their own fields, all this has inspired me to continue volunteering for YRF.Despite disruptions during the COVID-19 period, YRF continues to offer support to beneficiaries in need of help. More than $400,000 has been set aside by YRF to support ex-offenders, families and children of the incarcerated for initiatives such as the Yellow Ribbon Emergency Fund (YREF), YRF-Residential Aftercare Support Programme (RASP) and CARE Packs for Families of Incarcerated.If you require assistance from YRF, please reach out to cheryl_poon.gov.sg.
A new year brings new beginnings, and new opportunities to make things right again. No matter how hard the past is, you can always start again. Happy New Year everyone!

On 15 December 2020, the Singapore Precision Engineering and Technology Association (SPETA), Nanyang Polytechnic (NYP) and Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) signed a tripartite Memorandum of Understanding that aims to help inmates acquire industry skills and pursue career in the precision engineering sector.This is in line with YRSGs TAP (Train, Attach and Place) and Grow initiative to help inmates in their reintegration journey. A new training workshop will also be set up in prison for inmates to attain the WSQ Advanced Certificate in Precision Engineering with Quality Assurance Skills. It is is expected to commence in June 2021 where 100 inmates will be trained each year.We are confident this collaboration would help strengthen inmates rehabilitation and reintegration journey!

If you change nothing, nothing will change.While family and community support play an important part in an ex-offenders reintegration journey, each individual must also find it within themselves to change and make amends.Khairul was jailed four years ago for peddling contraband cigarettes. When he was released, he made the conscious decision to steer clear from his past mistakes and instead, focus on providing for his family an immediate priority as his household comprises 11 others.Together with his wife Nazira, they have set up a baking business called Bakes by NY. He handles the marketing and business side of things, while she does the baking. Bakes by NY has since expanded to three outlets in the span of four years.Khairul credits this achievement to strong family support and a good work ethic.He elaborated, I have a very encouraging family. They supported me endlessly with my dream to run a small business. They helped me with labour and in monetary terms. It took many years of hardship and failures to be here today, to finally have three outlets. I did not want to fail and hence this feeling further encouraged me to work tirelessly for four years, sacrificing my free time to work non-stop.Khairul is grateful for the support he has received, and continues to pay it forward as a business owner. He has also offered employment opportunities to other ex-offenders as he believes that people should be assessed on their capabilities, rather than their past. Ex-offenders are human as well. They need to be encouraged and given a chance so that they can have a better life and feel that they are accepted. If society closes their doors on them, the offenders might return to their old ways.SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Thank you to all who joined us in our first virtual YRP volunteer engagement session! During the session, our volunteers shared their experiences with YRP and contributed ideas to further support the YR cause in 2021.With the on-going safe management measures, many volunteer opportunities had to be put on hold. We are glad to hold this session to kickstart our engagement with our volunteers again! If you are interested to join us as a volunteer, find out more here SG4secondchances

The Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) raised more than $178,000 in their inaugural online silent auction which happened between October and November 2020. The items that were specially created for the auction included a 6-course fine-dining experience by the inmate chefs in collaboration with the Singapore Chefs Association (SCA), artworks by inmate artists from the Visual Arts Hub (VAH) in B4, and exquisite calligraphy pieces by Master Lim Tze Peng, a renowned artist in Singapore. Thank you to all who supported generously. All proceeds raised from the event will go towards supporting programmes such as the YRF STAR Bursary, which provides support for ex-offenders like Calvin in building viable future for themselves and their families through enhancing employability and encourage self-sufficiency.To find out more about the Yellow Ribbon Fund -

The Yellow Ribbon Fund STAR (Skills Training Assistance to Re-start) Bursary aims to provide support for ex-offenders like Ethan, to build viable futures for themselves and their families through upgrading, employability and self-sufficiency. Influenced by his friends who introduced him to drugs, Ethan turned to a life of partying and drugs. He was later jailed for drug consumption. When he was released in 2017, Ethan felt that everyone had given up on him. With assistance from the Yellow Ribbon Fund, he successfully enrolled in the YRF STAR (Skills Training Assistance to Re-start) Bursary, which sponsored his Diploma in Mechanical Engineering.This was a life-changing opportunity for Ethan and motivated him to work harder to better support his family and contribute back to society. We would like to thank for their support in 2020 through donations and educational opportunities for ex-offenders in their tertiary education journey. Training and upskilling is close to our hearts. We are happy to have the opportunity to give back through the YRF STAR Bursary. Through supporting educational opportunities for ex-offenders, we hope to offer them the means to gain knowledge, build capabilities, and motivate them to contribute towards society through their career in the future. the late Mr Kwek Kok Kwong (CEO, NTUC LearningHub)

Having a strong network and support system is crucial for an ex-offenders rehabilitation and reintegration journey. For Kasmawati, she was the sole caregiver and parental figure to her son when she was released in 2013. She juggled between jobs, housing loans and supporting her son - often dealing with her problems alone. She was not always optimistic about her situation but shared that it was her family and community who helped pull her through rough times.I aim to be a better person for my family. They constantly remind me not to go back to my old ways. My community and neighbours are helpful too they always give me encouragement.Kasmawati also credits her progress to her counsellor, Janet. She had received counselling from the Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association (SANA) for six months after her release, but continued after as it had helped her tremendously.Janet was very helpful. When I was released, she always called me to check up on me and showed me where to ask for help. I realised that if people want to help me, I should also help myself.Today, Kasmawati is a therapist to stroke patients at SynPhNe Pte Ltd and is also involved in rehabilitative and community work. She is the project chairwoman for various community projects and continues to take up volunteer work in her free time.When asked what advice she would share with other ex-offenders who might be struggling, Kasmawati said, Dont lose hope. You need to have more determination and goals for yourself. Focus for a better life you can do it.SG4SecondChancesBeyondSecondChances
Happy Deepavali to all! May the festival of lights illuminate the path for acceptance, forgiveness and secondchances.
Amidst the 11:11 shopping frenzy, do remember to make room for those that need our support and acceptance! Happy shopping! SG4SecondChances

The road to recovery from substance abuse starts with building individuals self-worth and enabling self-determination but the successful rehabilitation and reintegration of a drug offender requires a whole-of-community effort. As a member of the Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network, the (SANA) harness community support in substance abuse prevention and providing aftercare support for recovering drug addicts. SANA works closely with schools, youth groups, ex-clients and community groups to help Singapore achieve its aspiration for a drug-free society. Although the COVID-19 pandemic has impacted SANAs operating landscape, it also provided the impetus for SANA to relook at its client engagement approach and design new service offering to support clients who were adversely affected. SANA formed the Care and Resilience Support Taskforce (CARES) in April 2020 to provide timely support to clients who required urgent assistance but were no longer able to do walk-in to SANAs centres. SANA has also taken engagements with clients and volunteers online, through Zoom and FaceBook Live events, with themes ranging from family support to mental health, employment and skills upgrading. To all people in recovery struggling in this tough period, persevere in your recovery journey. The path ahead will not be easy, but you do not have to face the challenges alone. SANAs Step-Up Centres are always open and their counsellors, para-counsellors and Peer Leaders are here to provide all the support you need. To contact SANA: 6732 1122 / 9847 5102 SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances RiseAboveTheInfluence*Photos were taken before circuit breaker period._________________________________*The Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network is an alliance of various Social Service Agencies (SSAs) and Government Organisations dedicated to the rehabilitation and reintegration for ex-offenders and their families.

Successful rehabilitation and reintegration of ex-offenders is a community effort! SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances

Aftercare is an important aspect of every ex-offenders reintegration into society. Many face issues like strained familial relationships, stigmatisation, finding gainful employment and financial constraints upon release. As a member of the Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network, the Singapore After-Care Association (SACA) works with a pool of over 200 volunteers to support ex-offenders and their families upon their release, from walking with ex-offenders on their rehabilitation journey, to emotional support and practical assistance for clients and their families. When COVID-19 reached Singapore, SACA has kept its office open for as long as possible for walk-in clients and took steps to ensure that its hotline was running. As Singapore moves towards Safe Reopening, SACA has gradually resumed house visits for the families with urgent needs. This is a very tough time for everyone. The economy has been impacted and jobs are scarce. We cant create jobs from thin air, but we will try our best to help you if you reach out to us. Hang in there and remember the goals you have. As long as you dont give up, there will always be a way. Team SACASACA is reachable at 6294 2350/6294 2763 enquiries.org.sg if you require assistance.SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances *Photos were taken before circuit breaker period.__________________________________*The Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network is an alliance of various Social Service Agencies (SSAs) and Government Organisations dedicated to the rehabilitation and reintegration for ex-offenders and their families.

Gainful employment is a critical factor to prevent reoffending. In addition to providing income to these individuals and their families, jobs may provide a sense of structure, healthy social interactions and a sense of purpose. Through various programmes and initiatives, Industrial & Services Co-operative Society Ltd (ISCOS) has supported thousands of ex-offender members with job placements, skills training and support groups since its inception. This include the Gift of Hope (welcome packs for new members), Project ReConnect (an orientation programme), and Project Give A Line, Change A Life (sponsored mobile phones with data for eligible members). ISCOS is also one of the core members of the Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-Offenders (CARE) Network. Many were affected by the changes brought about by COVID-19 this year. The ISCOS team has made use of technology to continue supporting members in job placements and virtual support groups. Several initiatives were also introduced to help members and beneficiaries ride through these challenging times: Steady Packs were given to newly-released ex-offenders and residents of various halfway houses. Family Steady Packs, together with financial assistance, were given to case-managed families under the Fairy Godparent Programme by , the charity arm of ISCOS. Steady Payment was introduced to provide job retention award to members upon the first week of successful job placements. Steady Notes (words of encouragement) were compiled and shared on social media to uplift the spirits of the community. More Steady initiatives will be introduced along the way to support members and beneficiaries to combat COVID-19. Youve got a friend in ISCOS! To contact ISCOS: 6743 7885 or SG4SecondChances BeyondSecondChances *Photos were taken before circuit breaker period._____________________________________*The Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network is an alliance of various Social Service Agencies (SSAs) and Government Organisations dedicated to the rehabilitation and reintegration for ex-offenders and their families.

Despite the limitations that were brought about by the COVID-19 situation, Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) was able to raise more than $120,000 in its first ever online musical fundraising event - thanks to the support of many big-hearted donors!The musical fundraising event was started in collaboration with Singapore Repertory Theatre to raise funds for YRF, which supports initiatives that are catered to the families and children of inmates, like the Yellow Brick Road (YBR) Programme.We would also like to thank one of our corporate sponsors, Dymon Asia, for paying it forward through passing on the online musical passes to our beneficiaries. This thoughtful gesture brought much cheer and warmed the hearts of our beneficiaries and their families.

Mdm Nuraini (pseudonym) is the sole breadwinner of her family and takes care of her five children. Her husband, Ibrahim (pseudonym), has been incarcerated for drug-related offences. As she needs to work part-time to support her family, Mdm Nuraini has lesser time to spend with her children and thats when she found it hard to communicate and understand them. To work and improve on her relationship with them, she enrolled into the Yellow Brick Road (YBR) Programme. Through the YBR programme, the parenting workshops enabled her to better communicate with her children, thus fostering a stronger bond than before. She also hopes to spend more time with them during the school holiday period. To support more families like Mdm Nurainis, the Yellow Ribbon Fund will be organising an online musical fundraiser in collaboration with the on 12 Sep 2020. To find out more, please visit

A second chance is the greatest gift that an ex-offender can receive. For ex-offenders turned artists such as Barry and Rahman, they have transformed their lives for the better through their exposure of art at the Visual Arts Hub (VAH) in Changi Prison Complex. Art definitely played a big part in my recovery. When I embarked on my art journey in prisons, I became enlightened and saw myself as a piece of art. My life is like a piece of canvas, how Im going to paint it lies solely based on my decision making, said Barry, who is now a full-time artist. His mentee, Rahman, has also embarked on a journey to further pursue his calling to art after getting accepted into the Diploma in Fine Arts programme at LASALLE College of the Arts through the art portfolio that he curated during his time at VAH. Art gave me a second chance in life and I feel that through art I am able to explore my creativity. I feel really happy to be able to pursue it now, said Rahman. To hear more about both their life experiences and artists journeys, tune into RedDotAugust A Passage of Life to Art talk happening today, 19 August at 9pm on Esplanades Facebook and Esplanade Offstage ( BeyondSecondChances

For ex-offenders turned artists such as Barry and Rahman, they have transformed their lives for the better through their exposure of art at the Visual Arts Hub (VAH) in Changi Prison Complex. Art definitely played a big part in my recovery. When I embarked on my art journey in prisons, I became enlightened and saw myself as a piece of art. My life is like a piece of canvas, how Im going to paint it lies solely based on my decision making, said Barry, who is now a full-time artist. His mentee, Rahman, has also embarked on a journey to further pursue his calling to art after getting accepted into the Diploma in Fine Arts programme at LASALLE College of the Arts through the art portfolio that he curated during his time at VAH. Art gave me a second chance in life and I feel that through art I am able to explore my creativity. I feel really happy to be able to pursue it now, said Rahman. To hear more about both their life experiences and artists journeys, tune into RedDotAugust A Passage of Life to Art talk happening today, 19 August at 9pm on Esplanades Facebook and Esplanade Offstage ( BeyondSecondChances

Five ex-offenders, Affandi, Zulkifli, Wil, Razif and Yusoff, who used to be part of the Performing Arts Centre (PAC) will be taking the stage at 's RedDotAugust online concert. Joining them are their mentors and veteran artistes, Aaron Matthew Lim and Peng Chi Sheng, from Pte Ltd. Swipe to see what they have to say about being reacquainted with their bandmates and how music has empowered them to pay it forward. Remember to tune in on 19 August 2020, 8pm, at Esplanade Facebook and Esplanade Offstage ( to hear them perform original songs written by inmates from previous years Yellow Ribbon Songwriting Competition! BeyondSecondChances

Our mooncake orders are open for the upcoming Mid-Autumn Festival! Part of the sales proceeds from the mooncakes will go towards supporting the Yellow Ribbon Fund, which helps fund rehabilitative and aftercare programmes for ex-offenders. If you would like to order mooncakes baked by inmates, please direct message us for more details! :) BeyondSecondChances

Recently, collaborated with the Yellow Ribbon Project on their CareKitWithLove initiative. 10 women inmates from Institution A4s tailoring workshop volunteered to sew 1,400 mask pouches for beneficiaries of . I am truly grateful to be able to volunteer in sewing the mask pouches. It may be a small humble contribution, but I am contented to be able to do something for the community, while in prison, said inmate Sarah (pseudonym). Young children like Melissa and Jeremy (pseudonyms) who received the mask pouches were touched by the gesture, they said: I love the mask pouch! Thank you for sewing it! We are always thankful towards our partners who are more than willing to help offenders with their rehabilitation and reintegration journey. We hope that the mask pouches will be useful for the beneficiaries of Rainbow Centre! BeyondSecondChances CapitaLandHopeFoundation SGUnited

This afternoon, Yellow Ribbon Singapore (YRSG) and Pte Ltd signed a Memorandum of Understanding that aims to help inmates develop industry-level skills and pursue careers in the media services sector.A new media training academy will be set up in the Multi Media Hub located at Tanah Merah Centre. Accredited media courses such as the Specialist Diploma in Social Media Marketing and Online Content Creation, and the Diploma in Film and Television Production will be offered to inmates from September 2020 onwards.We hope that this fruitful collaboration will create more job opportunities for our inmates, as they embark on their rehabilitation and reintegration journey!BeyondSecondChances

The work to support our offenders still continues amidst a pandemic. With safe management measures in place, we had to adapt to a new normal in order to continue supporting our offenders who are preparing to reintegrate back into society. Before COVID-19, employers used to conduct face-to-face interview sessions with inmates. However, due to the pandemic, these interview sessions have since been conducted virtually. Mr Evan Ng, senior executive of talent acquisition at RE&S Enterprises Pte Ltd, a regional food service company, had recently participated in a virtual interview with several inmates at Changi Prison Complex. He said, "In the span of an hour, I managed to interview seven inmates virtually and I found some of them suitable for the vacancies in my company. "With the introduction of virtual interviews, it is more convenient for me to find suitable candidates for my vacant positions. I could ask them questions about themselves and gauge their reactions and responses from the video interview to ascertain suitability."If youre interested in working with us to employ ex-offenders, visit to find out more.BeyondSecondChances

In the midst of the challenges brought about by the COVID-19 situation, YRSG and our beneficiaries find ways to overcome adversities and emerge stronger together. When the Yellow Brick Road (YBR) face to face tuition programme had to be conducted online, beneficiaries such as eight-year-old Daniel (pseudonym) received sponsored tablets and SIM cards with data plan to continue their tuition online. It was a bit troublesome to adapt to the virtual sessions at first, as I didnt understand how to use the tablet, said Daniels father Haikal (pseudonym), but we eventually got used to it. The e-tuition has also proven to be beneficial to Daniel, who was lagging behind in his studies before he started his lessons. Daniel didnt know the alphabet at first, but after the lessons, he can now recite his ABCs. I can tell that Daniel enjoys his weekly e-tuition, as he is always excited to learn, said Haikal. To find out how you can support more beneficiaries like Daniel, visit SGUnited BeyondSecondChances

In these trying times, it is helpful and important to look beyond ourselves, to provide support to those who need help. During the circuit breaker period, the children in the Yellow Brick Road (YBR) programme had to transit to e-tuition with their tutor, in order to have continued support for their education. YBR beneficiaries who lacked access to digital devices and internet services were sponsored with the appropriate equipment through a Giving.sg campaign set up by the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF), which raised over $25,000. The YBR programme was developed in 2014 to reduce the detrimental effects of incarceration on families and children of inmates. To find out more about on-going YRF initiatives that support our inmates, ex-offenders and their families, visit SGUnited BeyondSecondChances

Over 100 care packs were distributed to senior citizens from Kembangan Chai Chee Senior Activity Centre (KCC SAC) on 3 July 2020. Lets hear from some of the elderlies on how they feel about receiving them!I am happy to see that the care pack has mask and hand sanitiser, which are essential items I can use during this period, said Mdm Rahamat. Another senior, Mdm Chia said, I am grateful that the care pack has reusable masks, as I can use it whenever I go out.Initiatives that engage our inmates and ex-offenders to contribute back to the community are made possible from our generous donors like Mr Philip Lim, who has been a long-time supporter of the Yellow Ribbon Project. Mr Lim said, It is indeed a pleasure to be able to contribute to the welfare of our senior citizens during this period of COVID-19. This care pack will be beneficial in helping them stay safe. Thank you Mr Lim for your support towards the Yellow Ribbon Project!BeyondSecondChances SGUnited

Despite being incarcerated for 24 years, that has not stopped ex-offender Jabez Koh from pushing boundaries and starting anew. Now, a founder and director of transport company Pte Ltd, which was founded in 2014, Jabez has conquered many personal and business challenges, and hopes to continuously pay it forward to society.From finding ways to sustain his business in the COVID-19 climate and having to ensure the job security of his 28 employees who are ex-offenders, Jabez still finds the time to contribute back to the community by volunteering his company resources to deliver 150 care packs to senior citizens from Kembangan Chai Chee Senior Activity Centre.During my incarceration, what struck me was that all the volunteers, whether it was rain or shine, they will always be there for the offenders. Hence, I told myself that one day when I am out, I too want to give back to society, said Jabez.He further added that helping others and paying it forward is something that he wants to continue doing in the long run and he encourages his own staff to do it as well.When asked what advice he would give to other ex-offenders, Jabez said, In life, we may not begin at the same starting line, but with determination and perseverance, slow and steady wins the race.BeyondSecondChances

Many have been affected by the COVID-19 situation in Singapore, including our migrant workers. In a bid to contribute back to the community, seven Selarang Halfway House (SHWH) residents volunteered to sew 600 reusable masks for the migrant workers living in dormitories. Selarang Halfway House is a secular and step-down residential facility overseen by at the Community Corrections Command (COMC). SHWH focuses on strengthening key reintegration factors such as accommodation and employment. Under Community Corrections, offenders are able to achieve a smoother reintegration, while still being under supervision and undergoing rehabilitation programmes. Mala (pseudonym), a resident in SHWH shared, "It feels great to be able to show how much we care for our nation by volunteering through the Mask for Migrants project." Mask for Migrants is an initiative by that calls for volunteers to sew 300,000 reusable masks in total for migrant workers living in dormitories. This initiative was made possible by Artelier Furnishing & Aratamete Interiors, who donated five sewing machines to SHWH as part of their non-profit initiative, Sew-Forth. Let us continue to support the offenders and ex-offenders, as they strive to contribute and give back to society in their own ways. CYC300Kmaskchallenge BeyondSecondChances SGUnited

Since his release from prison in 2005, Vijay has turned his life around and is now a proud owner of a transport company called . Founded in 2016, he now works with a dedicated team of 40 staff to run his business.Amidst his busy work schedule, Vijay believes it is important to give back to society, especially towards the marginalised and less privileged communities. Last week, Vijay and his team volunteered to deliver more than 100 care packs to our beneficiaries using his company resources. I know the struggle of trying to make ends meet, as I have travelled down that path before. I wanted to contribute as much as possible to lessen the burden of fellow Singaporeans who are bearing the brunt of this pandemic and the best way was to deliver care packs to the beneficiaries, said Vijay. Be prepared to work hard and success will eventually come your way, said Vijay when asked to give advice to other ex-offenders who are beginning to reintegrate into society. As an ex-offender himself, he hopes that others can adopt an attitude of resilience in the face of failure and not expect instant success. The journey to a successful reintegration may be a long road ahead, but through courage and perseverance, Vijay has proven that anything is possible and second chances are worth fighting for.BeyondSecondChances

Last week, Yellow Ribbon Singapore paid a visit to two beneficiaries. They shared with us on the hardships and challenges they encountered during the COVID-19 circuit breaker period.Jenny (pseudonym), lives with her parents-in-law and her two children and works in the food and beverages industry. During this pandemic, she lost her job and was extremely stressed about the loss of income. I dont want to cry in front of my children because I dont want them to worry and be heartbroken for me, said Jenny.Another beneficiary, Nurul (pseudonym), is a mother of three and the sole breadwinner of the family. Due to COVID-19, she received lesser income and struggled to make ends meet. There are some hiccups here and there. Due to the reduction in working hours, I received lesser income, but we are still able to get by, said Nurul who works in the security industry.To lighten our beneficiaries financial burden during this difficult time, we have provided support to more than 100 needy beneficiaries with care packs consisting of necessities and vouchers. You too can play a part to support the families of offenders, like Jenny and Nuruls. To find out more about the Yellow Ribbon Funds initiatives, please visit:

This Sunday we celebrate our fathers and father-figures, but not all children have that chance. Some children have their fathers incarcerated and they yearn to celebrate a special occasion like FathersDay with their Dads.As part of the 110 care packs distributed to beneficiaries of the Yellow Ribbon Fund, which comprised a set of storybooks kindly donated by , we hope that these stories will warm the hearts of the kids who receive them. We long for the day where they can reunite with their fathers and read the stories together.To all fathers out there, we wish you a HappyFathersDay!

Many Singaporeans have encountered tough times during the COVID-19 pandemic. One such group is the families and children of our offenders.To show support and care towards them, 110 care packs comprising necessities, vouchers and a set of storybooks kindly donated by , were packed by residents from Selarang Halfway House. These care packs will be delivered to beneficiaries of the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) by , a delivery company founded by an ex-offender.The care packs were made possible from generous individuals and corporates such as Baker McKenzie Wong & Leow.Ms Celeste Ang, Principal at Baker Mckenzie Wong & Leow said: "This is a tough time for everyone in Singapore, and we are all facing the same COVID-19 challenges from multiple aspects. As a long-time partner of Yellow Ribbon Singapore, we are very happy to be given the opportunity to participate in sponsoring the care packs for the beneficiaries." To find out more on how you can do your part to support the Yellow Ribbon Fund, please visit SGUnited

One such group is the families and children of our offenders.To show support and care towards them, 110 care packs comprising necessities, vouchers and a set of storybooks kindly donated by , were packed by residents from Selarang Halfway House. These care packs will be delivered to beneficiaries of the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) by , a delivery company founded by an ex-offender.The care packs were made possible from generous individuals and corporates such as Baker McKenzie Wong & Leow.Ms Celeste Ang, Principal at Baker Mckenzie Wong & Leow said: "This is a tough time for everyone in Singapore, and we are all facing the same COVID-19 challenges from multiple aspects. As a long-time partner of Yellow Ribbon Singapore, we are very happy to be given the opportunity to participate in sponsoring the care packs for the beneficiaries." To find out more on how you can do your part to support the Yellow Ribbon Fund, please visit SGUnited

Celebrating Hari Raya Aidilfitri is more than just enjoying delicious meals with our loved ones. This festive season represents new beginnings, forgiveness and second chances for many people, including ex-offenders. We may all be apart due to the social distancing measures, but we can certainly keep our community spirit alive by connecting virtually. Let us cherish every moment of this special occasion with our loved ones. Selamat HariRaya Aidilfitri to everyone!

Mothers go beyond second chances, walk with us through many mistakes, but in the end they still continue to love, support and accept us, come what may. In the spirit of celebrating our mums, let us also strive to achieve what they bring to our lives, to the society around us! Happy MothersDay!

Meet Thurston, an Operations Executive who has been working in YR Industries (YRI) Bakery for more than three years. YRI is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) that provides work programme to inmates during their incarceration. At YRI Bakery, inmates undergo on-the-job-training and certified bakery courses which equip them with skills in preparation for their release. Swipe through to take a virtual walk with Thurston at the Bakery.Thurston finds meaning in making an impact on the lives of inmate bakers. Some skills he has imparted to the incarcerated bakers are time management, communication skills and positive work ethics. These are not just key traits that a baker needs but also employability skills that are invaluable outside the prison.His day-to-day job includes training inmate bakers and briefing them on the safety procedures in the kitchen. After a few years working in the Bakery, Thurston is now able to identify each inmate bakers key strengths and interests. He then places them in the relevant departments in the Bakery. Day-to-day conversations between inmates help them learn from one another. "As much as inmates learn from me, I have also learnt a lot from them," says Thurston.Thinking back, Thurston shared that when some of the inmates were first introduced to the Bakery, they were apprehensive. They felt that baking was not their calling. It wasnt until they witnessed their finished products did they realise that their efforts had a sweet reward. This in turn inspired them to bake more and some even requested their loved ones to send them new recipes to try!What is one life lesson learnt while working at the Bakery? Thurston shared, "Never judge a book by its cover. Even though they are here to serve their term, some of them are very talented." BeyondSecondChances

The COVID-19 situation in Singapore has deeply affected the lives of many. In a bid to contribute back to the community, 10 women inmates from Changi Prison Institution A4s tailoring workshop volunteered to sew 300 reusable masks. These masks will be distributed to migrant workers living in dormitories.Amirah (not her real name), 35, an inmate volunteer shared, "Even though I am in prison and I miss my family, I feel blessed to be able to volunteer for this project to help protect those who need masks. I hope that the masks can help the recipients stay safe." These masks were sewed over 1.5 days as part of a partnership with CYC Made to Measure for their Masks for Migrants Project. If you are inspired by our inmates' effort and would like to do your part for the project, find out more !Stay tuned and continue your support for our inmates as they strive to give back to our community!CYC300Kmaskchallenge BeyondSecondChances SGUnited SingaporeTogether

Established on 1 April 1976, the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) is a statutory board under the Ministry of Home Affairs. It is the secretariat to the CARE Network, the Yellow Ribbon Project and the Yellow Ribbon Fund. SCORE plays an important role in the Singapore correctional system through the provision of rehabilitation and aftercare services to inmates and ex-offenders. Did you know that SCORE also focuses on the softer aspects of reintegration such as acceptance and raising awareness of the challenges offenders face? Together with the community, SCORE aims to inspire collective impact for a safer and more inclusive Singapore. Check out some quick facts about SCORE in the infographic above!

In these challenging times, everyone can play a part to pay it forward.To encourage and bring cheer to the COVID-19 frontliners, inmates started to bake cookies within Changi Prison Complex. Volunteers were needed to help deliver these 6,000 packets of freshly baked cookies to the many healthcare institutions around Singapore. Residents from various halfway houses The Helping Hand, Green Haven, Teen Challenge (Singapore) and HEB-Ashram Halfway House responded to this clarion call for action by stepping forward.Through this exercise, our inmates and ex-offenders have come together to show their appreciation to the 'Guardians and Angels' amongst us, in their own ways. "I feel very proud to be a part of this initiative, as I can see many frontliners who are doing good work and taking on extra duties to make sure that everything is moving in an orderly manner. I pray for their safety and thank them for their sacrifices, said Siva from The Helping Hand halfway house.We hope that our 'Guardians and Angels' will enjoy these cookies, find some warmth and comfort, and take great care of themselves during this critical period! SGUnited SingaporeTogether SG4secondchances SupportedbyToteBoard

Our inmates are preparing something special using the skills learnt inside prison to express gratitude to our guardians and angels. Our inmates stand together with Singapore in the fight against COVID-19. SGUnited SingaporeTogether SG4secondchances

This week in WhatsOnMyPlate: Char Siew Chicken Gong PoThe Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition allows inmate participants to express their appreciation and love to their family members, through the invention of unique dishes. Participants are also equipped with skills training relevant to the Food & Beverage (F&B) Industries that will enhance their employability.

Why do ex-offenders deserve a second chance? "When they are in prison, they have learnt the good ways and have repented. From the visual simulator [at Home Team Festival 2019] that I have experienced, the offenders have reflected a lot and I feel that people should give them a second chance." SG4secondchances

Participants are also equipped with skills training relevant to the Food & Beverage (F&B) Industries that will enhance their employability.
Why do ex-offenders deserve a second chance? "Everyone deserves a second chance, people often make mistakes, so it's important to learn from it." SG4secondchances

Participants are also equipped with skills training relevant to the Food & Beverage (F&B) Industries that will enhance their employability.

Why do ex-offenders deserve a second chance? "They can become a better person through community service and maybe they can pick up something new. People should accept ex-offenders, as they are trying to turn over a new leaf, and it's not right for people to shun them away from getting a job just because they committed an offense in their past." SG4secondchances

Today, as part of Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Networks 20th Anniversary celebration, President graced the occasion and watched 70 second-year students from Nanyang Polytechnics Diploma in Social Services (Social Work) create an original production called Ripples. Ripples follows four individuals hailing from various backgrounds who come together to bring about change in a community fraught with tension. The story pays tribute to the people working tirelessly behind the scene to make second chances possible the volunteers, professionals and the community.

Jaycie Tay shared with us how her volunteering journey began with the Yellow Ribbon Community Project when she was approached by another ex-offender turned volunteer, Azahari in 2018 to join the Woodlands division as a volunteer.Azahari first approached Jaycie to be a volunteer after reading about her story online. After receiving support from the Yellow Ribbon Fund STAR Bursary and positive peers along the way, Jaycie hopes to pay forward the support she has received.Now as a volunteer with the Woodlands division, Jaycie visits family members of the incarcerated to provide support and assistance to help them cope. Help does not come only in terms of food but also education and counselling. Families of the incarcerated are given attention in the form of tutors or people whom they can confide in.When asked how she overcomes difficulties in life, Jaycie added I am not so strong by nature, but my mentor touches my heart. I saw tears in her eyes when I was in a bad shape. She guided me to the right resources when I was facing difficulties in life. SG4SecondChances

"When I engage with the ex-offenders, I realize that they are actually struggling inside and they really want to turn over a new leaf, but society is not giving them that chance," said Ms Edna Tan, who has been the Yellow Ribbon Champion of Our Kebun Baru Division since 2014. As a Yellow Ribbon Champion, Ms Tan oversees the volunteers and cases within her grassroots division. She strongly believes that the community needs to come forward and actively support families of the incarcerated as they are often afraid of asking for help. "I'm happy ... even if I help just one family [because seeing] a positive change with the relationship between the ex-offender and their family ... is enough to make me feel like I've done something great," said Ms Tan. SG4secondchancesFor more information on becoming a YRCP volunteer, please visit:

As part of The Industrial & Services Co-Operative Society (ISCOS)s Give A Line, Change A Life project, 500 ex-offenders will be provided with a sponsored smart phone and mobile plan next year.This new project, which was officially launched this afternoon at Selarang Halfway House by Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Communications & Information and Ministry of Culture, Community & Youth, Ms Sim Ann (), will help newly released ex-offenders reintegrate into society, by reconnecting with their loved ones and accessing opportunities available in the digital world.

Being a mother of three young children, Aishah (not her real name) found herself facing many financial difficulties when her husband was incarcerated in July this year. As a Beneficiary of the Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) under the Woodlands Division, Aishah was able to ease her struggles with the help of the YRCP volunteers. "[The YRCP volunteers] would call me and ask, 'Kakak (meaning sister in Malay), are you okay? Is there any food at home?'," said Aishah. Her children also receive complimentary tuition and take part in activities under the Young Achievers Club, which is a Woodlands grassroots initiative. SG4secondchancesFor more information on becoming a YRCP volunteer, please visit:

This plate of fried rice may look like a staple dish to everyone, but the inmates who prepared this dish called it "My Mama's Fried Rice". It signifies their appreciation for their loved ones who have been supporting them throughout their rehabilitation journey.This dish was served in the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition 2019. WhatsOnMyPlate SG4SecondChances

"I hope ex-offenders will have the determination and keep it in mind that there are no quick paths to success. Everything must be done step by step, said Kelvin, one of the award recipients for the Yellow Ribbon Celebrating Second Chances Awards Ceremony.Being incarcerated for 13 years did not deter Kelvin from being a better person. Kelvin now works with various halfway houses, the Red Cross and government agencies and churches across China, Taiwan and Hong Kong on anti-drug movements and rehabilitation and reintegration initiatives for ex-offenders.He shares that in his spare time, he volunteers with SPS by sharing his story and participating in counselling sessions to help troubled inmates. He conducts bible studies and counselling for former drug addicts at The Helping Hand Halfway house. Kelvin feels that because of his experiences, he is better able to connect with these communities and is well-trusted by those he interacts with.SG4SecondChances

Ms Helen Shek participated in the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run for the first time this year. It was a memorable experience for her, as she was supporting second chances on behalf of her autistic brother who is an ex-offender. I think the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run is a very worthwhile cause because people make mistakes and I believe in their rehabilitation, said Ms Shek. SG4secondchances ChallengeYRself

At the Yellow Ribbon Community Project Awards and Appreciation Luncheon today, grassroots volunteers were recognised for their contributions and support towards the families of inmates and ex-offenders. The event was graced by Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance, Mr Heng Swee Keat.From its humble beginning in 2010 with 8 participating divisions, the Yellow Ribbon Community Project has now expanded to a total of 89 divisions today. In his speech, DPM Heng mentioned that, From less than 100 volunteers in 2010, there are now more than 1000 of you trained to carry out this important work. Through your combined efforts over the years, you have reached out to more than 10,000 families. You have made a difference to countless lives, so well done!Volunteers play an important role by providing care, support and encouragement to inmates, ex-offenders and their family members. Thank you to the grassroots volunteers for the work that you do it is the small acts of kindness that make a huge impact in the lives of others. SG4SecondChances
