DidYouKnow that the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run (YRPR) started 11 years ago? That is made possible all thanks to a loyal and dedicated second chances supporter like Mr KM Suresh. Mr Suresh has been participating in the YRPR ever since it started in 2008, he said: The run is something that is very close to me. Ever since I started, I make it a point to not miss it. I think it is a very good cause.. Through the years, the way the run is organised has changed drastically. Mr Suresh commended the organising committee on being able to improve the YRPR year after year. He said: I can see more participants joining the run and I can see that the organisation has improved in terms of quality of the goodie bags and official t-shirts. SG4secondchances ChallengeYRself

DSP Lawrence Lee was the Vice-Chairman of the organising committee for the biennial Yellow Ribbon Celebrating Second Chances Awards Ceremony 2019, where 134 outstanding ex-offenders were awarded for their efforts in staying crime and drug-free. "The road for offenders when they step outside of prison is really not easy, so the Celebrating Second Chances award serves as an encouragement for those ex-offenders who have made a mark in society," said DSP Lee. SG4SecondChances YRSecondChances

Khairul from Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association believes in second chances because "it is only human to make mistakes, and it is even more human to accept people who have made mistakes and to give them not just a second, but third, fourth, and as many chances as they need to turn over a new leaf." SG4SecondChances

Manmohan from Sikh Welfare Council believes in second chances because "everyone makes mistakes. Everyone deserves an equal opportunity after they have taken the wrong path. We need to let them redeem themselves and do better in life." SG4SecondChances

A Cancer survivor, a passionate educator, and a second chances supporterMr Mohamed Hilman hopes to give back to society by participating in the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run. I think we have to give people not just second chances, but third chances. We have to have faith in people, said Mr Hilman.Mr Hilman believes that society can help ex-offenders by being more open-minded. He added: Most of the problems usually surface because ex-offenders meet up with their old peers and fall back into their old ways. I think society needs to be more open and abolish the stereotypical mindsets. When ex-offenders feel like they have a sense of belonging in a certain place, then it would be easier to rehabilitate them. SG4secondchances ChallengeYRself

Amanda from Ministry of Social and Family Development believes in second chances because "theyve served their sentence in prison, and need the support that they can have in order to reintegrate back into society." SG4SecondChances

Meet Kasmawati - a Bronze Achievement Award recipient at the recent Yellow Ribbon Celebrating Second Chances Awards Ceremony. She battled with addiction and came out victorious and has now been drug-free for years. After her release, Kasmawati served as a support group facilitator and team leader at Acorn Quest Pte Ltd, a professional counselling firm. With Acorn Quest she spent time doing house visits, delivering food rations to those in need and supporting ex-addicts like herself.Today, she works as a therapist for stroke and special needs patients with health solutions firm Synphne Pte Ltd to support her family. She attributes her success to her employer and colleagues, for their relentless support when she first started on the job. Despite the difficulties she faced along the way, they never gave up on her. She stressed the importance of employment in the reintegration journey of ex-offenders.Kasmawati hopes that in time, the general public will be more accepting of ex-offenders, "With my experience in life, I hope to share my personal stories with my clients as well, to let them know that they are not alone in the reintegration journey." SG4SecondChances

Tanya from Singapore After-Care Association believes in second chances because "if we focus on reintegrating lives, we help the community greatly. It helps families as well, and strong families make strong societies." SG4SecondChances

Elwin from The Salvation Army believes in second chances because "nobody is born to do bad things, we all make mistakes. Its more important to embrace than judge people. Mistakes do not determine who we are, second chances are important." SG4SecondChances

Murugan from The Salvation Army believes in second chances because "there are a lot of gaps in society that needs to be filled up. We should give them adequate support to keep them from falling into a vicious incarceration cycle." SG4SecondChances

Peter from Prison Fellowship Singapore believes in second chances because "everybody deserves a second chance. We should give them the opportunity to turn over a new leaf and live a better life. They deserve the second chance." SG4SecondChances

Maniam from Ashram Halfway House believes in second chances because "everyone makes mistakes. I believe that we must give them the opportunity to change, so that they can show what they are capable of." SG4SecondChances

Khoon Mun from HCSA Highpoint Halfway House believes in second chances because "most of them really want to change, so we should help remove their obstacles to effectively reintegrate them into the society." SG4SecondChances
Samuel from HCSA Highpoint Halfway House believes in second chances because "they deserve it, to help upscale and uplift them to reintegrate better in the society." SG4SecondChances

Jennie from HCSA Highpoint Halfway House believes in second chances because "theyve paid for their mistakes while in prison. We should help them so that they can go back to their family and loved ones." SG4SecondChances
Toby from Singapore Children's Society believes in second chances because "if you were in their shoes, you would want the same thing too." SG4SecondChances

It's all about giving and celebrating second chances in life and in our community. This afternoon, the Yellow Ribbon Celebrating Second Chances Award Ceremony was held in recognition of the efforts of ex-offenders who have made a commitment to renew their lives, enhance their skill sets or educational levels and have kept themselves gainfully employed. 134 ex-offenders were awarded for remaining crime and drug-free for three to fifteen years, reflecting the resilience and tenacity of these individuals in reforming themselves and starting anew. Guest-of-Honour, Senior Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs & Ministry of Health, Mr , commended the award recipients, their families and volunteers. Rehabilitation and reintegration is not easy. It requires the collective effort of everyone involved." sg4secondchances

Dorothy from Serangoon Moral Family Service Centre believes in second chances because "everyone of us have made mistakes in life. Despite them being big or small, we should embrace ex-offenders and help them along in their journey in life." SG4SecondChances

Through strong family support and perseverance, Mr Mohamed Nor Bin Ismail has successfully remained crime and drug-free for the past 18 years. He is also a successful entrepreneur, having started his own wedding and catering business. Mr Mohamed is a recipient at the Yellow Ribbon Celebrating Second Chances award ceremony, which will be held this Saturday, 12th October. Mr Mohamed, who volunteers at the Jamiyah Halfway House () during his free time, credits his late mother as someone who motivated him to turn his life around. He said: "I told my late mother that one day I would make her proud of me. I'm happy and proud to be receiving an award from the Yellow Ribbon Project, as it will serve as an example to others to believe in themselves because nothing is impossible." SG4SecondChances YRSecondChances

Wen Lin from Serangoon Moral Family Service Centre believes in second chances because "we all make mistakes, and we would want people to forgive us, so we should do the same for others." SG4SecondChances

For those of you who have completed the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run 2019 and showed your support for second chances, let us reward you!All you have to do is to post any pictures that you took at the run on Facebook and Instagram, share a challenge you overcame recently, hashtag challengeyrself and you will stand a chance to win Puma vouchers.

The Kulkarni familys volunteer journey with the Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP) began in 2015 when they came across the YRP exhibition at the Home Team Festival. We were touched by the cause, and could empathise with the situation of the families, said the family of three, who volunteers to raise funds for families of the incarcerated.The Kulkarnis are quite active at YRP roadshows, prison runs, and even awareness programmes such as primary school art exhibitions featuring the creative work from children for the incarcerated. They hope that more families like them can come together to help make a difference to other less privileged families. Read more: YRSecondChances

As a curator at the Singapore Art Museum, Ms Andrea Fam, continues to be impressed by the calibre of artworks and poems created by 50 inmates from Changi Prison Complex Institution B4 and A4. Over 100 pieces of their work were displayed at the 12th Yellow Ribbon Community Art and Poetry Exhibition. Themed "Moving Forward Together", the exhibition called for greater community involvement in supporting the rehabilitation journey of inmates through sharing their artworks and poems. Ms Fam said: "I enjoy my time with the inmates and working closely with them because it's a powerful reminder of what art is and what art can do... When Im working with inmates or the Yellow Ribbon Project, its really rewarding for myself because its an opportunity for me to come up close with art." SG4secondchances

Local poet Mr Marc Nair mentored inmates from Changi Prison Complex Institution B4 and A4 in poetry writing for this year's Yellow Ribbon Community Art & Poetry Exhibition (YRCAPE). The inmates' nuanced and layered poetry left Mr Nair feeling impressed. He said: It was inspiring to go through the journey of self-discovery with the inmates, and for them to discover that they too, had talent. For some of the individuals, this was the first time that they were able to create something so meaningful to share with their family and with the public. "I was a little worried on whether I would be able to get them to write poems, but from my sessions with them, they showed a lot of interest and produced great ideas. I think they were able to translate their visual ideas to writing." SG4secondchances

In this inaugural joint exhibition between and the Yellow Ribbon Project, the public can visit from 19 - 22 September for an exhibition that reimagines a new life for the ex-offenders community. At the exhibition, the public can enjoy a Colours at Play Workshop hosted by ex-offender turned full-time artist , as well as engage in a meaningful installation called A Call for Acceptance. There will also be a Japan Pastel Art Workshop hosted by where you can take home your own creation!For more info about the exhibition visit: SG4SecondChances

We're delighted to share a secret little treat that's been baking in our ovens this past week: Finisher Cookies for all runners of this year's Yellow Ribbon Prison Run! Whipped up over the course of 6 days, these 10,000 cookies were lovingly baked by a small team of inmates, representing their desire to give back and their gratitude to all those who have run in support of SG4secondchances! We are grateful you support us and do not look down on us as prisoners, said John (not his real name) about why he is thankful for those who volunteered to run for second chances. This is also a good chance for us to show what we have learnt during incarceration, Samuel (not his real name) added.As you sink your teeth into these bite-sized treats, let's remember to support the cause of second chances for ex-offenders and acknowledge their endeavours for fresh beginnings.What are you most excited to see this Sunday? Let us know in the comments :) acceptance kindness spreadlove openness ChallengeYRSelf YRSecondChances

Weve come a long way, but we can definitely do a lot more, 60-year-old Jenap M. Said, aka our very own Catwoman, mentioned about volunteerism when it comes to Yellow Ribbon Project. After her personal experience with her neighbours incarceration and the difficulties his family faced through his sentence, she decided that she would put the cat suit to good use. By running in her cat suit, fuelled by a burning passion, she helps raise awareness to the ex-offenders need for acceptance which she has successfully done, raising a whopping $120,000 from donors in support of her cause in 2012.Her efforts are commendable, and Jenap is a definitely a meowtivation to everyone! SG4secondchancesRead more:

YELLOWRIBBONPRISONRUN BEHINDTHESCENES Did you know that this year's race entitlements are actually lovingly packed by inmates who were involved in the National Youth Achievement Award?As a way of giving back, 26 inmates volunteered to pack all the racepacks for the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run, which will take place on 15 September 2019. Taking over three days to pack close to 10,000 racepacks, the inmates volunteered to demonstrate their commitment to taking charge of their own rehabilitation journeys.More often than not, inmates are giving back to society, in their own ways, one step at a time. The society too, should accept them for their past and recognize their efforts to turn over a new leaf.ChallengeYRSelf YRSecondChances SG4secondchances

The Yellow Ribbon Community Art & Poetry Exhibition (YRCAPE) provides inmates with a platform to showcase their artistic talents and express their hopes and aspirations. This years theme, Moving Forward Together, illuminates the importance of the community supporting with inmates in their rehabilitation journey. The art pieces and poems help viewers visualise the inmates struggles, connect with their desire for a second chance and understand the support required from the larger community. A total of 100 art pieces and 23 poems were created by 31 male inmates from the Visual Arts Hub at Institution B4 and 19 women inmates from Institution A4. Join us at this years YRCAPE from 31 Aug to 8 Sep 2019 at School of the Arts, Level 2 Gallery. SG4secondchances challengeyrself

A total of 121 inmates from the Prison School and Reformative Training Centre in Institution Tanah Merah 1 participated in the 3MStepUpChallenge from 31 May to 16 June 2019, in which they clocked a total of 396 hours.The challenge encourages all Singaporeans to participate in physical activities. Additionally, for every 30 minutes of activity clocked in by each participant, 3M Singapore donated one safety and household product to elderly and families in need. The inmates' participation in the challenge, which is a joint collaboration between the Yellow Ribbon Project Singapore, and , helped the community reach the target of 9,000 hours of physical activity, which went on to benefit 3,000 beneficiaries island-wide.Rehabilitation Officer Chua Shi Qin, who is the Housing Unit Officer in-charge of the inmates, said: "During the challenge, it was encouraging to see that the inmates were motivating each other to reach the personal targets that they have set for themselves. "It was also heartening that some of them chose to use their recreation yard time for the 3M Step-up Challenge as they saw the importance of giving back to society." SG4secondchances

Better known as Captain America, Poon Zili is a familiar face to many marathoners. As an avid runner, he runs between 60 to 80km per week. Zili uses running as a method to stay in shape as well as to explore the wonderful city sights and forest trails around Singapore.When asked why he decided to take part in the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run, he added It's a run that ties in with a meaningful cause to spread the awareness of the Yellow Ribbon project and the purpose behind it. It's also great to be able to run through the prison grounds too! He recounted an experience with an ex-offender, sharing that he met an ex offender who is now a motivational speaker and felt that the experiences he shared during his school assembly talk was something that benefited both students and teachers.Zili will be joining the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run on 15th September as Captain America to spread joy to runners along the route. Don't forget to say hi if you see him! Challengeyrself

Singer-song writer Farisha Ishak uses her influence beyond music, and is an advocate of second chances. Farisha is constantly looking for opportunities to show her support for second chances. This year, she is proud to be attending the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run 2019, as a social media advocate for the Yellow Ribbon Project.So what kept her going to be a social media advocate for the Yellow Ribbon Project? I've always feel strongly for the Yellow Ribbon Project and particularly for the families of those affected by incarceration. Ultimately, the end goal is to remove any stigma that may still revolve around them and to instill a sense of acceptance among society for these ex-offenders who are only trying their best for themselves and their families. Acceptance from the community for ex-offenders will pave the way for them to better reintegrate into society and prevent them from going back to their old ways. More often than not, the first step comes from people like you and me, why not hear an ex-offender out the next time you see them on the street? You may or may not make a new friend, if not you would have at least lent them a listening ear.Last but not least, we asked Farisha about her favourite running quote and she added: "It's all in the mind. If you believe you can do it, nothing can stop you!" Challengeyrself

The Prison Fellowship Singapore (PFS) has been supporting and positively influencing inmates and ex-offenders by offering incare and aftercare services since 1953. Mr Andrew Tay, the Executive Director of PFS said: Our objective is to form a new community for each ex-offender that we are following up [with] because when they are stressed out, its very easy for them to go back to their old community. So what we believe in is to build a village around each ex-offender to follow them and to journey with them." In-care services includes Christian counselling, while aftercare services includes having PFS volunteers guide the inmate upon their release from prisons, as well as assisting them in finding a suitable church community. This strong community support is just one of the many components that help ease the rehabilitation and reintegration journeys of inmates and ex-offenders. SG4SecondChances

Being a mother of two does not stop Jenny Huang from being an avid runner as she takes part in at least 12 races per year.Participating in races enables Jenny to push herself beyond her physical and mental barriers. Incorporating fitness into her lifestyle, Jenny runs for 60-90 min and does a TRX workout six days a week. Having participated in the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run for several years, Jenny is a strong advocate of second chances and believes that everyone deserves the opportunity to be a better person and not be judged for mistakes that has shaped them.So how does running challenge her? Jenny added: Every day is a fresh start. You analyse the body to see if it's ready to run, feel how each step brings you closer to a runner's high, and to mentally keep your focus and goal of finishing the distance you've set for yourself for that day. ChallengeYRSelf YRSecondChances
From all of us at the Yellow Ribbon Project, Selamat Hari Raya Haji!

Known to many as an iconic figure in the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run, Shariff Abdullah, better known as Singapore's Blade Runner, was born without a left foot. Undaunted, it did not deter him from making the most out of his life. He took up running to challenge himself and has participated in the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run since 2011.We asked him about his motivation behind being a social media advocate for the run. Shariff emphasised on the need for society to give ex-offenders a second chance. He added that ex-offenders deserve second chances and opening the door of opportunities will give them the courage to live in the good society. So how does the run challenge him? Shariff added: The challenging run route pushes me to conquer myself, my fears and my dreams. Once you push yourself, you will notice that the possibilities are endless. challengeyrself SG4SecondChances
From all of us at the Yellow Ribbon Project, Happy 54th birthday Singapore! challengeyrself

This morning, President Halimah Yacob visited Changi Prison Complex to gain a first-hand understanding of Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) rehabilitation and aftercare services for inmates. During the visit, President Halimah toured the Hope Cafe, a training kitchen where inmates undergo hands-on vocational training modules under the Singapore Workforce Skills Qualifications framework. Trainings such as these are important because it raises hiring confidence among prospective employers from the F&B and Hospitality Industry.President Halimah was also present to see how SCORE facilitates job placement exercises for inmates two weeks prior to their release. Upon their release, Job Coaches will be assigned to ex-offenders for up to 12 months after their release, providing support and assistance as needed. Through these programmes, SCORE adopts a multi-faceted approach to rehabilitation and reintegration focusing on training and employment assistance so as to help ex-offenders enhance their employability potential. SG4SecondChances challengeyrself

As we run for second chances, let us not forget the many offenders still behind the wall. To many of them, this wall is made up of not just bricks and stone, but also fears, worries and anxieties. And yet, like all of us, they too have many hopes, dreams and aspirations.Today, more than 100 of them have shared their hopes and aspirations with you, through these letters. If you would like to help them break down the walls they face, send in your replies now. Reply them here: YRSecondChances SG4SecondChances challengeyrself

Meet Pris Chew, a fitness blogger who has been running for the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run since 2012. The desire to advocate for second chances was her push factor to participate in the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run for seven years continuously. Her chance encounter with ex-offenders who shared their personal stories at the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run further kept her going to be a Social Media Advocate for the Yellow Ribbon Project. When asked why she supports YRSecondChances, Pris added: It is important to forgive and forget and give second chances. It is only human to make mistakes, and I strongly feel that people should not be stigmatised for mistakes that they may have made in the past. SG4secondchances ChallengeYRself

On 26 July 2019, the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) and the Singapore Precision Engineering and Technology Association (SPETA) signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to enhance the employability potential of ex-offenders in the Precision Engineering Industry.CEO SCORE Mr Matthew Wee and Deputy Chairman SPETA Mr Philip Kia signed the MOU in the presence of Mrs Josephine Teo, Minister for Manpower and Second Minister for Home Affairs.With the new training academy in Changi Prison Complex, inmates will be equipped with skills and technical trainings which will help them excel in the Precision Engineering industry. Upon their release, SCORE will work closely with SPETA member companies to facilitate job placement opportunities for these ex-offenders. Through this collaboration, SPETA member companies are not only able to meet manpower requirements, they will also be able to support the cause of second chances for ex-offenders in the community.SG4secondchances

James (not his real name) used to be an ex-secret society member who started consuming drugs at the age of 16. "When I go inside prison, the most affected people were my families, especially my son [who] came to ask me, Dad, when are you going to come out?," said James. Now, at 46, James has turned over a new leaf and works at a logistic company as a supervisor. During his time in prison, James attended the "Manalive" programme, which helped him overcome his violent tendencies. Today, he is a dedicated volunteer with Industrial & Services Co-operative Society Ltd (ISCOS) and currently visits Changi Prison twice a month to share his story with other inmates so as to inspire and help them with their rehabilitation journey.Kudos to James for being an inspiration to others SG4SecondChances

I think the outside world can accept ex-offenders, Ms Ramona Binte Rahman, who is employed under Career Trial, talks about how her employers and colleagues have been very welcoming. My managers and team leaders never looked down on me. She has been offered a permanent job after 240 hours of trial, fuelling Ms Ramona's hope for a better life for herself and her three children. SG4SecondChances
Be an early bird, come catch the worm. Join us in giving others a second chance at life. SG4SecondChances challengeyrself

The Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network first started in 2000 with a goal of working with community partners to improve the rehabilitative and reintegrative efforts for ex-offenders.Ms Shanthi Pandian, Director of CARE Network Office, Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE), said: "There are a lot of challenges that the ex-offenders faces once they are released from prison and back into society. There is a need to ensure that the transition is eased and there is enough scaffolding and support from the community to help the ex-offender reintegrate successfully and help him start his life again." SG4SecondChances

After managing to escape the gallows, Azahari served his final 20 years in prison since he was 20 years old and was released in 2014. He had been in and out of prison since a young age of 16 for a total of 4 times, and said I grew up in prison, it was my kind of environment. However, nearing his release date, he reflected on all the years he wasted during his incarcerations, which led him to join prison school. After taking his O levels, he was motivated, I thought to myself, "Hey, I can do this! and did well for his A levels.After he was released, he was supported by the Yellow Ribbon Fund STAR Bursary for his Diploma in Chemical Engineering at Singapore Polytechnic, and graduated in September 2018, defying odds and continuing to strive for excellence. SG4SecondChances

In partnership with the Yellow Ribbon Project (YRP), the Singapore Chefs Association (SCA) equips basic culinary skillsets for inmates to prepare them for life after prison. Mr Elvin Chew, a committee member for the SCA, has contributed 7 years on this partnership between the two organisations. He helps to mentor ex-offenders by imparting his own culinary skills to them. He also participates in Dining Behind Bars (DBB), giving career talks, and even initiating culinary competitions among inmates. When they are attached to me, I do not see them as an ex-offender in the way I treat them, but I also go the extra mile to guide them so they are able to get back up on their feet and work towards reintegrating into society, says Mr Chew.SG4secondchancesRead more:

In partnership with the Singapore Chefs' Association, the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition took place this afternoon in Changi Prison, eight years since the last competition in 2011.The event was graced by guest-of-honour, Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Trade and Industry & Ministry of Education, Mr Chee Hong Tat said "In partnership with The Singapore Chef Association, the Yellow Ribbon Culinary Competition aims to equip offenders with skills relevant to the Food & Beverage Industry to enhance their employability after their release. Through this event, we hope to generate greater awareness for second chances." The top 3 finalist teams of inmates worked in pairs to cook the ultimate dish based on the theme of "My Family's Recipe". Unknown to them, their family members were invited in secret to witness their cooking through a live feed. As a form of appreciation to their families, participants served their dishes personally to their family members, strengthening the bond with their family through a shared love of food. SG4SecondChances

On 27 June 2019, a small auditorium in Changi Prison Complex was bustling with activity for the Yellow Ribbon Song Writing Competition. As part of a collaboration between the Yellow Ribbon Project and Composers and Authors Society of Singapore (COMPASS), the song writing course saw industry names who worked with inmates participants to express their heartfelt feelings to their loved ones through self-composed songs.Based on the theme Stronger Together', the final project of the course required participants to compose songs and lyrics in line with the theme, with three contestants bagging the top prizes.Other than allowing the inmates to draw themselves closer to their loved ones, these song writing competitions also allow inmates to reignite their passion for music through exposure to influential musicians in the industry who can serve as huge motivational forces, easing the way for them on their respective rehabilitation journeys.SG4SecondChances

The Community Action for the Rehabilitation of Ex-offenders (CARE) Network and over 100 community partners held its seventh seminar at Fairmont Singapore. Themed Transformation: The Future of Aftercare, the seminar served as a platform for community partners to have a dialogue on how to further strengthen aftercare support for inmates and ex-offenders. Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law, Mr K Shanmugam Sc who was the Guest-of-Honour for the seminar, highlighted that the two-year recidivism rate has improved from about 44% from 20 years ago, when CARE Network was first formed, to 23.7% today for the 2016 released cohort. It is important that ex-offenders are provided with proper aftercare support from the community partners to ensure a successful rehabilitation journey. SG4SecondChances

This industry isn't easy and we've always found it difficult to find people who are suited to this type of work. We're really happy that the Career Trial offers us a new pool of candidates that we can consider and assess their suitability for. Furthermore, we should give those who are sincere in changing a second chance. , said Mr Chia Tze Yong, the Director of Wingstop Singapore when asked about why he hires ex-offenders. SG4SecondChances

Over 100 inmate participants from Clusters A and B took to the stage to present their self-composed songs to a panel of three judges from Composers and Authors Society of Singapore (COMPASS) for the Yellow Ribbon Songwriting Competition 2019. Stronger Together is the theme of this year's competition, and a common thread running through the songs was the significance of being supported by loved ones during challenging times.After much deliberation, 60 participants were selected to proceed to the next phase of the competition. They will be embarking on several weeks of training under the tutelage of accomplished singer-songwriters Nicodemus, Azmi, and Ang Zhi Hui, in preparation for the finals on 27 June 2019.

A fathers newborn, his biggest regret He gently embraced his child with his heavily tattooed armsHe thought about the endless nights he dreamt about holding his childHis perpetually troubled face dissolved into a smileHe took one long last gaze before he was called back to his cellNot everyone is able to celebrate fathers day, if you have the chance to do so, please appreciate your father. Happy Fathers Day.SG4secondchances

Since June 2018, residents at the Ashram and Green Haven Halfway House were treated to mindfulness training classes that helps to reduce anxiety and restores residents' self-confidence. These classes also help them to better pay attention to their own bodies and further prevent negativity and depression. With over 800 training hours involved, it is only from community support from our partners such as the Ashram and Green Haven Halfway House that we can help ex-offenders reintegrate into society. SG4secondchances

One of the things we need to do is respond to need, said Charlotte Yew, a dedicated committee member of the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) board.She started volunteering with the Prison Fellowship Singapore in 2009, before she got involved with YRF in 2013. Charlotte highlights the importance of helping ex-offenders reintegrate into society, Some of them even wish they could go back to the safety of the regularity (in prison), its that terrifying." SG4SecondChances

We want to help so that they can get back into the community. The most meaningful work is giving people a second chance. In life, you will trip. Nothing is perfect, and nobody has a smooth-sailing life all the time, said Mr Mak Lye Mun, CEO of and a Yellow Ribbon Fund Corporate Donor, on why he believes in the importance of second chances. SG4SecondChances

From all of us at the Yellow Ribbon Project, Selamat Hari Raya Aidilfitri! Take this time to seek forgiveness and cherish every moment of this special occasion with your loved ones.Psst, tell us whats your favourite raya kueh in the comments below.

Even with a job, ex-offenders may face challenges in transiting from the prisons to employment back in society. The Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises provides Job Retention support by assigning a Job Coach to each ex-offender for up to 12 months after their release. Mr Paul Teng, Assistant Director of Retention Support, Reintegration Division, SCORE, added that job coaches act as an important bridge to help both the ex-offenders and employers understand each others expectations, difficulties and perspectives. Job Coaches engage ex-offenders at their workplace regularly to provide support and set goals with them. This helps them to cope with the demands from the new job and work environment. If ex-offenders have any work related issues, the job coaches will work closely with employers and supervisors to help the ex-offenders resolve it. With stable employment and strong support network, the ex-offender is better able to reintegrate back into society and lead crime free lives. SG4secondchances

When asked why he hires ex-offenders, Mr Chia, Spokesperson for Abaavo Group Pte Ltd added , They are often genuine people who want to change and want to learn, so why not? We teach our kids to not discriminate, so be it whether its race, economic status, or whether you have past records. Thats what we are trying to inculcate even at Wingstop itself. After they pass the work trial, they are just like a regular full-timer. The only difference is they have a job coach to guide them along the way. Other than that, they are no different than any other regular employee and are treated equally. It all boils down to the performance and their attitude towards the job. Mr Chia shared that with the six-month pilot Career Trial (CT) programme, employers will get an avenue to access the ex-offenders suitability for the job before offering them a permanent employment.Ex-offenders are also offered on the Job Training (OJT) to ensure that they have the correct skillset for their job. This programme helps to strengthen employment outcomes through a short-term work stint with employers, and help ex-offenders navigate challenges after a long period of displacement from work.Once the employability of an ex-offender is enhanced, they will have an easier time reintegrating into society. SG4secondchances

An ex-offender reintegration journey is never easy, even when they are finally offered employment by companies who believes in the gift of second chances. This is when the six-month pilot Career Trial (CT) programme comes into place. The CT programme helps ex-offenders to experience employment outcomes through a short-term work stint with participating companies.Ramona, who is currently undergoing the CT programme with Wingstop Singapore, added, My job coach has been of great help. My manager and my team leader understand that I have three kids at home, and theyve given me a good opening, and allow me to go home earlier. Whenever an ex-offender faces challenges in transitioning from the prison to employment in society, there will always be a job coach there to guide them and ensure them that they are not alone in their rehabilitation journey. SG4secondchances

This is a picture of an inmate holding hands with his elderly mother during an open visit. His mother visits him diligently, even though her memory is failing. Shes getting older and starting to forget who I am. Its only through touch that she can remember me. Im scared shell forget who I am someday, he explains.This heartfelt moment serves as a reminder to us of a mothers love and sacrifice over all else. Lets cherish our mothers on this special day. YRConfessions SG4SecondChances

"Initially, I did not believe in rehabilitation programmes. After some time, I found meaning in the phrase "Rehab, Renew and Restart". I learnt how to differentiate what is wrong and what is right, what I should do and what I should not. The counselling sessions and family programmes enabled me to fill up my time and set my mind thinking on what I want to achieve in life," - AndyYRConfessions

"When I feel the urge to consume drugs, I will call my wife. Once she is beside me, I will restrain myself from taking drugs", Danial, ex-offender. Family support actually plays an important role in the rehabilitation journey of an ex-offender. They are the ones the ex-offenders turn to when they have difficulty reintegrating into society. yrconfessions

[Love And Second Chances] When Alvin Chiong was 15, he worked as a plumber to earn some pocket money. While repairing broken pipes and fixing clogged toilets, a girl named Mei caught his eye, however he was too shy to approach her. He spent the next few months calling 50 different telephone numbers written across his trousers to look for Mei, which he eventually found after much difficulty, and started courting her. After 10 years of dating, they got married in 1997.However things soured in 2007 when Mei caught him red-handed consuming drugs at home. That was when she decided to take their sons and leave him for good. In 2008, with the intention of starting anew, he checked himself into a halfway house. It was only during his third stint in that halfway house that he turned over a new leaf. During the three years at the halfway house, he found religion, companionship and eventually went on to become an employee at the halfway house. By 2014, he felt empowered enough to leave the halfway house and devoted his Saturdays with Mei and his boys. His Sundays were reserved for church and volunteering with the Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association, where Alvin conducts faith-based counselling programmes in prison.As time went on, Alvin and Mei realized that their feelings for each other had never faded. Alvin proposed to Mei again in 2016, and they remarried within the same year. Here at the Yellow Ribbon Project, we couldn't be happier to celebrate stories of SecondChances. Congratulations to Alvin and Mei and thank you for sharing your love story with us! SG4SecondChances valentinesday2019

Here at the Yellow Ribbon Project, we strongly believe ex-offenders need a second chance from the community so that they can better reintegrate into society. At times, we may need a little help in cajoling our crushes, dates and loved ones to give us another chance.So we came up with a V'day card for you to tag your crush and (hopefully) score a date tonight, don't say we never share hor. SG4secondchances valentinesday2019

"I feel more confident after I attended the rehabilitation programmes as now I know what to expect when I reintegrate into society. Also, I feel that the desire to change starts within ourselves, we must believe in ourselves before others believe in us." YRConfessions
May the Lunar New Year bring prosperity, health and opportunities to you and your loved ones! Happy Lunar New Year from all of us at the Yellow Ribbon Project!

Ten years ago, Augustine Jadyn Ng used to destroy his body with drugs and went on the wrong path. He was then sentenced to the Reformative Training Centre where he did two stints that spanned for about 4.5 years. However, this did not deter him from completing his education through the Yellow Ribbon Star Bursary and landing himself a marketing role in a law firm. Making it a point to thank everyone who helped him, Jadyn paid it forward by volunteering for the Yellow Ribbon Community Project and helping those who were in a similar position. This year, he was accepted in the Singapore University of Social Sciences for the Law programme and hopes to become a lawyer in the future. 10yearchallenge YRconfessions glowup

"Why do you think ex-offenders deserve secondchances?""Giving them a second chance is equivalent to giving them a new lease of life. They need to step out of their old life and reintegrate into society again. They deserve this chance no matter what their past is so that they can keep moving forward in life." SG4SecondChances
From all of us at the Yellow Ribbon Project, We wish you a Merry Christmas! May your Christmas sparkle with moments of love, laughter and goodwill.

A new Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) initiative was launched on Saturday where over 400 school-going children of offenders received Back to School packs worth $50. These packs comprise a school bag, vouchers and stationery. A personalised letter written by the incarcerated parent will also be included in the pack to provide encouragement and to foster stronger parent-child bonds. The school bags are sponsored by the Yellow Ribbon Fund.Guest-of-Honour Mr Amrin Amin, Senior Parliamentary Secretary at the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Ministry of Health, unveiled the new initiative and together with Mrs Josephine Teo , 2nd Minister for Home Affairs and Advisor to Bishan North Grassroots Organisations, distributed the packs to beneficiaries present at the event. Following the launch, grassroots volunteers will begin distributing these packs to families of the offenders in their respective constituencies. This initiative will act as an added touchpoint for YRCP volunteers to engage and connect with the children, alleviate the financial burden on the family and prepare the children for the new school year. SG4SecondChances

As we sat down with John Tung, Curator at the Singapore Art Museum, his passion for art and for helping inmates find their way back into society shone through.Speaking earnestly, John shared that he wanted to help to break stereotypes about inmates. "Art helps them to build their creativity and is very self-empowering. They (inmates) come in for the programme, and most of the time, they leave as proficient artists which really boosts their confidence in life." When asked about the theme for this year's exhibition, he shared how it helped to frame them (inmates) in an open manner - a father, husband and/or brother. The team involved the participants and asked them questions like "what are you interested in pursuing" and "what do you want to address this year", of which, the keywords were then condensed into the theme.In keeping with the theme, a new programme, Art History was included to help participants understand the types of art they were creating. Summing it up nicely, John added: "art for them is a form of catharsis and it also a platform to help showcase change and reinstall their family's confidence in them". SG4SecondChances

Artist mentor and Nanyang Academy of Fine Art lecturer Edwin Ho, was one of the artist mentors for the recent Yellow Ribbon Project Community Art Exhibition (YRCAE) which took place at Raffles City Shopping Centre recently.We spoke with Edwin about his personal interactions with the inmate artists and why he thinks helping inmates and ex-offenders are worth it. Having worked with inmates for the past eight years, he only had praise to share. "I have personally seen four inmates change their lives, I have seen them renounce their old habits and vow to change." Sharing more about his role as an artist mentor, he takes it upon himself to walk with, lead and guide them on the path to rehabilitation through art. One thing he laments that, "whenever I meet the new artists, the thing they lack most is confidence". Edwin also described how the inmate artists gain confidence when their works are displayed at such events like the YRCAE, knowing that distinguished guest view their works.His advice to artist mentors? "Be passionate and walk with them (inmates)". Listen and understand where they come from and help them to express themselves through art. SG4SecondChances

Ahmad was struggling with two jobs to support his six children. When Ahmad was first sentenced, his biggest worry was his six children that he was leaving behind. But all his worries were lifted when he was selected for the Development and Reintegration Programme (DRP). The programme, run jointly by the Singapore Prison Service (SPS) and the Association of Muslim Professionals (AMP), provides support for Malay-Muslim offenders and their families, from the in-care stage when the offender is first incarcerated, to a period of up to 12 months after the offenders release. In-care support includes offenders undergoing the Personal Development Programme, a 10-session programme focusing on the socio-educational development of Malay-Muslim offenders, with a religious element. After-care support includes providing casework services to the family of these offenders, with the intent of enabling their families to become self-reliant.While he was incarcerated, one of Ahmad's constant worries was his children. To facilitate his reintegration, case worker from AMP enrolled his children into student care and then collaborated with Social Service Office and SPS to ensure he had employment upon release. They also facilitated financial assistance for his parents and arranged for religious classes for him to attend when he came out. By leveraging on various agencies to come together and provide holistic support, this enables Ahmad to focus on his rehabilitation and reintegration journey upon his release. "I am thankful to be in this programme as they rendered support so that the needs of my family are taken care of," Ahmad said. Through the assistance given by the DRP, Ahmad was then able to find his footing and turn his life around. He is now better able to cope and ensure that the needs of his children are met. YRConfessions

The idea to offer inmates a chance to study for a diploma in Prison School sprouted from a learning journey to Prison School. The lecturers from Ngee Ann Polytechnic (NP) were touched by the inmates determination to study and decided to launch the Diploma in Business Practice (International Supply Chain Management) course in Prison School.However, things were not easy for the inmate students as they have a different learning environment compared to the other students out there. The inmate students would seek opportunities to clarify their doubts in class as they do not have access to electronic devices after their lesson. They cherish the lesson time as they do not have access to tuition nor peer learning., Mr Wong Yew Fei, lecturer at Ngee Ann Polytechnic and at Prison School.Inmates who have successfully enrolled in the Diploma course will remain registered as NP students after their release. Students who require financial assistance to continue the course after their release can approach Yellow Ribbon Fund or Singapore Aftercare Association.SG4SecondChances
Happy Deepavali to all our Hindu friends!.May the Festival of Lights brighten up your day with happiness and prosperity..We hope you guys are happily snacking on Murruku because we are!

Daniel* first discovered his talent for art in school. Released earlier this year after four years in prison, Daniel shared how Yellow Ribbon Community Art Exhibition programme helped him regain his confidence and belief in himself..Daniel opened up about how he found art as a medium to share his thoughts and feelings he normally had issues with, to everyone. "I'm actually a very reserved guy, I don't open up easily," he said with a laugh. He also reflected that the programme and artist-mentors at the Visual Arts Hub helped him to find the confidence in expressing himself to his friends and family..Not only helping him personally, art has opened new doors for him. This newfound passion has opened new doors at home too. When he paints, his son sits close by to watch and has even expressed interest in painting too. Not only does art provide a second chance in many ways, it also empowers newly-released ex-offenders to focus on the positive instead of negative. Keep up the good work Daniel, we are proud of you!.YRConfessions MotivationalMonday.*Names have been changed to protect identities.

After his release from the Drug Rehabilitation Centre, Adam struggled to restart his life. How he turned his life around was with the loving support of his family. "My family is like my mirror. They cry with me and they laugh with me," Adam shared. He credits his rehabilitation to his family for walking with him and spoke about how his sister went the extra mile to get him a new phone and got him to discard all of his old contacts.Through the support and assistance rendered by Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) volunteers, Adam was then able to find his footing and turn his life around. He decided to give back to society by becoming a YRCP volunteer himself since "if they (public) can give me a chance, why not i support them (ex-offenders) as well?" One memorable case he remembered was when he helped a mother and two children while the father was in prison. As a father of two kids himself, he felt the need to help them. Now, he shares that he still visits the family every two weeks to check in on how they are doing. When asked why such volunteers are important, Adam shared that family and community support is key to reaching out to ex-offenders. He also shared that when he sometimes reveals his background to the families he helps, they are very surprised and ask how did he do it, he simply replies, "with the support of volunteers, friends and family." YRConfessions SG4SecondChances

Grassroots leader, previous Chairman of Tampines-Changkat Division and a Yellow Ribbon Champion. Suzana Ahmad, shared with us how her volunteering journey began with the Yellow Ribbon Project - a visit to Changi Prison five years ago which sparked her desire to help families affected by incarceration. Now as a Yellow Ribbon Champion, Suzana coordinates and manages the volunteers within her grassroots division. Having been a volunteer with the Yellow Ribbon Community Project for the past five years, Suzana has a selfless heart for reaching out to the loved ones of the incarcerated and providing support and assistance to help them cope. Tears flow as she recounts particular cases which have made lasting impressions. One of her first cases was when she organised Iftar (an evening meal Muslims end their daily Ramadan fast at sunset) for a family who had been coping with the husband's incarceration for the past 14 years. Help does not come only in terms of food but also education and counselling. Both spouses and children, who have been emotionally affected by the parent's incarceration, are given attention in the form of tutors or people whom they can confide in. "(The) Yellow Ribbon Community Project is a bridge to reach out to the beneficiaries. There are a lot of people out there who need help and this project helps to open that door to helping them." Having many volunteers ready to help is a huge step in helping ex-offenders re-integrate back into society. SG4SecondChances

During the Yellow Ribbon Conference (YRC) held last month, we sat down with Deputy Chief Executive of the Society of Rehabilitation and Crime Prevention, Hong Kong, Anthea Lee for a quick chat. First held in 2005, the aim of the conference was to provide professionals with a platform to share best practices and discuss the rehabilitation, and reintegration of inmates and ex-offenders. Anthea, who is also the General Manager of Bright Services Company Limited (BSC), manages a social enterprise under the Society of Rehabilitation And Crime Prevention, which includes maintenance services, as well as a central kitchen and restaurant. Speaking with Anthea quickly broadened our perspectives on helping ex-offenders internationally. She compared the situation in Hong Kong to one not much different than the one we have in Singapore. Describing that community support was key, she highlighted that community and family support were paramount in re-integrating ex-offenders. Having been to Japan, China and Taiwan, Anthea shared that these countries are aware and very supportive of the cause we work for! Let's keep up the good work with our international and national partners in the spirit of promoting a more accepting society!MotivationalMonday SG4SecondChances

Ole Hessel, Director of High:five, has a goal of cooperating with relevant parties in order to establish sustainable solutions that create value for at-risk young people, private businesses, and the public sector. Having worked as a police officer from 1981 to 2006, he became Director of High:five, a newly established organisation tasked to create jobs for former offenders. Today, besides job creation, the 22-member strong High:five advocates for and drives public-private cooperation that prepares prisoners and ex-offenders for jobs. "Motivation is the key thing here. Everybody dreams of a good life. If people are sitting in prisons thinking "It's impossible for me to get a good life" then they wont dream of getting out... [I was] invited as a speaker to inspire Singapore but [I] find we are the ones being inspired." sg4secondchances

"Why do you think ex-offenders deserve a Second Chance?" "I hope that the community could take that tiny leap of faith and give ex-offenders a new lease of hope. I feel that community support is important, as when ex-offenders feel that everyone is supporting them, giving them a chance to press the restart button in their life, they will definitely turn over a new leaf and make their lives count. I can, so can you!" SG4SecondChances

At the recent Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) Appreciation Awards ceremony, ABR Holdings Limited received the Spark of Hope award for their special contribution towards SCOREs mission in reintegrating and rehabilitating ex-offenders. Employed under ABR Holdings, Mr Mohammad Khairool Bin Ramlee, ex-offender and now part of the Service Crew at Swensens, shared passionately his plans to always do better and how he is doing his best with his second chance. Khairool shared, I was afraid that my colleagues would not accept me, for who I am, where I came from, but so far they are very good to me. They made me feel welcomed. Through his work ethic and supportive colleagues and bosses, Khairool performed well in his job and was promoted to a supervisor as of 1 July 2018.Well done Khairool and thank you for inspiring us all!SG4SecondChances

At the recent Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) Appreciation Awards ceremony, ABR Holdings Limited received the Spark of Hope award for their special contribution towards SCOREs mission in reintegrating and rehabilitating ex-offenders.Helping ex-offenders realise their potential is Mr Benny Ng, General Manager, Operations, ABR Holdings Limited. Since 2010, Swensens has provided 40 to 50 ex-offenders the opportunity to grow a career in the F&B industry,he said. My advice to the other companies is to be open-minded about giving these ex-offenders an opportunity to work in their companies, but of course it requires encouragement from their colleagues and co-workers in the workplace. SG4SecondChances

When asked about Mr N Chandramohans reputation, Mr Abdul Aziz replied with a laugh, At first, arrogant ah, stern also. But this is what I heard from my colleagues. Now, thats not the case, hes one of my good friends, BFF lah. During the recent Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) Appreciation Awards ceremony, Mr Chandramohan received the Model Supervisor Award. To be considered eligible, supervisors have to be nominated by ex-offenders under their charge. This award recognises supervisors for going the extra mile in coaching and supporting ex-offenders. Aziz, who nominated Mr Chandra, appreciated his supervisor for being ready to lend a helping hand whenever he faced problems. My boss is very kind-hearted and willing to listen. He encourages me to do a good job and I am very happy to work for him. We would like to wish Mr Abdul Aziz Md Sani and Mr N. Chandramohan the very best as they continue on their respective paths!SG4SecondChances

"Why do you think ex-offenders deserve a second chance?" "Actually, you shouldn't say second chances. You should say, they need chances. They need all the chances they can get and they need all the help they can get from any organisation or community. Just remind yourself that you're (ex-offenders) in this life for a reason. Everyone is special in their own way so find the special reason you are here for and make a difference in your life." SG4SecondChances MotivationalMonday

Transitions: Crossroads & Choices - the theme for the 11th Yellow Ribbon Community Art Exhibition (YR CAE), was launched today by President Halimah Yacob at the Raffles City Shopping Centre. For the first time, a special exhibition featuring illustrations by children of inmates will also be on display. Titled The Invisible Victims of Incarceration, the exhibition includes drawings that show the hopes and aspirations of children under the CapitaLand-YRF Children Support Programme..This years exhibition showcased mixed medium artworks that were created by inmates, reflecting the challenges and transitions experienced in their own rehabilitation journey. In addition, members of the public can support the Yellow Ribbon cause by adopting the art pieces at the exhibition. Proceeds from the adoption will go towards the Yellow Ribbon Fund, which supports a variety of rehabilitation and reintegration programmes and services for inmates, ex-offenders, and their families..If youll be in the area from the 22nd to 30th September, come on down to see these wonderful art pieces! Check out our event page for more info. SG4SecondChances

"Why do you think ex-offenders deserve a second chance?" "I think the label of 'ex-offender' is very telling, it sets them apart from everyone else. At the end of the day, we're all humans. If we are able to make mistakes and rectify them, why not [ex-offenders] as well?" SG4SecondChances MotivationalMonday

Close to 400 Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) volunteers across various grassroots divisions were recognised for their contribution and support towards the families of inmates and ex-offenders at the seventh Yellow Ribbon Community Project Awards and Appreciation Luncheon today. The event was graced by Guest-of-Honour Mr K Shanmugam, Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Law.In his speech, Minister Shanmugam noted that of the 9000 offenders entering into prison, more than 80% have drug antecedents. He also regarded that while the Singapore Prison Service is committed to the rehabilitation of offenders under their custody, community involvement is critical in supporting the families who are affected by the incarceration of a loved one. Minister Shanmugam also announced the launch of a new YRCP initiative, where approximately 900 booster packs will be distributed to the families of offenders to provide further support, as well as to create an additional touchpoint to strengthen bonds between these families and grassroots volunteers. Kudos to the grassroots volunteers for the work that they do it is small acts of kindness that transform the world. SG4SecondChances

IMPORTANT ANNOUNCEMENT:.Hi everyone,.We cannot rule out the likelihood of inclement weather during the run. Depending on the situation, the flag off timings could be delayed or in a worst case scenario, all categories could be cancelled..However, please note that our end-point carnival at Changi Prison Complex will continue regardless of the weather..We understand your concerns and will:1. publish an update on social media at 6.30AMAND2. send out a mass SMS to registered runners..We really hope the weather favours us tomorrow and that we get to see all of you! Fingers crossed the morning brings us sunny skies and happy smiles! 10YRsAndRunning .Cheers,Yellow Ribbon Prison Run Organising Committee

Meet our social media advocate, Jasmine Neo who has been active in gymnastics and cheerleading since she was young. During 2016, she took up running as a form of therapy to clear her mind when shes stressed.She emphasises the importance of having a running support group as everyone can be a pillar of support to each other and they are able to conquer new races together as a team. Running has also been a sports for her to bond with the people around her as she gets her family members and her friends to join her in races. Jasmine also shared her running tips for first time participants of the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run. Dont think about how long it would take you to complete the run. Just enjoy running with the people around you. Dont forget to warm up and cool down after the race. On why ex-offenders deserve a second chance, Jasmine shared that Everyone deserves a second chance. We should not be condemned just because we made a mistake. We must provide support for one another to re start a new journey! This will be her first time taking part in the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run so do say Hi if you manage to run past her on 9th September 2018. SG4SecondChances 10YRsAndRunning
Here's wishing all our Muslim friends Selamat Hari Raya Haji!

We must be there and support them, support must come from the willingness of our hearts," says Hanniel Choong, former-offender-turned-marathoner. Hanniel, 57, is no stranger to running for the Yellow Ribbon Project..Back in 2009, Choong and a contingent of 80 ex-offenders participated in a run called - Beyond the Run. Their message was for all ex-offenders to pick themselves up after having fallen down. Choong challenged himself to finish the 10 km race in 48 minutes - a personal best. His effort raised S$35,000 in donations for the Yellow Ribbon Fund..His first step down the wrong path came in 1976 when he was just 15. Caught in 1977, he was sent to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre. Since then, he was incarcerated two more times and had been in and out of prison for almost 20 years on drug-related charges. Finding his turning point in prison after his final release in 1996, he joined The Helping Hand as a full-time staff..When questioned why he keeps running for second chances, Choong shared that he has seen the positive effects of creating greater awareness for the reintegration of ex-offenders. He described a time without the Yellow Ribbon Project when he was just released, to present day when over 5,000 employers registered with SCORE and hiring ex-offenders..I don't just run for myself, I run to raise awareness and for others too. Seeing my friends from church and outside as well as family really shows how far we have come in opening up to ex-offenders." When asked about his most memorable runs so far, he cheekily shares that they have been the last two Yellow Ribbon Prison Runs. When asked why, he shared that having his wife support him and running with friends really helped to show that everyone deserves a second chance at life. SG4SecondChances 10YRsAndRunning

To commemorate our upcoming 10th Yellow Ribbon Prison Run, we're taking a trip down memory lane. Don't miss our Thursday series as we show you the run through the years! The highlight of the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run 2012 was the recordturnout of 10,000 participants. Themed The Road toAcceptance, the unique run route led runners to a carnival at the endpoint, where they were joined by fellow supporters from Fajar Secondary School and corporations like Tiger Balm Active, Pokka and Gold 90.5fm.Yellow Ribbon Champion, Mdm Jenap Said also pledged her support for ex-offenders by embarking on her Dusk Till Dawn Challenge an overnight 12hours marathon before the official flag-off at Yellow Ribbon Prison Run 2012.Through her inspirational effort, she raised $120,000 for the Yellow RibbonFund.Were you one of the participants back in 2012? If so, let us know your experience in the comments below! SG4SecondChances 10YRsAndRunning

The Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) honoured 88 organisations and individuals at the SCORE Appreciation Awards Ceremony today..Themed Strengthening Collaboration, Enhancing Skills this year, the SCORE Appreciation Awards Ceremony recognised the invaluable contributions of various partners who support SCORE in rebuilding the lives of ex-offenders by helping them enhance their employability potential..Graced by Guest-of-Honour, Mr Ong Ye Kung, Minister for Education, the event also showcased the testimonies of some of the award winners and reformed ex-offenders. Through these anecdotes, the event hopes to inspire many others to come forward to build a more inclusive and supportive working environment for ex-offenders.SG4SecondChances

To commemorate our upcoming 10th Yellow Ribbon Prison Run, we're taking a trip down memory lane. Don't miss our Thursday series as we show you the run through the years! The Inaugural Yellow Ribbon Prison Run held on 6 September 2009, saw 6,000 runners, including ex-offenders, coming forward in support of the Yellow Ribbon cause. Themed Beyond the Run, the run was all about giving ex-offenders a second chance to start life afresh. One of Yellow Ribbons success stories, Mr Hanniel Choong also came forward to attempt to break his personal record of finishing 10km in 48 minutes. Many runners, inspired by his story, came forward to support his attempt and made pledges to the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF). Hanniels 10K48 challenge was done under 45 minutes and in the process, managed to raise about $40,000 for YRF!Were you one of the first participants back in 2009? If so, let us know your experience in the comments below! SG4SecondChances 10YRsAndRunning

The Yellow Ribbon Project and Composers and Authors Society of Singapore (COMPASS) jointly organised the Yellow Ribbon Song Writing Competition recently to champion the rehabilitation process of inmates and provide them with new skills that would enhance their employability.Popular singer-songwriter duo Jack and Rai have been involved in the Yellow Ribbon Songwriting Competition for the past few years as artist mentors. For Jack, this was his third time as a judge and what impressed him was the commitment of the participants in putting their heart and soul into the songs. Describing the competition as getting tougher and tougher every year, he describes happily that every year, the inmates bring more passion into their music. Rai spent his third year as the lead mentor getting every participant up to speed. Working closely with the participants, he guided them to better their compositions without losing the essence. When asked to share words of encouragement to aspiring musicians, both chimed: "Keep practising, keep writing. Like chefs and soccer players, writing songs means putting it into practice and penning your thoughts down." Thank you to Jack, Rai, and everyone at COMPASS, for believing in second chances and for inspiring inmates to believe in themselves. SG4SecondChances

We're pleased to announce that LinkedIn and the Yellow Ribbon Project is working on a long-term partnership to conduct programs for ex-offenders who have recently graduated or are currently pursuing their diploma or degrees. LinkedInCoaches help them to be connected digitally and give guidance on optimising social profiles to expand their social network and find the career they desire. A total of 12 students from the Yellow Ribbon Fund STAR Bursary Programmes and Singapore After Care Association - Education Support Programmes attended the first workshop on 6 July.Thank you to our partners at LinkedIn and stay tuned for an interview video with some of the students and hear what they strive to achieve. SG4SecondChances

"Why do you think ex-offenders deserve a second chance?"."There are a lot of reason why people offend, there are a lot more reason why they should reintegrate back into society. There are also lot of success stories out there so we need to give ex-offenders the chance and avenues to succeed.".MotivationalMonday SG4SecondChances

"Why do you think ex-offenders should be given a second chance?"."To err is to be human. I think we have to start having an open mindset from young, understand the obstacles they face and not judge them.".MotivationalMonday SG4SecondChances

"Don't care about what people say about you, prove it to them. Focus on what you want to achieve and don't be afraid to ask for help when you need it." These are the words that Siti Sarah, 29, a Yellow Ribbon Fund Skills Training Assistance to Restart (YRF STAR) Bursary Recipient shared with us when we caught up with her recently..Education, to her, was a way of showing her family and friends that she had changed and was willing to restart. She also shared that with education, she could upgrade herself to find a better job to support her family in the future. Being open with herself and her family about her motivations has helped Sarah and her family grow even closer. Acceptance and support from her family in taking care of Sarah and her three children has made a huge difference too..We wish Sarah all the best as she continues to pursue her Diploma in Computer Engineering!.SG4SecondChances YRConfessions

As part of SCORE, Ravi Subramanian, Senior Director, Reintegration & Aftercare of the Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) looks after the reintegration and aftercare for ex-offenders. He also looks to enhance the employability of inmates through skills training to prepare inmates for reintegration..Speaking about how the CARE Network has to stay relevant in this day and age, he shared that members of the CARE Network "must constantly update themselves with new competencies to best handle reintegration and rehabilitation of ex-offenders"..SG4SecondChances

Andy Lee, Acting Head, Aftercare Department, Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association (SANA) shared about how SANA plays an active role in supporting drug abusers in their rehabilitation journey under the CARE Network..Andy shared about how he had been a Senior Social Worker before and some of the recurring issues that these ex-offenders face include accommodation, employment, and family support. Andy hopes to see more outreach programmes to engage families. "It is especially important to reach out to families as it is not just one person but a whole system and so, trying to help the families as a whole instead of just one person is one thing we are trying to do..SG4SecondChances MotivationalMonday

Heya folks, its the moment youve been waiting for - registration is finally open! Click our link in bio to enjoy early bird prices when you register from now till 22 July.This year is a little special for us as well be celebrating a decade of Yellow Ribbon Runs. So lets come together to run for second chances and greater acceptance for ex-offenders and their families this 9 September. We cant wait to see you. 10YRsandRunning

Mdm J is 68 years old. She is a grandmother to 13 grandchildren - 9 of which are affected by incarceration. She describes her family as a happy one that is, before drugs tore her family apart in 2015 - resulting in her son and his wife being sent behind bars, leaving their children helpless. She spends her days taking care of the nine children by shuttling them to various enrichment activities organised by the Yellow Brick Road Programme and making sure that their days are full..To me the YBR is good because it has a lot of activities. They have even included programmes for me as a caregiver! she laughs..YRConfessions MotivationalMonday

Thomas Liao, Social Work Associate at Fei Yue Community Services has a comeback story with a happy ending that inspires everyone who reads it.."I have been helped by many people so I also understand the importance of acceptance and helping someone. Through these experiences, I hope (that) I can also help and share this experience with other people"..Read more about Thomas on our Facebook page!.SG4SecondChances

One major challenge that ex-offenders face, is the drastic change to Singapores landscape especially when theyre released after three years or longer, explained Elvis. Some ex-offenders may not be familiar with using smartphones, software, apps or even topping up their EZ-link cards..As the Deputy Director of Industrial & Services Co-operative Society (ISCOS), Mr Elvis Overee shares about how the recently launched Project Reconnect has been doing a lot of good in the community. Project Reconnect caters to ex-offenders who have been incarcerated for more than three years and who have little family or social support. Upon their release, these ex-offenders are provided with assistance through educational programmes on basic yet essential life skills, including the use of smartphones, software, apps or even topping up their EZ-link cards..SG4SecondChances

It was the look of extreme disappointment on his mother's face that propelled Mr Ramli Bin Abdullah to change for the better. "I had disappointed her for so many times and this was going to be the last." In 2012, he finally decided to turn his life around for the sake of his mother, now 74, who had been the only one in the family who visited him in prison..Taking it upon himself to prove his naysayers wrong about how a "leopard never changes it's spots", Ramli does his best everyday to show that anyone can change, by volunteering as a preventive drug education speaker with Central Narcotics Bureau, a citizen-on-patrol with Singapore Police Force and one he's most proud of, a Befriender with Singapore Prison Services (SPS)..SG4SecondChances

During the CARE Network Workplan Seminar yesterday, Senior Parliamentary Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs and Health, Mr Amrin Amin highlighted the strong aftercare eco-system, supported by both professionals and volunteers..Having grown from eight key partners to over 100 partners to date, the CARE Network continues to play a key role in bringing together various agencies to innovate and look for novel ways to approach aftercare..Along with our volunteers, who are crucial to the success of our programmes, the CARE Network will continue to find ways to enhance our programmes in order to tackle the changing needs and demographics of beneficiaries..SG4SecondChances

Did you know?.The Singapore Prison Service and Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises provide industry-relevant skill training to inmates to prepare them for their eventual reintegration into the community. With a WSQ Certificate in Culinary Arts, we aim to build a pool of talented and trained chefs for the F&B industry and to aid in their rehabilitation and reintegration journey through sustainable employment. Our inmates are taught to cook local delights such as Kway Teow, Nasi Lemak and Roti Prata. But never CrispyRendang..RendanGate RendangIsNotCrispy RendangGate

Today, on InternationalWomensDay, we celebrate two extraordinary women who have worked quietly, selflessly and relentlessly to empower female ex-offenders and raise awareness for secondchances.. Grace Wong and Lau Leng Hoe (affectionately called Auntie Leng), co-founded ic HUB a secular shelter for homeless female ex-offenders and women in recovery from addictions back in 2013. Since then, the shelter has helped over 100 women get back on their feet and successfully reintegrate back into society. The women are given social support, assistance in job placement and help with finding permanent housing arrangements. While the women wait for job placements, Auntie Leng teaches them how to bake and shares her special recipe for melt-in-the-mouth pineapple tarts and cookies so that the women are given the chance to earn an income and start their lives anew.. Some months are more challenging than others and Grace does not bring home a salary sometimes. Sometimes I ask myself what am I doing and whether it is all worth it, she says ruefully. However, she sees this as a calling to change how ex-offenders are viewed, especially female ex-offenders who have to overcome obstacles like bringing up children single-handedly.. When asked how the community can better help female ex-offenders, she simply says, I think we should have more compassion and dont be quick to judge others. If you would like to show your support, you can order Auntie Lengs cookies via our link on Facebook!. SG4SecondChances

John (not his real name) was first admitted to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre in 2016 and subsequently placed on the Residential Scheme (electronic home tagging) as he showed signs of reform and had strong family support.. When asked how he had started consuming drugs, John mentioned that it was a form of escapism from the side effects of his nose cancer treatment.. Johns journey started when he was placed on electronic home tagging and had strict curfew hours to abide by. The strict hours helped him gain discipline. At work, he never felt shunned: Everyone treats me normally, to them, I am not an offender, he recalled of his colleagues.. He also received assistance from SCORE through job coaching and a counsellor who taught him how to strengthen family ties. To date, John has completed his Certificate in Maritime Business, is now pursuing a Diploma and applying for the Yellow Ribbon Star Bursary.. Congratulations John, and we wish you all the best! . YRConfessions

A total of 108 artworks will be displayed at the tenth edition of the Yellow Ribbon Community Art Exhibition at the Singapore Art Museum. Themed For Better Endings and New Beginnings, the exhibition expresses the inmates resolve in righting past wrongs, and starting anew with their loved ones.The exhibition will run from 7 October 22 October 2017, 10 am to 7 pm from Saturdays to Thursdays and 10 am to 9 pm on Fridays. Admission is free.

Good morning everyone, I am Shariff the Bladerunner! Ive been supporting the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run for the past eight years.For those who dont know me, I am a marathon enthusiast born without a left foot and I run with a prosthetic blade. Being part of the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run enables me to encourage other runners to keep on moving and pledge their support for second chances. This year I would like to share what its like to prepare for the run from my point of view! Stay tuned to this page to find out more!
