DID YOU KNOW? Everyone has a reason to run and let me share with you my YRReasonToRun.Yellow Ribbon Prison Run was the first ever running race when I started running in 2012, and it has always held a special place in my heart. I joined the run as my friends were taking part in it, and the fact that the cause resonates with me. It is important to give second chances to people and we should not be judged by our past mistakes.If youre coming down for the Prison Run, dont forget to share YRReasonToRun on social media and stand to win attractive prizes!

WHATS IN MY BAG: I will be carrying the essentials, mobile phone, a little money, EZ-Link card, keys and a Poke ball charger to fuel my phone on long runs and to catch le wild pokemon along the run route.

Some tips for you guys for the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run! 1. Start out slow and conservative so that you can finish strong and feel good when you finish. Do not get caught up in the hype and adrenaline and dash out from the start line.2. Do not try anything new, too, on race day. Do not wear new shoes for the first time on race day, as this will increase your chance of getting blisters.3. Hydrate yourself well! There will be enough water points on race day. Make use of them and drink at each water station.4. Grab a pre-workout snack two to three hours before the run and youre good to go!5. Lastly, put on your earpiece for some energetic songs to keep you going for the run.

MY TRAINING REGIME: Ive been training with Coached, a heart rate training programme that allows helps me to track and optimise my training. To prepare for the Prison Runs hilly slopes, Ill also attend hill sessions and track sessions with the members from Coached on Tuesday and Thursday. During the weekends, I like to do long run and strength run trainings which require me to focus on running within specific heart rate zones.

Last week, volunteers from the Yellow Ribbon Fund (YRF) celebrated Childrens Day with beneficiaries under the Yellow Brick Road Programme at West Coast Park.The children were engaged in interactive activities and games such as the Family Relay, which gave them an opportunity to spend time with their families while bonding with the volunteers. This event lets the children know that they are not forgotten by the community, said Mrs Wong Ai Ai, Chairman of the YRF.The Yellow Brick Road Programme was developed in 2014 with the aim of reducing the detrimental effects of incarceration and burden on families and children of inmates. In July this year, the Yellow Brick Road Programme was enhanced with a focus on building the future of offenders children with one-to-one home-based tuition and developing hidden potential and talents through social enrichment workshops. Wishing everyone (yes, even the inner child) a Happy Childrens Day from all of us at the Yellow Ribbon Project!

The ninth Yellow Ribbon Community Art Exhibition, themed From Night to Light, was held at the Singapore Art Museum (SAM) last month. Eighty one pieces of artwork by inmates and former offenders were on display, symbolising the emotional journey that inmates undergo when incarcerated.SAM provides a platform for inmates to showcase their artworks and publicly express their artistic passions. During previous editions, the curator selected pieces for display after the inmates have completed it. This year, the curator worked alongside with the inmates and the project manager to develop the inspiration behind their artwork. Working closely with the night festival, the theme illustrates their journey behind bars and actually came from the inmates. As this is not something that is dictated to them, they felt a sense of ownership, Andrea Fam, Assistant Curator at SAM.Proceeds from the adoption of artworks will go towards the Yellow Ribbon Fund, which supports a variety of rehabilitation and reintegration programmes as well as family support programmes. Drop us a PM to find out more!

Royal Plaza on Scotts, a Spark of Hope Award recipient at the recent SCORE Appreciation Awards Ceremony, has been partnering with Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) since 2012.Their first hire through SCORE was Mr Shaharuddin Bin Mokhtar, who began working as a trainee cook after his release. With the support from both the Yellow Ribbon Fund STAR Bursary and allowance provided by Royal Plaza on Scotts, Mr Shaharuddin simultaneously undertook a Diploma in Culinary Skills from SHATEC. He has since been promoted to a 1st Cook as a result of his good work ethic and desire to learn. My ex-wife was asking for divorce at that time, that really made me change. All this while I promised my ex-wife, my kids, my mum and dad, and every one that I would change, but in the end I didnt. So now I needed to change for myself, before I can prove it to them that I can change. Mr Shaharuddin now acts as a mentor to other ex-offenders in the company, and is also a Peer Leader with the Singapore Anti-Narcotics Association (SANA), sharing his past experiences to help ex-offenders in their reintegration journeys. [Working with Shaharuddin] gave us the confidence that changes are really possible and theres a good source of manpower that we can really look at, says Ms Ong Pau Hsing Juliana, Director of Human Resources at Royal Plaza on Scotts. Ex-offenders need the support of employers and the community in order to successfully reintegrate into society. Drop us a PM to find out more about how you can employ ex-offenders and make a difference in their lives!

Did you know that our unique run route features the Johore Battery? Built in 1939 by the British Army, Johore Battery comprises a labyrinth of underground tunnels used to store ammunition for three 15-inch Monster guns constructed to defend Singapore. Have you ever heard of the story of the boy and the starfish? This story resonates firmly with our beliefs at the Yellow Ribbon Project, so much so that it has inspired us to create a sea-like wall at the centre of the rehabilitation fair, where visitors can paste their messages of acceptance and encouragement for second chances. If you havent heard of the story before, read it here. Its truly inspiring. ...One day, a man was walking along the beach, when he noticed a boy hurriedly picking up and gently throwing things into the ocean.Approaching the boy, he asked, Young man, what are you doing? The boy replied, Throwing starfish back into the ocean. The sea is up and the tide is out. If I dont throw them back, they will die. The man laughed to himself and said, Havent you realized that there are kilometres and kilometres of beach with hundreds of starfish stranded? You cant make a difference! After listening politely, the boy bent down, picked up another starfish, and threw it into the sea. Then smiling at the man, he said, I made a difference to that one. YRSecondChance

The Singapore Corporation of Rehabilitative Enterprises (SCORE) Appreciation Awards Ceremony is an annual event organised to recognise the invaluable contributions of various partners who have supported SCORE in the rehabilitation and reintegration of ex-offenders. We sat down with Ms Juliana Binti Abdul Khalik, SCOREs Director of Reintegration, to learn more about their initiatives. Ms Juliana shared how SCORE is dedicated to enhancing the employability of ex-offenders, as employment is a key factor in their successful reintegration into society. Other than being given opportunities to participate in work programmes during incarceration, SCORE helps prepare ex-offenders for work by ensuring that training provided is relevant so that employers will have greater confidence when hiring. The trainings are also aligned with the WDAs Workforce Skills Qualification Framework, ensuring offenders attend the same type of training as other Singaporean job seekers. Deepening the commitment to the rehabilitation and reintegration of ex-offenders, SCORE will be extending its job retention support to 12 months for ex-offenders this year. A differentiated approach will also be adopted to assist ex-offenders with differing levels of job fit and commitment. With the new approach, this will increase employers confidence in partnering SCORE to offer employment opportunities, added Ms Juliana. Together with the communitys support and ex-offenders determination, lets keep striving towards successful reintegration for these ex-offenders.SecondChancesEveryday

Here at the Yellow Ribbon Project, it warms our hearts to see success stories of reformation and reintegration amongst ex-offenders. Speaking to Mr. William Toh Chor Kok confirmed our belief that love goes a long way in changing lives. During his teenage years, Mr. Toh found himself in bad company, when he dabbled with drugs and became an addict soon after. He was apprehended by the police at the early age of 20 and found that the cycle of re-offending was immensely tough for him to break out of. As a result, he spent a total of 13 years in and out of drug rehabilitation centers.The turning point for him was when he saw the enduring love of his family, leading to him questioning his identity and future. Daunting thoughts on whether he would be known as a mere drug addict all his life and whether or not the cycle of re-offending would ever end caused him to realise that he needed to set his priorities straight and pick up important values such as discipline and abstinence, so that he could better continue on his journey of reformation.His journey of change was tough as it required him to make consistent and conscious decisions to do things that would help steer him on his journey of change. As a result of his determination, he was able to stand strong against the influences and become the person that he longed to become.Today, Mr. Toh spreads his love by volunteering with the Prison Fellowship Singapore, sharing with inmates how he had overcome his personal demons with the hope that they would be able to break out of the re-offending cycle too. During these sessions, he emphasises the need to believe and to hang on to love, as well as the importance for everyone to give their own self a second chance.SpreadYRLoveSecondChancesEveryday

During the 4th Care Network Workplan Seminar which took place yesterday, we got the opportunity to meet the dedicated and passionate Yellow Ribbon Community Project (YRCP) volunteers.These trained volunteers have been a great source of support to families of newly-incarcerated offenders. They have taken the time to understand the needs of the families and bridged them with relevant social support networks in Singapore.Our community plays a critical role in keeping Singapore safe by contributing to the rehabilitation journey of offenders and providing support for their families.Once again, we would like to extend our heartfelt thanks to all our YRCP volunteers.SecondChancesEverydayYRCPVolunteers

Every day is a new day and a fresh start to learn, grow, develop your strengths, heal yourself from past regrets or hurts, and move forward older and wiser. Every day gives you a chance to reinvent yourself, to fine-tune who you are, and build on lessons of what you have learned. It is never too late to change things that are not working in your life and switch gears, instead of thinking in the same old ways, hoping for a different outcome.SecondChancesEveryday

We have overcome challenges in the past, and will continue to do so in the future as long as we stand united as one nation RememberingLKYTributeToLKY
Singaporeans will long remember and honour Mr Lee Kuan Yew for bringing the people together to build our nation RememberingLKYTributeToLKY

Today we mourn the passing of our founding Prime Minister, Mr Lee Kuan Yew. A legacy to all Singaporeans, Mr Lee devoted his life to the making of Singapore and ruled with a vision to break new grounds. In this moment of grief, we honour his spirit of dedication to serving Singapore and Singaporeans. Let us stay true to the ideals that Mr Lee fought for and remind ourselves to continue striving to realise his vision of a fair and meritocratic nation that stays united. Thank you for your dedication, Mr Lee. You will be greatly missed. If you would like to express your condolences and share your memories of the late Mr Lee, visit the official website: TributeToLKY

Hope was lovingly painted by an offender from the Visual Arts Hub, Changi Prison Complex using acrylic paint on canvas. The hope of a nation rests on its foundations the hands that hold up the building blocks provide a safe and secure environment. YRArt

Today we mourn the passing of Mr Subhas Anandan, a legend in the courtroom, who is known to have dedicated his life towards fighting for the rights of accused persons and for having a profound compassion and empathy for inmates. He was also a strong believer that every ex-offender deserves a second chance to fulfil their dreams and ambitions after serving their time. In this spirit, the Association of Muslim Lawyers launched the Yellow Ribbon Subhas Anandan Star Bursary Award in October 2014 as a tribute to the honourable work that Mr Subhas has accomplished. The bursary will provide financial support to ex-offenders who wish to further their studies and pave the way to a fresh start in life. Thank you for championing second chances, Mr Subhas Anandan, you will be greatly missed.

Calling all students from secondary schools, junior colleges, polytechnics and centralised institutes. Student teams must register by 15 September and submit their videos by 15 November. Voting will be held on our Facebook page from 24 Nov to 14 Dec. The video with the most number of likes and support will win cash prizes of up to $300 and win goodie bags. Tell us your story, show us your creativity and sign up now. To register email us at yrp.school.videos.com
Our pledges run for the Yellow Ribbon Project to champion the cause of second chances. If you have already registered, complete the following sentence: "I run for Yellow Ribbon Project because..."
